Gonzaga (1).Entry Details: prob. Ercole GONZAGA; poss. Francesco GONZAGA.

Gonzaga, Carlo.Entry Details: 15th-century soldier of Mantua, member of the Gonzaga family, rulers of Mantua; he betrayed Milan by admitting to the city the troops of Francesco SFORZA.

Gonzaga (2).Entry Details: Ercole, 1505-63, cardinal of the Roman Church and regent of the Duchy of Mantua; a patron of the arts and learning, presided over the Council of Trent.

Gonzaga, Fran°.Entry Details: Gian Francesco, d. 1519, Lord of Mantua (1484-1519).

Gonzaga, Luigi.Entry Details: 1267-1360, founder of the house of Gonzaga, which ruled Mantua from 1328 to 1708, Luigi became captain-general of Mantua in 1328.

Good Hope.Entry Details: the cape at the tip of South Africa.

Goodwin.Entry Details: Sir Francis, principal of the Goodwin Case (1604) in which Parliament asserted its right to be the sole judge of the election returns of its own members.

Gosindi.Entry Details: Pierre Gassendi, 1592-1655, French philosopher, theologian, and physicist; author of the Syntagma Philosophicum.

Gospel Society of London.Entry Details: the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts, a missionary arm of the Church of England; it was powerful but disliked in colonial America.

Gould, Joe.Entry Details: Greenwich Village, N.Y., bohemian, and writer.

Gourdon.Entry Details: city in Provence, N of Toulouse; associated with troubadour poetry.

Governor (2).Entry Details: a viceroy of Honan province in AD 1728.

G.P..Entry Details: poss. Gaby Picabia, wife of Francis Picabia, French painter; Madame Picabia was a member of the French Resistance in World War II.

Graces.Entry Details: the Charites, three Greek goddesses, Aglaia, Thalia, and Euphrosyne, personifications of beauty and charm; often associated with the MUSES, DIONYSUS, EROS, and APHRODITE.

Gradonico, Tomasso.Entry Details: prob. Gradenigo, a member of the Consiglio der DIECI in Venice.

Graham.Entry Details: prob. R. B. Cunninghame Graham, 1852-1936, Scottish essayist, biographer, and world traveler, noted for his journey by horse through South America.

Gd Ducal Palace.Entry Details: the Grand Ducal Palace in Siena.

Grand Duke (1).Entry Details: see LEOPOLD II, Holy Roman Emperor.

Granham.Entry Details: a trade name for a type of fly used in fishing.

Granville.Entry Details: prob. Harley Granville-Barker, 1877-1946, English actor, manager, and playwright.

Grasse.Entry Details: city in France where soap and other products are manufactured from fats; it is also the center of the perfume industry of Provence.

Grcolini, Cenzio.Entry Details: prob. a notary of Florence in 1622.

Grcolini, Orazio.Entry Details: fl. 1622, prob. secretary of MARIA MAGDELENA and Orazio della RENA.

Gt Tichfield St.Entry Details: street in central London, crosses Langham Street, where Pound once lived (1908).

Gt Tower Hill.Entry Details: hill near the Tower of London where the gallows formerly stood, in the 18th century it was an area of fine residences.

Great Wall of China.Entry Details: (Ch.: Chang-chêng), the defensive wall of China, extending 1250 miles from Mongolia to China Proper; started in the 3rd century BC and finished in BC 204 by Emperor TSIN-CHI.

Greek armies.Entry Details: the armies of Agamemnon in the Trojan War.

Greek classics.Entry Details: the classic works of Greek literature.

Greek Emperor.Entry Details: John VIII Palaeologus, 1391-1448, son of Manuel II, Emperor (1425-48), attended the Council of Ferrara-Florence (1438) with GEMISTUS.

Green.Entry Details: prisoner in a "security cage" near Pound, DTC, Pisa.

Gregory.Entry Details: Theodor Emanuel Gugenheim, 189? - English economist, author of Gold, Unemployment and Capitalism (1933).

Grenville.Entry Details: George, 1712-1770, Prime Minister under GEORGE III (1763-65), his most famous act was the creation of the Stamp Act (1765), he also tried to enforce the Sugar Act. Neither did him much good.

Grey.Entry Details: a casual acquaintance made by John ADAMS in England.

Gridley (1).Entry Details: Jeremiah, 1702-1767, American lawyer and attorney general of Massachusetts Bay Province, in 1761 he defended the legality of the WRITS OF ASSISTANCE.

Gridley (2).Entry Details: Benjamin, fl. 1768, loyalist lawyer practicing in Boston, left America in 1776.

Gridley of Abingdon.Entry Details: a farmer (?) named Greenleaf, resident of Abington, Mass.

Griffiths.Entry Details: Arthur Griffith, 1872-1922, Irish political leader; founder and editor of the United Irishmen, a Journal; founder and leader of the Sinn Fein Movement (1906), which worked for the establishment of an Irish parliament united to the British Parliament only by the Crown.

Grillparzer.Entry Details: Franz, 1791-1872, the Austrian playwright and poet.

Grimaldi.Entry Details: Philippe, fl. 1691, Jesuit missionary in China.

Grishkin.Entry Details: allusion to character in T.S. ELIOT's poem, Whispers of Immortality.

Grosvenor Sq..Entry Details: the fashionable square in London, residence of John ADAMS when he was in London.

Grouchy.Entry Details: Emmanuel, Marquis de, 1766-1847, French general in the French Revolution and the Napoleonic wars. Because he failed to prevent the Prussians from joining the British, he was largely responsible for Napoleon's disaster at Waterloo.

Guadaloupe.Entry Details: the name applied to two islands of the French West Indies: Basse-Terre and Grande Terre; the two are separated by a narrow channel.

Gualdo.Entry Details: Gualdo Tadino, town in Perugia province, central Italy.

Gubberton.Entry Details: prob. reference to Surbiton, a town on the Thames, Surrey, England.

Guiduccioli.Entry Details: prob. the representative of Carlo MALATESTA at the arrangements for the marriage of Carlo's daughter, Parasina MALATESTA, to Niccolo d'ESTE in 1418.

Gulf of St. Lawrence.Entry Details: the gulf off E coast of Canada.

Gutta.Entry Details: Gytta, a town on the Atlantic coast of North Africa, founded by HANNO, just S of KARIKON.

Guys.Entry Details: Constantin, 1802-92, newspaper illustrator for the Illustrated London News during the Crimean War; settled in Paris (c. 1865) where he sketched the life and manners of the Second Empire.

Gyges.Entry Details: a Lydian secreted by Candaules, king of Lydia, so Gyges could see the beauty of the naked queen; discovering his presence, the queen forced Gyges to kill Candaules and marry her.

H., Captain.Entry Details: prob. an English officer of the Black and Tans at the time (1916) of the Irish Rebellion.

H..Entry Details: poss. Ernest HEMINGWAY; poss. Adolf HITLER, poss. Henri GAUDIER-Brezska.

H., old.Entry Details: poss. Henry MORGENTHAU, poss. Sisley HUDDLESTON.

H., young.Entry Details: poss. Henry MORGENTHAU, Jr., poss. Ernest HEMINGWAY.

[Haarlem].Entry Details: city of North Holland province in W Netherlands, near Amsterdam.

Habana.Entry Details: La Habana (Sp) Havana, capital of CUBA.

hac dextera mortus.Entry Details: (L) hac dextera mortuus dead by this right hand. (See. Literary Essays, 270).

hac local fluvius alluit.Entry Details: (L) haec loca these places the river washes.

Haec sunt fastae.Entry Details: (L) haec sunt fasti (?) these are the festivals (?)

hagoromo.Entry Details: the feather-mantle in the Noh play, Hagoromo.

Haig.Entry Details: Douglas, 1861-1928, British marshal, commander-in-chief of expeditionary forces in France and Flanders (1915-19); he served under French Marshal Foch during the final stages of the Allied advance.

[Haile Selassie].Entry Details: 1891- , Haile Selassie I, emperor of Ethiopia (1930- ).

Hai men.Entry Details: (Hai-men), a department of what is now Kiangsu province, China.

Hakluyt.Entry Details: Richard, ?1552-1616, the English historian and geographer.

Halbach.Entry Details: see Gustav KRUPP VON BOHLEN UND HALBACH.

Hales.Entry Details: Sir Edward, fl. 1686, principal in a law case by which JAMES II attempted to establish the Crown's dispensing power in regard to the Test Act; having failed to gain support for such power from Parliament, James tried to secure it by the verdict of the judiciary (1686).

\"half dead at the top\".Entry Details: from W. B. Yeats, Blood and the Moon, I, IV.

Hamilcar.Entry Details: Hamilcar Barca, ? 270-228, Carthaginian general who commanded in Sicily (247-41) and in Spain (237-28); father of HANNIBAL.

Hamilton.Entry Details: Alexander, 1753-1804, American statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1782, 83, 87, 88), first U. S. Secretary of the Treasury (1789-95). As a supporter of a strong federal government, Hamilton was instrumental in securing the ratification of the CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES, especially in New York. Under WASHINGTON's administration, he established a national fiscal system and placed public credit on a sound basis; retaining much of his control of the Cabinet during John ADAMS' administration, he hampered Adams' attempts to maintain peace and fostered the emergence of political parties. Hamilton was wounded in a duel with Aaron BURR on 11 July 1804 and died 12 July.

Hamish.Entry Details: prob. Dave Hamish (or Fowler in Faber text); evidently associated with MENELIK II of Ethiopia, but exact information unknown.

Hammerton, Cyril.Entry Details: a pseudonym having no particular reference.

hamomila de hampo.Entry Details: (It) prob. campanile de campo bell tower of the Campo (Siena) (in Tuscan dialect); poss. camamilla de campo. the camomile of the field (in Tuscan dialect).

Han (5).Entry Details: a feudal kingdom of China, roughly the area of SZECH-WAN province, formerly one of the THREE KINGDOMS.

Han (6).Entry Details: a principality in the provinces of SHENSI and HONAN on both sides of the Hwang-ho; established in BC 453.

Han (7).Entry Details: prob. the After Han dynasty (947-51); (Yin Ti, the last emperor of the After Han, was eighteen when he came to the throne).

Hananel.Entry Details: (Heb) God is gracious. (See: TOWER OF HANANEL).

Hancock.Entry Details: John, 1737-93, American merchant and statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1775-80, 1785, 86), first signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, governor of Massachusetts (1780-85; 1787-93).

Han Ho Ti.Entry Details: (reign 89-106), during his reign the military fame of China was higher than ever before; and at this time the first eunuch was raised to the rank of mandarin, thus setting a precedent that led to many seditions and intrigues in later years of the Empire.

Han-hou].Entry Details: (Han Hu) fl. BC 800, a military officer during the time of SIUEN-OUANG, for his services in battle Han-hou was given the districts of YUEI and Me, which he developed into important principalities.

Han-houon-ti.Entry Details: (Han Huan Ti) (reign 147-168), in 158 he did away with his corrupt prime minister, LEANG-KI, and confiscated his estate, which amounted to three hundred million TAEL. Because he had so much money, Han-houon-t remitted the land tax for a year; he also built a temple to honor LAO-TSE.

Hanibal.Entry Details: Annibale di Constantino Cerboni da Castello, agent of Domenico MALATESTA to the Venetians.

Han-kiang.Entry Details: the Han river, which flows through SHENSI and Hupeh provinces and into the YANGTSE river at Hankow, (kiang = river in Chinese).

Hanjong.Entry Details: (Han Jung) fl. AD 1347, an imperial inspector serving Emperor CHUNTI. When Hanjong found temples on land needed for cultivation, he had the temples destroyed, when he found young people who wanted to learn, he had schools established.

Han-lin-eul].Entry Details: (Han Lin-erh) d. AD 1367. In 1355 the WHITE LILY SOCIETY proclaimed him emperor of a new Sung dynasty and he set up a capital at Po-chou in Anhwei province, calling himself by the dynastic title Ming Wang. This new Sung dynasty was created in opposition to Emperor CHUNTI of the YUAN dynasty and was one of many such ventures during the reign of this last Mongol emperor. As a symbol of revolt, Han-lin-eul's dynasty was effective, but it was not permanent.

Han Ling.Entry Details: Han-ling-ti (Han Ling Ti) (reign. 168-90). His reign was distinguished while TÉOU-CHI was regent and her father Tou Wu (d. AD 167) prime minister, but the chief eunuch persuaded the emperor that Tou Wu was dangerous, so Han-ling-ti executed the prime minister and banished the queen dowager. In 184 an outbreak in the northern provinces started the series of calamities that brought the downfall of the HAN dynasty.

Han Ming.Entry Details: Han-ming-ti (Han Ming Ti) (reign: 58-76). This emperor has the reputation of having introduced Buddhism, and consequently idolatry, into China. Hearing that there was a holy man in the west named FOÉ, he sent ambassadors to discover his teachings and bring back books of his doctrines.

Han Ngan.Entry Details: Han-ngan-ti (Han An Ti) (reign: 107-25). He was a very just emperor; but unfortunately he elevated women to the rank of court officials, and from this time there was great corruption in the court, justice was perverted, and honest men driven from the government.

Hannibal.Entry Details: 247/182, Carthaginian general who led the forces of Carthage against Rome in the Second Punic War (218-201).

Hanno.Entry Details: C. BC 470, the Carthaginian navigator who led an expedition through the Straits of Gibraltar and founded seven towns on the Atlantic shore of Morocco; the account of his voyage is The Periplus of Hanno.

Han Ou.Entry Details: Han-ou-ti (Han Wu Ti) (reign: 140-86). Had not this emperor been a believer in the Taoist magicians, the philosophy of Confucianism might have become supreme in the empire; Han-ou-ti laid the first general property tax in China.

Hanover.Entry Details: an electoral house of Germany and a royal family of England. Hanoverian Kings of England were George I, George II, GEORGE III, George IV, William IV, and VICTORIA (1714-1801).

Han Ping.Entry Details: Han-ping-ti (Han Ping Ti) (reign 1-6). Since he was only nine when he came to the throne, the empire was ruled by Wang Mang, an evil minister who usurped all power and finally murdered Han-ping-ti.

Hanseatic.Entry Details: the German commercial cities which formed the Hanseatic League.

Han-Siuen-ti.Entry Details: (Han Hsüan Ti) (reign 73-48), an able emperor who, in 65, sent out Kung Su to deal with the many men who had turned brigand during a famine, Kung-su said that every man with a hoe on his shoulder would be treated as an honest man, every poor man was invited to present his case to the emperor, and farmers without seed were assisted.

Hans of Kalkas.Entry Details: the kings (Han is a title) of the KALKAS.

Han Tchao Ti.Entry Details: Han-tchao-ti (Han Chao Ti) (reign. 86-74). In the second year of his reign he remitted the land tax in impoverished areas. When crops failed in 80 BC the emperor's ministers said, "pay more attention to the good government of the people." The people said they wanted taxes on salt, iron, spirits, and property abolished. Han-tchao-ti compromised and abolished taxes on spirits and property.

Han-tchéou.Entry Details: (Han-ch'ou), a large town in SZECHWAN province.

Han Yu.Entry Details: (Han Yü) fl. AD 819, judge of a tribunal which, in the time of emperor HIEN-TSONG, investigated Buddhism in the Empire. In a memorial to the emperor, Han-yu said that the Buddhists had been the ruin of many dynasties, that they had perverted the old ways of the Chinese, that they were a pernicious influence in the Empire, and that they and their temples should be stamped out.

Han Yuen.Entry Details: Han-yuen-ti (Han Yuan Ti) (reign 48-32). This emperor started his reign by cutting taxes and forcing the court to be economical; but he later came under the control of the eunuch Shih Hsien, who "seduced the emperor into immoral habits."

Hao tse.Entry Details: poss. (Ch) Tai-tsé (T'ai-tzu): chief prince or noble, a reference to Kong-sung-yang (Kung Sung-yang) who died in 338 BC.

Hapsburg-Lorraine.Entry Details: a ducal and ruling house of Europe, founded by Joseph II (1741-90) Holy Roman Emperor and King of Bohemia and Hungary.

Hard night, and parting at morning.Entry Details: variation of the titles of Browning's two poems, Meeting at Night and Parting at Morning.

harpes et luthes.Entry Details: (L) harps and lutes. (See: Villon, Au moustier voy dont suis paroissienne/ Paradis paint, où sont harpes et luthes)

Harriet.Entry Details: poss. Harriette Wilson, 1789-1846, in whose Memoirs (1825, ed. J. Laver, 19 29) there is an account of a discussion between Wellington and Harriette Wilson concerning the propriety of boots. It is to be noted, however, that the story the text seems to refer to is usually associated with the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough.

Harrison.Entry Details: William Henry, 1773-1841, ninth president of the U. S. (1841), serving only one month of his term in office before he died of pneumonia. He first gained fame in wars against the Indians (1811-12) and was known as "Tip" for his successful battles against the Indians at Tippecanoe (1811).

Hartford.Entry Details: city in N Connecticut on the Connecticut river.

Hartley.Entry Details: David, 1732-1813, English diplomat who, with Benjamin FRANKLIN, drafted and signed the peace treaty between the U. S. and Great Britain in 1783.

Hartmann.Entry Details: Sadakichi, 1867-1944, American poet, playwright and art critic.

Hashar.Entry Details: a petty court in the Bukhara region, W Asia.

Hast 'ou seen the rose in the steel dust.Entry Details: variation of Ben Jonson, The Triumph of Charis: "Have you seen but a bright lily grow Or swan's down ever?"

Hathor.Entry Details: an Egyptian fertility goddess, sometimes represented as a cow, sometimes as a combination of a cow and a woman.

Hatvany.Entry Details: prob. Bernhard and Joseph Deutsch, Jewish bankers of the town of Hatvan, titled 15 January 1879 as Deutsch de Hatvany. Bernhard Deutsch de Hatvany was Director of the Osterreich-Ungarische Bank in 1888. The sons were made Barons in June 1908.

Haute Brion.Entry Details: Haut Brion, a wine of Bordeaux.

Hawkins.Entry Details: William, 1673-1746, English lawyer, author of Treatise of the Pleas of the Crown (1716).

Hawkwood.Entry Details: Sir John de, d. 1394, an English soldier who fought in France with the Black Prince. With his "white company" of mercenaries Hawkwood entered Italy in 1362 and became a condottiere, serving any and all republics; finally he accepted a pension from Florence.

Hawley, Joseph.Entry Details: 1723-88, American political leader who was associated with James OTIS, Samuel ADAMS and John ADAMS. He was one of the first to urge a declaration of independence and a unified colonial administration.

Haworth.Entry Details: Colonel Howarth, fl. 1775, American army officer. (See: Adams, Works, II, 232).

Hay aqui mucho catolicismo, / y muy poco.Entry Details: (Sp) desaparecen: Here is much Catholicism/ and very little religion/ I believe that kings disappear.

Hayes, Rutherford.Entry Details: Rutherford Birchard Hayes, 1822-93, nineteenth President of the U. S. (1877-81).

Hebrew scriptures.Entry Details: either the Pentateuch or the Old Testament.

Heine.Entry Details: Heinrich, 1797-1856, the German lyric poet and literary critic.

helandros kai heleptolis kai helarxe.Entry Details: (Gr) destroyer of men, and destroyer of cities, and destroyer of governments. (See: Appendix A).

Heliads'.Entry Details: the daughters of HELIOS, they were changed into poplar trees as they mourned for their brother, Phaethon.

Helios.Entry Details: (Gr) the sun, the god of the sun who drove a four-horse chariot through the heavens.

Helvetius.Entry Details: Anne Catherine, Countess of Ligniville d'Autricourt, 1719-1800, wife of Claude Adrien Helvetius, the French philosopher.

hennia.Entry Details: (Jap) hannya. an evil spirit in Noh drama.

Henri, Herr.Entry Details: prob. Henri de Wendel, grandson of the original François de WENDEL and thus influential in French steel and banking circles.

Henriot.Entry Details: prob. Emile Henriot, (pseudonym for Emile Maigrot), 1889- , the French novelist and poet.

Henry (3).Entry Details: poss. Henry JAMES; poss. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow; poss. Henry NEWBOLT.

[Henry II].Entry Details: 1133-89, King of England (1154-89), m. ELEANOR of Aquitaine (1152).

Henry, Patrick.Entry Details: 1736-99, American Revolutionary leader, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-76), governor of Virginia (1776-79; 1784-86), U. S. Secretary of State (1795) and justice of the U. S. Supreme Court (1795).

[Heou-chou].Entry Details: (Hou-chou), a principality combining parts of the provinces of SHENSI and SZECHWAN; known as the Second Chou and lasted 925-65.

[Heou-tchu].Entry Details: (Hou Chu) (reign: 583-89). Not heeding the signs that his dynasty was at its end, this emperor pursued a course of extravagance and debauchery; he built three great buildings for his favorite concubines. When he was told that the Duke of Sour was about to overthrow the dynasty, Heou-tchu told his ministers not to worry because the rebellion would probably be unsuccessful -- it wasn't.

Heou-Tsie.Entry Details: (Hou Chi) fl. BC 2357, chief minister of agriculture and animal husbandry under Emperor YAO.

[Heraclitus].Entry Details: Greek philosopher of the 6th-5th century BC, known as the "Weeping Philosopher".

herbal.Entry Details: A book in which plants are named, described, and their officinal properties noted.

Herculaneum.Entry Details: Ancient city of Italy at the NW foot of Mt. Vesuvius, destroyed by the eruption of AD 79.

Hermes.Entry Details: The messenger and herald of the gods; the patron of merchants and thieves and the god of luck and wealth.

Hé Sloveny.Entry Details: (Russ) Hail the Slavic Peoples. (There are many Russian songs of this title).

Hesperus.Entry Details: The evening star. (See: Sappho, Ode to Hesperus).

Hewlett, Maurie.Entry Details: Maurice Henry Hewlett, 1861-1923, English essayist, novelist and poet.

[Heyman, Katherine].Entry Details: 1877-1944, American pianist; specialist in works of Scriabin; friend of Pound, London, 1908.

Hia (1).Entry Details: (Hsia), usually designated as the first dynasty of China (2205-1766).

Hia (2).Entry Details: (Hsia) a minor kingdom or principality in the region of Ordos, the island bordered on one side by the Hwang-ho and on the south by the GREAT WALL; the territory is on the north border of SHENSI and was occupied by Tartars.

Hianglou.Entry Details: (Hsiang-lu), a mountain near the KIANG river, probably in the province of HONAN.

Hiang-yu.Entry Details: (Hsiang Yü or Hsiang Chi) 233-202, a general who at first fought with LIEOU-PANG against the TSIN dynasty and then turned against him when the dynasty had been overthrown. Hiang-yu's forces were crushed in 202, and he killed himself.

Hiao Ching Hien Hoang Héou.Entry Details: (Hsiao-sheng, Hsien-huang-hou) d. AD 1777, empress dowager, mother of Emperor KIEN-LONG; after her death, she was given great honors by her son.

Hiao Hoei Ti.Entry Details: (Hsiao Hui Ti) (reign: 194-87), the son of KAO-HOANG-TI, he was a kind-hearted youth, but rather feeble-minded, and was completely controlled by the queen dowager, LIU-HEOU.

Hiao King.Entry Details: Hiao-king-ti (Hsiao Ching Ti) (reign: 156-140). In his second year as emperor there was a rebellion of feudal lords, they said they would disband their forces if the emperor would execute his chief counselor, Chao Tsu, who had urged the emperor to abolish all feudal dependencies. The peace terms were met, but the feudal lords attacked again and were not defeated until later.

Hiao-ouang.Entry Details: (Hsiao Wang) (reign 909-894), known as "The Filial", the brother of Y-OUANG. He was an undistinguished ruler whose reign was marked only by the appearance of FEI-TSEI, whose descendants were later to overthrow the Chou dynasty.

Hiao Ouen.Entry Details: Hiao-ouen-ti (Hsiao Wen Ti) (reign: 179-56), an emperor famous for his generosity, humanity and economy. He decreed that a man's family should not suffer for his crimes; he established the unit of money in the Empire and reserved for the government the sole right to coin money, for the punishments of mutilation, he substituted flogging and made beheading the only great punishment. He also ordered that the classical books be hunted out again and that scholars start studying them.

Hiao-ou-ti.Entry Details: (Hsiao Wu Ti) (reign: 453-464) Little happened during his reign, and he had no able minister to spur him to activity. The emperor was very frivolous, giving people of the court nicknames and having his servants chase the mandarins with a stick. Thus, there was no respect given the emperor, and Hiao-ou-ti is known as the "Discarded."

Hiao Tsong.Entry Details: (Hsiao Tsung) (reign: 1488-1505). He had able ministers and was able to institute several administrative reforms, stop internal rebellions, deal with Mongol invasions, and curtail the power of the eunuchs.

hic est medium mundi.Entry Details: (L) here is the center of the world.

Hic/ Jacet/ Fisci Liberator.Entry Details: (L) Here/ Lies/ the Liberator of the Treasury.

Hic mihi dies sanctus.Entry Details: (L) This day a holy one for me.

Hic nefas commune sepulchrum.Entry Details: (L) Here is wickedness the common sepulchre.

Hideyashi Toyotomi.Entry Details: d. AD 1598, in Japanese his name means "the man found under a tree, " known to the Chinese as Ping Hsiu-ki. Born of poor parents he rose through his military exploits to be the greatest power in Japan. In 1586 he was named Kwambaku (commander-in-chief) of Japan and held power far greater than the emperor. He is noted for his toleration of Christianity, but in 1587 he expelled the Portuguese Jesuts from Japan, for he thought they might make his country a vassal of Portugal. In 1592 he declared war on Korea, hoping to destroy Korean control of the sea and to re-open trade with China, but was unable to subdue Korea completely.

Hien-Tsong.Entry Details: (Hsien Tsung) (reign 806-821). He started his reign by regulating the revenue of the Empire, stopping presents, forbidding slavery, and remitting taxes. In a series of wars (814-19) he re-established imperial control over the provincial governors. However, the emperor was controlled by the court eunuchs, who often opposed his reforms. Toward the end of his reign he became a Buddhist and died suddenly after taking some pills that were supposed to ensure his immortality.

Hien-tsong.Entry Details: (Hsien Tsung), imperial title of MANGU KHAN.

Hien Tsong.Entry Details: (Hsien Tsung) (reign. 1465-88), a weak emperor who was ruled by his concubine and by eunuchs; during his reign there were rebellions in the northern provinces. However, he did repair the GREAT WALL, improve the Grand Canal, and restore the reputation of YUKIEN with posthumous honors.

Hien-yang.Entry Details: (Hsien-yang), the capital city during the Former HAN dynasty and several other dynasties; today it is the city of Sian, capital of SHENSI province in NE central China.

High Libya.Entry Details: corresponds roughly to what is today Algeria.

High Wycombe.Entry Details: Chepping Wycombe, municipal borough of Buckinghamshire in SE central England.

Hildebrand.Entry Details: major in charge of Post utilities, DTC, Pisa.

Hillhouse.Entry Details: James A., 1754-1832, American lawyer, member of the House of Representatives (1791-1808).

Hinchcliffe.Entry Details: Captain Walter G. Hinchliffe, d. 1928, a one-eyed English pilot who was hired by Charles A. LEVINE to pilot the Columbia, bad weather defeated their attempt to fly the Atlantic. Hinchliffe acquired a small plane and made plans to fly the Atlantic himself. On the morning of 13 March 1928, he smuggled Elsie MACKAY aboard and the two started over the Atlantic. Crowds awaited them in New York, they never arrived.

Hindenburg.Entry Details: Paul von, 1847-1934, the German general and president of the German Republic (1925-34); his greatest military success was his victory over the Russians at Tannenberg (1914).

Hi-Tsong.Entry Details: (Hsi Tsung) (reign. 874-89). He left the government to eunuchs while he devoted himself to sport, music, and mathematics. During his reign, the greatest rebellions of the TANG dynasty occurred, they devastated much of China and led to the run of the dynasty.

Huuen-tsong.Entry Details: (Hsüan Tsung) (reign: 713-56). The reign of this emperor is one of the most celebrated in Chinese history, he paid great attention to governing his people and made sumptuary laws for the court to cut down state expenses. In 740 he ordered that CONFUCIUS be elevated to the rank of prince. But his reign ended in rebellion and palace politics, and Hiuen-tsong resigned in favor of his son, SOU-TSONG.

Hoadly.Entry Details: Benjamin, 1676-1761, Bishop of Bangor and Hereford, author of religious and political treatises, among them An Essay on the Origin of Civil Government.

Hoai (1).Entry Details: (Huai), the territory roughly identical with the old province of KIANG-NAN; the rich agricultural area watered by the HOAI-HO, S HONAN and NW Anhwei provinces of modern E China.

Hoai-ho.Entry Details: (Huai-ho), river in S HONAN and NW Anhwei provinces in E China, flows into the HOANG-HO above Hungtze Hu.

Hoai-nan.Entry Details: (Huai-nan), a former city on the south bank of the Huai River (HOAI-HO) in Anhwei province.

Hoai-ngan.Entry Details: Hoai-nghen (Huai En) fl. AD 1487, a palace eunuch who became president of the tribunal of mandarins and then minister of state under Emperor HIAO-TSONG.

Hoai Tsong.Entry Details: (Huai Tsung) (reign: 1628-1644), last true emperor of the MING dynasty. He made an attempt to rule well, but heavy taxes and poor harvests drove the northwest into revolt. The emperor managed to keep peace with the Manchus, but the revolutionaries, led by Li Tzu-ch'êng, captured the province of HONAN and by 1642 advanced into SHENSI. In 1644 Peiping fell, and the emperor killed himself.

Hoang-ho.Entry Details: (Hwang Ho), the second largest river of China, known as the Yellow River.

Hoang Tchang.Entry Details: Hoang-tching (Huang-chêng), a region within the walls of the imperial palace at Peiping, in 1693 the first permanent church and residence of the Jesuits in China was established there at the expense of Emperor KANG-HI.

Hoang Ti.Entry Details: (Huang Ti) (reign. 2698-2598), the Yellow Emperor, from whom all later kings and princes of China claimed to be descended; he was a practical and beneficent ruler.

Hobhouse.Entry Details: John Cam, Baron Broughton de Gyfford, 1786-1869, British administrator and liberal pamphleteer.

Hoché-té-kelei.Entry Details: (Hoshih Te-kelei) fl. AD 1643, a Mongol prince who allied himself to the Manchu leader TAI-TSONG during one of the latter's many raids on SHANSI province.

Ho Ci'u.Entry Details: poss. Hoku (Ho-ch'u), a town in NW SHANSI province near the GREAT WALL.

Hoei-tsong.Entry Details: (Hui Tsung) (reign: 1101-26). He was a clever artist and collector of antiques -- but not much of an emperor. He was dominated by his minister, TSAI-KING, who led him into Taoism. Unable to resist the KIN Tartars, the emperor abdicated and surrendered himself to the invaders, they gave him the title of "Besotted Duke."

ho fo.Entry Details: (Ch) (huo-fo): living BUDDHA. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, XI, 112 note).

Ho-kien.Entry Details: (Ho-chien) prob. a district city in the province of Hopeh

Holland Park.Entry Details: on Kensington Road, London, site of Holland House.

Hollis, Thomas.Entry Details: 1720-74, English student of political philosophy and an ardent supporter of republican principles. In 1765 he had John ADAMS' Dissertation on the Canon and Feudal Law published in England, Hollis attributed Adams' work to Jeremiah GRIDLEY, however.

Hollis, Thomas Brand-.Entry Details: C. 1790, English friend of John ADAMS and a sympathizer with republican forms of government. He inherited the property of Thomas HOLLIS and took the name of his benefactor.

Hollis Brook.Entry Details: the proposed name for a brook on John ADAMS' property at BRAINTREE, it was to be a compliment to Thomas Brand-HOLLIS.

Holt, Charles.Entry Details: fl. 1800, editor of the Bee, a Republican newspaper in Connecticut, who was imprisoned under the Sedition Act (1798) for his attacks on the administration of John ADAMS.

Honan.Entry Details: a province in E central China.

hong-mao.Entry Details: (Ch) (hung-mao): Red-heads, the name used by the Chinese to designate the English and Dutch.

Hong Vou.Entry Details: (Hung Wu) (reign: 1368-99), founder of the MING dynasty. He started his career as a rebel against the Emperor CHUNTI, in 1368 he overthrew the YUAN dynasty and took the throne, changing his name from TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG to Hong-vou. Once emperor, he showed himself an able administrator, he reformed the law code and the system of taxation, re-established government coinage on a sound basis, prohibited eunuchs from holding office, and patronized literature and education.

Hooper.Entry Details: William, 1742-90, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-77), signer of the DECLARATION of Independence.

Horner, Leonard.Entry Details: 1785-1864, English geologist and educational reformer, appointed in 1833 to a commission on child employment and until 1856 was a chief inspector under the FACTORY ACT.

Ho-tcheou.Entry Details: (Ho-ch'ou), city on the Kialing river, 60 miles N of Chunking.

Hotel Valentinois.Entry Details: on the Rue Raynouard, Benjamin FRANKLIN and John ADAMS stopped there while in Paris; later known as the BASSE COUR; it no longer exists.

hotien.Entry Details: Khotan, town in NW China, important as a caravan junction.

Hou-chi.Entry Details: (Hu Shih) d. AD 552, empress of the state of OUEI who built many Buddhist temples and often waged war against the Empire.

Hou-han-yé.Entry Details: (Hu Han-yeh) fl. BC 55, a tartar chief of great importance who became a vassal of Emperor HAN-SIUEN-TI in BC 55.

Hound of Heaven, The.Entry Details: poem by Francis Thompson (1859-1907), appeared in the volume Poems (1893).

House of Commons.Entry Details: the lower house of the English PARLIAMENT.

House of Lords.Entry Details: the upper house of the English PARLIAMENT.

House of Representatives.Entry Details: the lower house of the CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES.

Howard.Entry Details: Catherine, ?1521-1542, Queen of England, fifth wife of HENRY VIII; she was accused of immoral conduct before her marriage and was beheaded. Or poss. reference to the entire Howard family.

Howe.Entry Details: Richard, Earl Howe, 1726-99, English naval officer engaged in the American Revolution (1776-78).

Hoy mismo han llegado, los Americanos to.Entry Details: (Sp) Today have arrived at this square the knight/ John ADAMS member/ etc/ the Englishmen evacuating RHODE ISLAND/ the Americans took over. (See. John Adams, Works, III, 247).

Hudibras tavern.Entry Details: inn near Nassau Hall College, Princeton, New Jersey; John ADAMS stopped there in 1774.

Hudson.Entry Details: river in E New York State.

Hulme.Entry Details: Thomas Ernest, 1883-1917, the English philosopher and poet, killed in World War I.

humanitas.Entry Details: (L) humanity, the sum of humane qualities, virtu.

Hume.Entry Details: David, 1711-1776, the Scottish philosopher and historian.

Humphries.Entry Details: David, 1753-1818, colonel in the American Army during the Revolution, aide-de-camp to George WASHINGTON, minister to Spain (1794), recognized as an expert on raising merino sheep.

Hunt, Violet.Entry Details: 1866-1942, English writer; companion of Ford Madox FORD.

Huntington.Entry Details: Samuel, 1731-96, president of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1779-81), signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, member of the Continental Congress (1776-83).

Hutchinson.Entry Details: Thomas, 1711-80, American colonial administrator, member of the Massachusetts governor's council (1749-66); accepted the legality of the STAMP ACT (1765); Royal Governor of Massachusetts (1771-74). Hutchinson was a firm believer in British authority, and his policies in Massachusetts did much to hasten the American Revolution.

Hyades.Entry Details: a cluster of stars in the constellation Taurus, their rising with the sun was supposed to indicate rainy weather.

Hyder Ali.Entry Details: or Haider Ali, d. 1782, Indian maharaja of the Hindu state of Mysore.

Hydra.Entry Details: a southern constellation having the form of a serpent.

Hyperion.Entry Details: a Titan, father of the Sun, Moon, and Dawn; also a reference to the sun itself.

[Iacchos].Entry Details: a mystic name of DIONYSUS. (See. Appendix A).

Iamblichus.Entry Details: C. AD 330, the Greek neo-Platonic philosopher.

\"I am the torch she saith\".Entry Details: from Arthur Symonds, Modern Beauty in Images of Good and Evil, 257.

Ibsen.Entry Details: Henrik, 1828-1906, the Norwegian poet and dramatist.

Ida.Entry Details: a hill in the Troad, scene of the marriage between ANCHISES and APHRODITE; also the scene of the Judgment of Paris.

igitur meis encomus.Entry Details: see DE LIBRO CHI-KING SIC CENSO

I had not loved you.Entry Details: from Lovelace, To Althea from Prison.

Il cardinale di San Pietro in Vincoli.Entry Details: (It) the Cardinal of SAN PIETRO IN VINCOLI. (i.e., Nicholas of Cusa, 1400-64, German churchman named cardinal in 1448 by Pope Eugene IV).

Il duol che sopra Senna/ Induce, falsegg.Entry Details: (It) the grief that over the Seine river/ Induces, forging the money. (See. Paradiso, 19, 118-119).

Ile St Louis.Entry Details: Ile de Saint-Louis, one of the islands of Paris.

Il est bon comme le pain..Entry Details: (Fr) it is good as bread; proverbial. it is good as gold.

illa dolore obmutuit, pariter vocem.Entry Details: (L) she hushed with grief, and her voice likewise. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, XIII, 538-540).

Illmo ac exmo (eccellentissimo) princeps.Entry Details: (L) principi To the most illustrious and excellent prince and lord.

IIUS Balia eseguisca in tutto.Entry Details: (It) Illustrious BALÍA that acts in everything.

Illustrae Dominae Parisinae Marxesana..Entry Details: (L) Of the illustrious Lady Parisina, Marchioness. (See: Parisina MALATESTA).

Illustre signor mio, Messire Battista.Entry Details: (It) My dear sir, Master Battista. (See: Leon Battista ALBERTI).

Il me paraît un curé déguisé.Entry Details: (Fr) He appears to me a disguised priest.

Il più galantuomo del paese.Entry Details: (It) the best gentleman of the town.

Il Popolo.Entry Details: Popolo d'Italia, newspaper started by MUSSOLINI in 1914.

Il Scirocco è geloso..Entry Details: (It) and the south-west wind is jealous.

Ils n'existent pas, leur ambience leur c.Entry Details: (Fr) ambiance They don't exist, their surrounding confers/ an existence upon them.

ima vada noctis obscurae.Entry Details: (L) the lowest depths of dim night.

Immaculata, Introibo.Entry Details: (L) immaculate, I shall enter. (Introibo from the Preparation of the Roman Mass).

Imperial Seal.Entry Details: the seal of the Emperor of China during the Former HAN dynasty.

im Westen nichts neues.Entry Details: (Ger) im Westen nichts Neues: nothing new in the West. (Novel by Erich Maria Remarque, the English translation is All Quiet on the Western Front, 1929).

Ina.Entry Details: King of the West Saxons (689-728); organized a code of laws.

In campo Illus. Domini Venetorum die 7/.Entry Details: (L) In the field of the Illustrious Lord of the Venetians, 7 April 1449, opposite CREMONA.

in capite.Entry Details: (Law) referring to the holding of land under direct grant of the lord or king; lit.. in chief. (See: John Adams, Works, II, 372).

in coitu inluminatio.Entry Details: (L) coition maketh the light to shine.

Incostante.Entry Details: The Inconstant, the ship on which NAPOLEON left Elba in 1815.

In den Deutschen Befreudenskriegen.Entry Details: (Ger) Befreiungskriegen: In the German Wars of Liberation. (See. Wilhelm BAUR).

Infante.Entry Details: prob. the son of Alfonso XIII, last king of Spain.

inficit umbras.Entry Details: (L) tinges with a darker shade. (See Ovid, Metamorphoses, X, 596).

in harum ac ego ivi.Entry Details: haram into a pig- sty I too have gone.

In libro pactorum.Entry Details: (L) In the book of the agreements.

Innes.Entry Details: George Inness, 1825-94, American landscape painter, member of the Hudson River School, or his son George, 1854-1926, also a painter.

Innsbruck.Entry Details: capital of the Tyrol, W Austria.

In officina Wecheh.Entry Details: (L) At the workshop of WECHEL. (See. Homeri Odyssea, adverbum translata, Andrea Divo Iustinopolitano (Andreas DIVUS) interprete, Paris, 1538, title page).

Inopos.Entry Details: Inopus, a river of Delos, it is said to rise and fall at the same time as the Nile, and the two rivers were supposed to be connected in some way.

in principio verbum/ verbum perfectum: s.Entry Details: (L) In the beginning was the Word/ the perfect Word: sincerity. (See: John 1, 1).

in quella parte/ dove sta memora.Entry Details: (It) memoria, in that part/ where the memory is. (See Cavalcanti, Donna mi prega).

Inquisition.Entry Details: the systematic punishment of religious heretics during the period between the 13th and 18th centuries; especially the Spanish Inquisition.

Institutes.Entry Details: comprehensive summaries of legal principles and decisions; here prob. a particular reference to COKE's Institutes of the Laws of England.

Institutes Digest Roman.Entry Details: the institutes, digests, and codes of the Roman law.

Interea pro gradibus Basilicae S. Pietri.Entry Details: (L) Meanwhile in front of the steps of the Basilica of ST. PETER, from dry stuff/ a huge pyre was built and on top of it was placed an effigy of Sigis/mondo, imitating so exactly the man's features and style of dress/ that it seemed rather to be the real person/ than his effigy; but so that the effigy could not fool anyone, / some writing came from his mouth which said:/ Here am I, Sigismondo/ MALATESTA, son of PANDOLFO, king of traitors, naked before God and men, by decree of the Sacred Senate/ condemned to the flames;/ would write. Many read (the words). Then as the people stood by, a fire was lit beneath it, / and the pyre of a sudden set the the likeness on fire. Commentaries of Pius II, Book VII.

in terrorem.Entry Details: (L) in terror; for the purpose of terror (?).

Intorcetta.Entry Details: fl. 1691, an Italian Jesuit missionary in China.

Invention-d'entités-plus-ou-moins-abstra.Entry Details: (Fr) Invention of more or less abstract entities/ in number equal to the things to be explained / Science can not be composed of it. "I/ got a burn" / "from which it took me six months to recover.

Ionides.Entry Details: prob. Luke Ionides. (See: Guide to Kulchur, 227).

Io venni in luogo d'ogni luce muto.Entry Details: (It) I came to a lightless place. (See Inferno, 5, 28).

Iphigénie.Entry Details: Iphigénie en Tauride, an opera by Christoph Willibald GLUCK (1779).

Ipswich, Agot.Entry Details: poss. Margot ASQUITH, (however, the 1954 Faber edition of the Cantos substitutes the name Minny Humbolt for Agot Ipswich).

Ipswich Instructions.Entry Details: the instructions given by the people of Ipswich, Massachusetts to Dr. John Calef, their representative to the STAMP ACT Congress (1765).

Iriquois, Frank Robert.Entry Details: prob. an American expelled from France C. 24 July 1928.

[Irish Parliament].Entry Details: the quasi-legislative body of Ireland; the Irish Parliament had been curbed by POYNINGS's Law in 1495 and made dependent upon the English Parliament for legislative initiative; the law was not rescinded until 1782.

Irritat mulcet et falsis terroribus impl.Entry Details: (L) annoys, soothes, and fills with false fears. (See: Horace: Epistles II, 1, 212).

Isé.Entry Details: the two sacred Shinto shrines to the Sun Goddess; located at Ujiyamada, S Honshu, Japan.

Ismarus of the Cicones.Entry Details: Ismarus, a city of the Cicones, attacked by ODYSSEUS shortly after his leaving Troy. After an initial defeat, the Ciconians rallied and drove the Greeks back to their ships. (See Odyssey IX, 39ff).

[Isolde].Entry Details: theheroine of the legend of Tristam and Isolde.

Issy.Entry Details: Issy-les-Moulineaux, SW suburb of Paris, on the Seine.

Istria.Entry Details: the Istria Peninsula on the NE coast of the Adriatic Sea.

I-Tching-tcheou.Entry Details: Tching-tcheou (Ching-ch'ou), a village in the district of CAI-FONG-FOU.

Ithaca.Entry Details:
the island-kingdom of ODYSSEUS in the Ionian Sea.
"I think you must be Odysseus
Always with your mind on the past.
39/44-45: from Odyssey, X, 456-64.

[Ito, Miscio].Entry Details: a Japanese dancer known to Pound. (See Guide to Kulchur, 217).

Ito Yen.Entry Details: poss. Ho-yan, a town in what is now Anhwei province. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IX, 615).

[Itys].Entry Details: son of Procne, who was married to Tereus, king of Thrace. Tereus seduced Philomela and cut out her tongue, to revenge her sister, Procne killed Itys and served his flesh to her husband.

in harum ego ac vidi cadaveres animae.Entry Details: (L) haram I went into the pig-sty and saw soul-corpses.

Ixion.Entry Details: a Thessalian who courted Hera illicitly, as punishment for his crimes, Ixion was bound to an ever-turning wheel in the underworld.

I Yin.Entry Details: 18th century BC, a minister of TCHING TANG, first emperor of the CHANG dynasty. I Yin was instrumental in putting an end to the HIA dynasty.

Jackson.Entry Details: Andrew, 1767-1845, seventh President of the U.S., member of the House of Representatives (1796-97) and of the U.S. Senate (1797-98, 1823-25); successfully defended New Orleans against the British (1814), President (1828-36).

Jackson, Colonel.Entry Details: prob. acquaintance of Pound. (See: Guide to Kulchur, 227).

Jackson, Jim..Entry Details: James Jackson, 1757-1806, American statesman, member of the House of Representatives (1789-91), governor of Georgia (1798-1801), he was an opponent of HAMILTON's financial measures.

Jacob, rue..Entry Details: street on the Left Bank, Paris.

Jaffa.Entry Details: a subdistrict of S Palestine; ancient Joppa was a seaport of Palestine.

Jah, (the Bard's pedestal) 1st am Lester.Entry Details: (Ger) Yes, (the BARD's pedestal) is in LEICESTER SQUARE.

J'ai eu pitié des autres/ probablement p.Entry Details: (Fr) I had pity for the others/ probably not enough.

J'ai honte d'ètre Hollandais.Entry Details: (Fr) I am ashamed of being Dutch.

James.Entry Details: prob. a negro servant of Pound's AUNT FRANK.

James I.Entry Details: 1566-1625, King of Great Britain and Scotland (1603-25).

James II.Entry Details: 1633-1701, King of Great Britain and Scotland (1685-88).

[Jan Ch'iu].Entry Details: a disciple of CONFUCIUS. (See- Analects, XI, 25).

Janequin.Entry Details: Clement Jannequin or Janequin 16th-century French composer of both secular and church music.

Janus.Entry Details: the god of beginnings, the guardian of the gate or the gate itself, usually represented as bifrons, with two faces, looking both before and behind. The closing of the Janus geminus, in the Roman Forum, signified peace.

Jason.Entry Details: poss. Jason, Tyrant of Pherae, C. 380-70; a man of great ability who started to unite northern Greece into a strong Thessalian hegemony but was assassinated before he could carry out his plans.

Jassy.Entry Details: a commercial town in NE Rumania.

Jay.Entry Details: John, 1745-1829, American jurist and statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-77, 78, 79), aided in peace negotiations with Great Britain (1782-3), Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court (1789-95), negotiated Jay's Treaty with Great Britain (1794-5).

Jefferson.Entry Details: Thomas, 1743-1826, third President of the U.S., member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1775, 76; 1783-85), chairman of the committee to draft the DECLARATION of Independence (1776), U.S. minister to France (1785-98), Secretary of State (1790-93); Vice-President (1797-1801), President (1801-09).

Jenkyns.Entry Details: John Jenkins, 1592-1678, English composer and musician to CHARLES I and CHARLES II, composed many Fancies for viol and organ.

Jerome, Jennie].Entry Details: mother of Winston CHURCHILL, married Randolph Henry Spencer Churchill in 1874.

Jerusalem (2).Entry Details: a painting of Jerusalem by Vittore CARPACCIO; poss. his St. Stephen Preaching at Jerusalem, in the Louvre.

Jesu Christo! / Standu nel paradiso terr.Entry Details: (It) Jesus Christ/ being in the terrestrial paradise/ thinking how to make Adam's mate!

Je suis au bout de mes forces.Entry Details: (Fr) I am at the end of my tether.

Je suis / plus fort que. / ...le Boud-ha.Entry Details: (Fr) I am/ stronger than/ BUDDHA/ am/ stronger than/ CHRIST/ I would have/ abolished weight!

Jesuit church.Entry Details: a church and residence in Peiping. (See: HOANG-TCHANG).

Jesuits (1).Entry Details: the Society of Jesus, founded by St. Ignatius Loyola in 1534.

Jesuits (2).Entry Details: (see entry above), the Jesuit missionaries in China who established the modern Roman Catholic missions there. First to arrive was Matteo RICCI (1582), followed by Johann Adam Schall von Bell (1619). The period of greatest missionary effort began in 1688 when GERBILLON and VERBIEST gained the favour of Emperor KANG-HI.

[Jimmu Tenno].Entry Details: 711-585, first of the legendary emperors of Japan (660-585). Jimmu is regarded as a direct descendent of the Sun Goddess and as the founder of the Japanese imperial dynasty, which has remained unbroken since his accession to the throne. The Japanese Era is dated from the beginning of his reign 11 February 660 BC.

Jockey Club.Entry Details: the leading social club of Paris.

John..Entry Details: John Lackland, 21167-1216, King of England (1199-1216), forced by the English barons to sign the Magna Charta (1215) at Runnymede.

John Baptiste Lazarus.Entry Details: see John Baptiste Lazarus de Theveneau de FRANCY.

[ John de Neufville & Sons].Entry Details: a Dutch banking house through which John ADAMS tried (c. 1780) to arrange an American loan.

[John of Austria].Entry Details: 1629-79, Spanish general and statesman, natural son of Philip IV.

Johnson (1).Entry Details: William, 1771-1834, appointed associate justice of the U.S. Supreme Court (1804) by Thomas JEFFERSON.

Johnson (2).Entry Details: Colonel Richard Mentor, 1780-1850, member of the House of Representatives (1807-19; 1829-37) and the U.S. Senate (1819-29), Vice-President (1837-41).

Johnson (3).Entry Details: Joshua, American merchant who settled in England before the Revolution; first U S consul at London (1785-97), father of Louisa Catherine, who married John Quincy ADAMS (1797).

Johnson, Sam..Entry Details: William Samuel, 1727-1819, American jurist and educator; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1784-87) and the U.S. Senate (1789-91); president of Columbia College (1787-1800).

Johnson, Sam.Entry Details: Samuel, 1709-84, the English lexicographer, critic, and poet; edited Shakespeare (8 vols., 1765).

joli quart d'heure, (nella Malatestiana).Entry Details: (Fr) pleasant quarter-hour (It) (in the TEMPIO of the MALATESTA)

Jones (2).Entry Details: lieutenant and Provost Officer, DTC, Pisa.

Jones, Paul.Entry Details: John Paul Jones, 1747-92, naval officer serving America during the Revolution.

[Jones, Sir Thomas].Entry Details: d. 1692, English jurist, chief justice of the Common Pleas, he was dismissed in 1686 by JAMES II for refusing to rule in favour of the dispensing power of the Crown in the HALES case.

jongleur.Entry Details: (Fr) one who sings the songs composed by a troubadour.

Joritomo.Entry Details: or Yoritomo, 1146-99, the first true Shogun in Japanese history; he assumed sovereign power in 1185. A great and constructive statesman, he inaugurated a system of military government which ran the affairs of Japan in disregard of the emperor.

[Joseph II].Entry Details: 1741-90, King of Germany (1764-90) and Holy Roman Emperor (1765-90).

Journal des Débats.Entry Details: French newspaper, controlled by the COMITE DES FORGES.

Jozefff.Entry Details: poss. a waiter in the WIENER CAFE.

Juana, Dona, la loca.Entry Details: 1479-1555, daughter of Ferdinand of Aragon and Isabella of Castile; mother of Emperor Charles V; driven mad by the death of her husband, Philip (1506).

Judas's tree;.Entry Details: according to tradition, the tree on which Judas hanged himself.

Julia the Countess.Entry Details: prob. a member of the Tassoni family of Ferrara, which owned the SCHIFANOJA: one time. Text reference is to the fact that the Schifanoia once was used as a tobacco factory; the Italian verb, conciare, means to tan hides, or to cure tobacco, hence the confusion of tannery in the text.

Juliet.Entry Details: the character in Shakespeare's play, Romeo and Juliet.

jura ordo aequitas leges.Entry Details: (L) rights order equity laws. (See: Livy, Annals, III, 63).

jure regalia.Entry Details: (L) jura. royal rights. (See: John Adams, Works, IV, 107).

Justinian.Entry Details: Justinian I, 483-565, Byzantine Emperor (527-65), his greatest accomplishment was the codification of Roman law, done under his direction by Tribonan, called the Corpus Juris Civilis.

Juxta fluvium Hual acies ordinatur nec m.Entry Details: (L) By the river HOAI the battle line is drawn up without delay. (See: A. Lacharme, Confucil Chi-King, III, 3, 9, stanza 4; Classic Anthology, 263).

Kabir.Entry Details: ?1450-1518, Hindu mystic poet in the time of the Lodi kings.

Kagekiyo.Entry Details: character in the Noh play, Kagekiyo, by Motokiyo. (See. Translations, 315-322).

Kai Moiral' Adomin.Entry Details: (Gr) And the FATES (cry over) ADONIS. (See: Appendix A).

kaka pharmak edöken.Entry Details: (Gr) she (CIRCE) had given them dreadful drugs. (See: Appendix A).

Kalb, Johann.Entry Details: 1721-80, known as Baron de Kalb, a German army officer commissioned major general in the Continental Army (1777-80), killed at the battle of Camden.

Kaldan.Entry Details: (Galdan) d. AD 1697. Chief of the ELEUTES, a nomadic tribe to the north-west of China. In 1680 Kaldan became khan of his people and invaded the territory of the KALKAS, however, Emperor KANG-HI declared himself on the side of the Kalkas. Daring the emperor's power, Kaldan invaded the Chinese frontier in 1691, he was beaten but not crushed. When he invaded China again (1695) his forces were destroyed by the imperial troops, who used cannon. Kaldan poisoned himself.

Kaldans.Entry Details: the people ruled by KALDAN; the ELEUTES.

Kalkas.Entry Details: (Khalkans) a nomadic tribe to the north and north-west of China; the Kalkas were Mongols and traced themselves back to GENGHIS KHAN.

Kang Hi.Entry Details: (K'ang Hsi) (reign: 1662-1722), second emperor of the Manchu dynasty to rule over China. In 1675 the Manchu dynasty was threatened by the revolt of the Three Feudatories (one of them OU-SAN-KOUEI); but by 1681 Kang-hi had re-established a firm rule over all China and, two years later, over Formosa. He extended the Empire to the borders of Kokand and Badakhshan and into Tibet. He was a patron of the Jesuits, whom he employed (especially VERBIEST) to survey the Empire, study astronomy, and cast cannon, but later, fearing their propaganda and the possible influence of the Pope on the government of China, he restricted their activities. A great patron of literature and scholarship, the emperor directed the writing of the Imperial Dictionary and the great Concordance of all literature. Kang-hi was an emperor in the tradition of YAO, CHUN and YU.

Kang Ouang.Entry Details: (K'ang Wang) (reign. 1078-52), a weak emperor, but one who was supported by strong ministers.

Kanouen.Entry Details: Kanouensing (Kan Wen-hsing) d. AD 1297, the commander of the city of TCHANG-TCHEOU; he was attacked and killed by TCHIN TIAQUEN. His wife, OUANG-CHI, preferred to die on his funeral pyre than to marry his murderer.

Kao-hoang-ti.Entry Details: (Kao Huang Ti) (reign: 202-195), founder and first emperor of the HAN dynasty; known formerly as LIEOU-PANG. On the whole he was an able emperor and one provided with many wise ministers -- to whom he listened most of the time, he established a firm foundation for the Han dynasty.

Kao-Ti.Entry Details: (Kao Ti) (reign: 480-83), first emperor of the Ch'1 dynasty (480-503); he is said to have seemed deficient in some of the more heroic qualities, an unimportant ruler.

Kao-tsou (2).Entry Details: (Kao Tsu) (reign: 618-26), first emperor of the TANG dynasty; he established schools and stabilized the monetary units. Although the Tartars invaded the Empire, Kao-tsou's son, Shih Min, drove them out of the Empire; Shih Min did much to establish the Tang dynasty and became its second emperor, ruling under the name TAI-TSONG.

Kao-tsou-ou-ti.Entry Details: (Kao Tsu Wu Ti) (reign: 420-23), formerly LIEOU-YU, known generally as Wu Ti, the founder of the Liu SUNG dynasty; he proved to be a good emperor, but did not live long enough to be effective.

Kao-Yao.Entry Details: (Kao Yao) d. BC 2204, a famous minister under Emperor CHUN; said to have been the first to introduce laws for the repression of crime.

Karikon.Entry Details: Caricus Murus, a town on the coast of North Africa founded by HANNO, just south of the promontory of SOLOIS.

Karxèdonion Basileos.Entry Details: (Gr) The King of the CARTHAGINIANS. (See. Appendix A).

Kasgar.Entry Details: Kashgar, city in W Sinkiang province W China, became a part of China in 1759, the chief city of Chinese Turkistan.

Kashmir.Entry Details: Indian state in N India on the Sinkiang and Tibet frontier.

Katin.Entry Details: Katyn, village west of Smolensk, occupied by the Germans during W.W.II. In 1943 the Germans said that the mass grave of some 10,000 Polish officers had been discovered near Katyn and claimed the Russians had massacred them, the Russians denied the charge but refused to allow an investigation. Later the Russians accused the Germans of the massacre.

KEI MEN RAN KEI/KIU MAN MAN KEI/ JITSU G.Entry Details: (Ch in Jap transliteration) How bright and colorful the auspicious clouds,/ Hanging gracefully;/ Let sun and moon be thus resplendent/ Morn after morn. (See. Fu Sheng, Shang-shu ta chuan).

Keith, Sir William.Entry Details: 1680-1749, British colonial governor of Pennsylvania and Delaware (1714-26).

Kensington.Entry Details: the Royal Borough of Kensington, London.

Kent.Entry Details: James, 1763-1847, American jurist, chief justice of the New York State Supreme Court (1804-14), judge of the New York State Court of Chancery (1814-23). His decisions as judge of the Chancery Court were instrumental in reviving equity, which had largely lapsed in America after the Revolution.

Kettlewell.Entry Details: prob. John Kettelwell, a student at St. John's College, Oxford, C. 1910.

Khitan (Khitans).Entry Details: (Kitan), a Mongol tribe to the north of China, near Korea. By AD 907 the Khitans had become very strong under the chieftain YÉ-LIU-APAOKI, who proclaimed himself emperor of an independent kingdom with the dynastic title of Liao ("iron"). The Khitans encroached on the Empire until China was divided at the Yellow River; KAI FONG became the capital of the Empire, and PEIPING became for the first time a metropolis and the Khitan capital.

Kiang.Entry Details: the YANGTZE river. Present day maps make no distinction between the Kiang (or Blue River) and the Yangtze; formerly, the upper reaches of the river, as far as the lake of Tungting Hu (in Hunan province) were known as the Kiang, and the river from the lake to its mouth on the East China Sea was called the Yangtze.

Ki, Uncle.Entry Details: (Ki Tzu) fl. BC 1153, the uncle of Emperor CHEOU-SIN and his first minister; a man of true merit.

Kiang-nan.Entry Details: (Chiang-nan), an old province of China, roughly the area of the present provinces of Anhwei and Kiangsu.

Kiang-ping.Entry Details: (Chiang Ping) d. AD 1521, a military adventurer who became the favorite of Emperor OU-TSONG. He corrupted the emperor by providing him with pleasures and, in 1520, attempted to murder him. After Ou-tsong's death Kiang-ping was ambushed and killed by order of Emperor CHI-TSONG; his entire family was also killed and his property confiscated.

Kian King.Entry Details: prob. error for NANKING (See. Mailla, Histoire Générale, X, 4).

Kiao-Chan.Entry Details: (Chiao-shan), a mountain in the district of Chung-pu, in the province of SHENSI.

Kiao-hoang.Entry Details: (Ch) Kiao-hoa-hoang (Chiao-hwa-huang): the sovereign pontiff of the prosperous religion; (the Pope of the Roman Catholic Church).

Kiassé.Entry Details: Kia-ssé-tao (Kai Ssu-tao) fl. AD 1273, a minister and military officer under Emperor LI-TSONG. He made a secret treaty with KUBLAI KHAN in 1259, representing the emperor as willing to pay a tribute to the Mongols to insure peace. Kublai accepted the treaty and turned his troops north, but Kia-ssé-tao attacked the rear of the Mongol troops. For this treachery, Kublai vowed to ruin the SUNG dynasty. Kia-ssé-tao was minister to two other emperors: Tu Tsung (reign: 1265-67) and K'ung Ti (reign. 1275-76). His attempts to deal with the Mongols, either by diplomacy or armed force, never seemed to do the Sung much good. He died disgraced.

Kia-Y.Entry Details: (Kia I) fl. BC 178, member of the court of HIAO-OUEN-TI and head of the office of tax collection.

Ki-chan.Entry Details: (Ki-shan), a mountain in China which was destroyed by the earthquakes that appeared as evil omens during the reign of YEOU-OUANG, the mountain was said to be the cradle of Yeou's family.

Kiei-kou.Entry Details: (Chieh-ku), a barbarian tribe, obviously European, to the west of China, these people had red hair and blue eyes, they were tall and had a martial air. "The such like had never been seen in China before."

Kien Long.Entry Details: (Ch'ien Lung) (reign: 1736-1795), fourth son of Emperor YONG-TCHING. He was an excellent administrator and is often compared to his grandfather, KANG-HI. After ten years of reorganizing the government, Kien-long put down a revolt of the aborigines in W China, forced Burma and Nepal to pay tribute, established Chinese supremacy over Tibet, and maintained friendly relations with western nations. The emperor was an indefatigable poet and published a total of 33,950 pieces, his work is very correct, but rather mediocre. Under his patronage, historical works, encyclopedias, and library catalogues were printed.

Kien-ouen-ti.Entry Details: (Ch'ien Wen Ti) (reign: 550-52), a puppet emperor set on the throne by ambitious nobles who needed a prince of the royal blood to head the Empire; but Kien-ouen-ti's usefulness was soon over and he was murdered.

[Kien-ouen-ti].Entry Details: (Ch'ien Wen Ti) (reign 1399-1403), second emperor of the MING dynasty and grandson of HONG-VOU. He was a weak emperor and unable to deal with the rebellions of his uncle the Prince of Yen, fourth son of Hong-vou. In 1403 the Prince of Yen took Nanking, the capital. Kien-ouen-ti was about to kill himself, when he was told of a chest which Hong-vou left to be opened in such an emergency, in the chest were the dress of a Buddhist priest, a diploma, a razor, and money. Kien-ouen-ti, dressed as a Buddhist monk, escaped to a monastery in SZECHWAN, where he lived for 35 years until he was discovered during the reign of YNG-TSONG. The Prince of Yen took the throne, ruling under the name YONG-LO.

[Kien-tchéou].Entry Details: (Ch'ien-ch'ou), a large town in SZECHWAN province.

Kieou.Entry Details: Kieou-heou (Chiu Hou) C. BC 1147, a noble serving Emperor CHEOU-SIN. His daughter disapproved of the evil emperor and his concubine, TAN-KI, so they had her killed, quartered, and served up to her father for dinner.

Ki-kié.Entry Details: (Chi Chieh) fl. BC 279, commander of the forces of the Prince of Yen.

Kimball, Dexter.Entry Details: 1865-1955? economist and writer; author of Industrial Economics (1929).

Kimmerian lands.Entry Details: land of the mythical Cimmerians; it lies at the entrance of hell and is always shrouded in darkness of mist and cloud. (See: Odyssey, XI, 14-19).

Kin.Entry Details: (Chin), a Tartar tribe formerly known as the NUTCHE. In 1114 AKOUTA, chieftain of the Nutché, proclaimed himself an emperor and gave the name of Kin ("gold") to his dynasty. The Kin dynasty lasted 1115-1234.

king, the.Entry Details: see SHIH CHING and SHU CHING.

King of Ragona.Entry Details: see ALFONSO V, King of Aragon.

\"King Otreus, of Phrygia, / That king i.Entry Details: from Homeric Hymn V, To Aphrodite, 111-112.

King.Entry Details: Rufus, 1755-1827, American statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1784-87) and of the U.S. Senate (1789-96), minister to Great Britain (1796-1804), again U.S. Senator (1813-25). He was a strong supporter of HAMILTON.

King-Ho.Entry Details: (King or Ching), river of China, rises in NE Kansu province, N central China, and flows to the Wei river in central SHENSI.

King Kong (1).Entry Details: (Ching Kung) d. BC 578, the Prince of Tin (Ch'in) and a powerful warrior.

Kingtcheou.Entry Details: (Ching-ch'ou), the capital city and seventh department of SHENSI province.

King Ti.Entry Details: (Ching Ti) (reign 1450-57), came to the throne after his brother, YNG-TSONG was captured by the Mongol invaders; King-ti regarded his position as a permanent one and did not wish to give it up when his brother was released by general YU-KIEN. But before he could establish the succession upon his son, King-ti died and Yng-tsong returned to the throne.

King Wang.Entry Details: (Ching Wang) (reign: 519-475), emperor during the major portion of the life of CONFUCIUS, he was known as the "Reverential."

Kin Lusiang.Entry Details: (Chin Li-hsiang) 1232-1303, a scholar at the court of the SUNG, after the fall of the Southern Sung dynasty in 1280, he retired to Mt. Jen where he collected many disciples. He wrote a history of early China and many commentaries on the Classics.

Kio-feou-hien.Entry Details: (Chüo-fou-hsien), near the city of Yen-chou-fu in SHANTUNG province.

[Kiong-tcheou].Entry Details: (Chuung-ch'ou), a large town in SZECHWAN province.

Kitson.Entry Details: Arthur, 1860-1937, British writer, interested in Social Credit.

Klages.Entry Details: Charles, 19th century French composer and guitarist.

Knower.Entry Details: Benjamin, fl. 1827, friend of Martin VAN BUREN, active in New York State politics.

Knox..Entry Details: Philander Chase, 1853-1921, American political leader, member of the U. S. Senate (1904-09, 1917-21), one of the opposition to the entry of the U. S. into the League of Nations.

Koba, Kumrad.Entry Details: see Joseph STALIN. (Koba is what Stalin was called as a boy in Georgia, it means "the Bear", Kumrad is borrowed from E. E. Cummings' poem No Thanks).

Koen.Entry Details: (Kun) fl. BC 2297, Earl of Ch'ung and father of the Great YU. He was minister of works under Emperor YAO and was appointed to drain the Empire after the great overflow of the HOANG-HO in 2295. He worked for nine years and accomplished little, so in 2286 his son was appointed to the task, after another nine years, Yu succeeded.

Kohinoor.Entry Details: Koh-i-noor, the famous Indian diamond, now among the British crown jewels.

Kokka.Entry Details: Urquell, "ex-diplomat, ex-imperial staff officer." (See Guide to Kulchur, 83).

Kolschitzky.Entry Details: Georges François Koltschitzky de Szombor, fl. 1683, an interpreter for a commercial company of the East who was employed to spy on the Turkish forces during the siege of Vienna (1683). As payment he was granted a patent to open the first coffee house in Vienna and was given a quantity of coffee found in the Turkish camp.

[Kong-ouang].Entry Details: (Kung Wang) (reign: 946-34), sixth emperor of the CHOU dynasty.

Kongpei.Entry Details: Kongpésoui (Kungpêsui) fl. AD 1354, an officer in the imperial troops under Emperor CHUNTI.

[Kong-ti].Entry Details: (Kung Ti) (reign. 618-19), last emperor of the Soul dynasty. Depressed by rebellion and the coming end of his dynasty, Kong-ti took to drink, he killed his ministers, for he feared rebellion, and was himself murdered.

Kong Yeou.Entry Details: Kong-yeou-té (Kung Yeou-te) fl. AD 1633, a rebel against the MING dynasty who joined forces with the Manchu leader TAI-TSONG.

Königsberg.Entry Details: town, NW Prussia; residence of Immanuel KANT.

Koré.Entry Details: (Gr) Daughter; a reference to PERSEPHONE. (See Appendix A).

Kosouth.Entry Details: Ferencz Lajos Akos Kossuth, 1841-1914, Hungarian statesman, leader of the Independence Party.

[Ko-tse-hing].Entry Details: (Kuo Tzu-hsing) d. AD 1355, one of the more successful rebels who arose during the reign of Emperor CHUNTI; he captured Anhwei province and proclaimed himself generalis-simo. His nephew, TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG, joined him for a time, but later left to form an independent rebellion of his own.

Kouang Ou.Entry Details: Kouang-ou-ti (Kuang Wu Ti) (reign: 25-58), first emperor of the After HAN dynasty. His reign was a series of wars, for there were rebellions within the Empire and Tartars attacking from without. Kouang-ou-ti was a successful warrior and also had sympathy for scholars and literary men.

Kouei.Entry Details: (Kuei or Kuei Wang) d. AD 1662. About 1646 he was proclaimed "last" emperor of the MING dynasty and set up a government in the southern provinces. However, the Manchus were determined to destroy all Ming power, and Kouei was soon in flight, pursued by the armies of OU-SAN-KOUEI. In 1662 Kouei retreated to Yunnan province and, sure of no mercy from the Manchus, strangled himself with a silk cord.

Kouémen..Entry Details: (Kue-men), a gate of the city of Nanking, or perhaps the underground passage through which Emperor KIEN-OUEN-TI escaped from Nanking in AD 1403.

Koulihan.Entry Details: Kou-li-kan (Ku-li-kan), a nation to the north-west of China and north of the Caspian Sea.

Kouo-tsé-y.Entry Details: (Kuo Tzu-i) 697-781, one of the most famous Chinese generals; he served four emperors: HIUEN-TSONG, SOU-TSONG, TAI-TSONG, and TÉ-TSONG. His campaigns against the Tartars were successful, and he proved an able governor of various cities and provinces, unlike most officials, his loyalty to the Empire was never questioned. His name is mentioned in the famous NESTORIAN tablet.

Kreffle, Mrs..Entry Details: a pseudonym for a Mrs. Kraft whom Pound knew in Madrid (1906).

Krupp.Entry Details: Alfred, 1812-87, German industrialist, head of the Krupp Works at Essen and began the manufacture of ordinance there; his type of breech-loading rifle was adopted by the Prussian army in 1861.

[Krupp von Bohlen und Halback, Gustav].Entry Details: 1870-1950, husband of Bertha Krupp, elder daughter of Friedrich Alfred Krupp. During World War I he was president of the Council of Trustees of Krupp's.

Kuan Chung.Entry Details: Kuan Tzu, 7th century BC, a statesman of the principality of CHI, although he increased the political prestige of his kingdom, CONFUCIUS considered that he did so without raising its moral status. (See: Analects III, XXII; XIV, xviii).

Kuanon.Entry Details: prob. (Ch) Kuan-yin, (Jap) Kwannon: Chinese goddess of mercy.

Kublai Khan.Entry Details: 1214-94. In 1260 he became emperor of the Mongols and in 1280 emperor of all China, giving the dynasty he founded the name YUEN. Kublai led few military expeditions after he became emperor of China, and his reign was generally one of peace. In 1285 paper money in the form of bank-notes was made current. Kublai was often under the influence of his ministers, particularly AHAMA and SANG-KO.

Kujak..Entry Details: (Kuyak Khan) (reign: 1242-48), a Mongol king, son of OGOTAI KHAN, who held a magnificent court in Tartary and led his forces as far as eastern Europe.

Kukano.Entry Details: Koukanor (Kuku-nor) prob. the area in W China known today as Ch'ing-hai province, or Kuku-nor province.

Kumasaka.Entry Details: the ghost in Ujinobu's Noh play, Kumasaka. (See. Translations, 249-255).

Kung-Sun Chow.Entry Details: (Kung-sun Ch'ow), Book II of the works of MENCIUS.

[Kung Yeh Ch'ang].Entry Details: a son-in-law of CONFUCIUS. (See Analects V, 1).

kylin.Entry Details: prob. variant of kaolin(e) [ Ch: kao-ling] an extremely pure white clay, used in the formation of porcelain paste.

la bonne soupe fait le bon soldat..Entry Details: (Fr) good soup makes a good soldier.

Lacedaemon..Entry Details: Sparta, the ancient city of the Peloponnesus, Greece.

lacking that treasure of honesty/ which.Entry Details: from The Great Digest, X, XXIII.

La Cour de Londres éludera autant et aus.Entry Details: (Fr) the Court of London will avoid as long as it can/ the admission direct/ or indirect of the independence of the United States.

ladies from West Virginia.Entry Details: Miss Ada and Miss Ida Mapel, American sisters from West Virginia, they were residents at the boarding house in Spain at which Pound stayed on his trip in 1906.

Ladro.Entry Details: (It) thief, rogue, prob. reference to a cat in the DTC, Pisa.

Lady de X.Entry Details: prob. Lady Augusta Gregory, 1852-1932, the Irish poet and playwright.

Lady Lucan.Entry Details: poss. Margaret Bingham, Countess of Lucan, d. 1814, most famous for her paintings, celebrated by Horace Walpole.

l'aer tremare.Entry Details: (It) the air trembles. (See: Sonnets and Ballate of Guido Cavalcanti, 28).

Lafayette.Entry Details: Marie Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette, 1757-1834, French statesman and officer, served as major general in the Continental army (1777), supported American interests in France. In his service in Virginia, Lafayette was associated with Daniel MORGAN of the Virginia riflemen.

Lafitte.Entry Details: Château Laffitte, a wine of Bordeaux.

Lalage.Entry Details: common name of courtesans, used as term of endearment. (See Horace; Odes, I, 22, 23).

lama.Entry Details: Tibetan priests; introduced into the palace of CHUNTI in 1353.

[Lamont, Thomas William].Entry Details: 1870-1948, American banker; member of the firm of J. P. Morgan and Co.

Lampascus.Entry Details: Lampsacus, ancient Greek colony in Mysia on the Hellespont.

Lancaster.Entry Details: the House of Lancaster, the English Royal House derived from John of Gaunt, who was created Duke of Lancaster in 1362, Lancastrian kings were Henry IV, HENRY V and HENRY VI.

Landon.Entry Details: Alfred Mossman, 1887- American business man and politician, governor of Kansas (1933-37), Republican nominee for President of the United States (1936).

Landor.Entry Details: Walter Savage, 1775-1864, the English poet and prose writer.

Lang-tchécu.Entry Details: (Lang-ch'ou), a city in Honan province, China.

[Lang-tchéou].Entry Details: (Lang-ch'ou), the modern city of Paoning, Szechwan province, China.

Languor has cried unto languor.Entry Details: poss. variation of Psalms 42, 7: Deep calleth unto deep.

Lanier.Entry Details: Sidney, 1842-1881, the American poet and musician, among his better poems is The Symphony, in which he discusses the relationship between trade and human values.

Laoist.Entry Details: a follower of LAO-TSE, founder of Taoism.

Laomedon.Entry Details: the legendary king of Troy for whom POSEIDON built the walls of Troy, the god was cheated of his pay and in revenge sent a sea monster to ravage the land.

\"Laomedon, Ahi, Laomedon\".Entry Details: from T. Sturge Moore, The Rout of the Amazons.

Lao Tse.Entry Details: (Lao-tzu), C. 604-531, one of China's most famous teachers, popularly regarded as the founder of the Taoist sect. His teachings centered on returning good for evil and looking forward to a higher form of life; in his interpretation of Tao, the "Way", he professed to have found the clue to all things human and divine. Central to his teaching is the Doctrine of Inaction, which states, "Do nothing, and all things will be done." Later, pure Taoism became mixed with magic, astrology, alchemy, and the search for an elixir of life.

la pastorella der suini.Entry Details: (It) the little shepherdess of the hogs.

la persecution contre M. Van Berckel/ et.Entry Details: (Fr) the persecution against M. VAN BERCKEL/ and his associates/ not to rush your departure/ business. crisis time could/ object of the English beyond that of amusing the Republic of Holland. (See: John Adams, Works, VII, 334-336).

la qual manda fuoco.Entry Details: (It) which sends fire. (See: Cavalcanti, Donna mi prega).

Larmann, Maxy.Entry Details: an invented name of no particular reference.

La Rochefoucauld, Duke de.Entry Details: La Rochefoucauld-Liancourt, Duc François Alexandre Fredéric de, 1747-1827, French politician and philanthropist; member of the States-General (1789).

La Rupe.Entry Details: La Rupe Tarpeia, a wineshop in Rome, originally near the supposed Tarpeian Rock, but now moved.

la scalza Io son' la luna.Entry Details: (It) the barefooted one: I am the moon.

La Serra.Entry Details: prob. a castle, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

Latium.Entry Details: ancient country on the Tyrrhenian Sea, Italy.

Latour.Entry Details: Château Latour, a wine of Bordeaux.

lattittzo.Entry Details: (It) lattizzo the skin of a suckling animal, similar to ermine.

laudatores temporis acti.Entry Details: (L) admirers of bygone days. (See: Horace, Ars Poetica, V, 173).

Laurance, John.Entry Details: 1750-1810, Revolutionary soldier and statesman, member of the House of Representatives (1789-93), U. S. Senator (1796-1800); active supporter of HAMILTON's monetary policies.

Laurens.Entry Details: Henry, 1724-92, American Revolutionary statesman; member of the Second CONTINENTAL CONGRESS and its president (1777-78), sent (1780) as U. S. commissioner to the Netherlands; was captured by the British and imprisoned in the Tower of London until exchanged for Cornwallis (1781). With Laurens was captured a copy of the U. S. -Dutch treaty, which England used as a pretext for war against the Netherlands.

Laurentius.Entry Details: reference to Lorenzo de' MEDICI, founder of the Laurentian Library in Florence.

la vecchia sotto S. Pantaleone.Entry Details: (It) the old lady under ST. PANTALEONE.

la vieille de Candide.Entry Details: (Fr) Candide's old woman. (See: Voltaire, Candide, XI-XII).

Lawes.Entry Details: Henry, 1596-1662, the English musician and composer; noted for his masques and airs for voice.

Lawrence, Thomas Edward.Entry Details: Lawrence of Arabia, 1888-1935, the British archaeologist, soldier and writer.

Lawrence, W..Entry Details: William George Lawrence, 1889-1915, younger brother of T. E. LAWRENCE; Will Lawrence invited Pound to St. John's College, Oxford, to speak on Provençal poetry. (See: Sir Ernest Baker, The Home Letters of T. E. Lawrence and His Brothers, 393, 395-397).

Lazarus, John Baptiste.Entry Details: see John Baptiste Lazarus de Theveneau de FRANCY.

League of Cambrai.Entry Details: 1508-1510 a league of the forces of Maximilian I, Louis XII of France, Pope Julius II, Ferdinand V of Aragon and several Italian towns against Venice; the League was temporarily successful

Léang-ki.Entry Details: (Liang Ki) d. AD 159, uncle of Emperor Han Chung Ti (reign: 145-146), Léang-ki and the queen dowager, Léang, became great powers in the Empire. Léang-ki served as prime minister under HAN-HOUON-TI, he sent poisoned cakes to those who insulted him, and was not very well liked. Finally Han-houon-ti sent three thousand men to put Léang-ki to death, Léang-ki saw what was up, and ate one of his own cakes. All the members of his house were slain and his treasure became the emperor's.

Leao.Entry Details: (Liao), the name of the dynasty of the KHITAN Tartars, the dynasty lasted from 907-1125, during which time the Khitans controlled much of northern China from their capital at Peiping.
