After the capture of Peiping by the KIN Tartars, the house of Leao was diminished to a minor dynasty known as the Western Liao (1125-1168).

Leber.Entry Details: prob. Albert Leber, a confectioner in Notting Hill, London, C. 1915.

Leboeuf.Entry Details: Edmond, 1809-88, French soldier and statesman, minister of war (1869-70); marshal of France (1870); disgraced in the Franco-Prussian War and retired.

Le corps des négociants de cette ville/.Entry Details: (Fr) the businessmen of this city/ wishing to add their acclamations to those of the whole nation/ J. NOLLET, SCHIEDAM, / 'I have been told that these gentlemen of Schiedam/ are giving this repast for a hundred people/ and that there will be many people from Rotterdam. (See: John Adams, Works, VII, 576).

Lee.Entry Details: William, American consul at Bordeaux during the Presidency of MONROE (1817-25).

Lee, A..Entry Details: Arthur, 1740-92, American diplomat; appointed in 1776 by the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS as one of the three commissioners to negotiate a treaty with France, he became suspicious of his associates, Benjamin FRANKLIN and Silas DEANE, and circulated charges against them. After the treaty was signed (1778), Deane was recalled; he charged in return that Lee did not have the confidence of the French foreign minister. Lee was then recalled in 1779. Lee served in the Continental Congress (1781-85), was a member of the Treasury Board (1784-89), and was among those who opposed the adoption of the Constitution.

Lee, Frank.Entry Details: Francis Lightfoot, 1734-97, American statesman; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1775-79), signer of the DECLARATION of Independence.

Lee, Henry.Entry Details: 1756-1818, also known as Light-Horse Harry Lee, American soldier and statesman; best known for his abilities as a cavalry commander in the Revolutionary War, when he covered Greene's retreat across North Carolina and Virginia (1781), member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1785-88); member of the House of Representatives, (1799-1801).

Lee, R. H..Entry Details: Richard Henry, 1732-94, American statesman; with Patrick HENRY and Thomas JEFFERSON, he initiated the intercolonial Committees of Correspondence (1773); delegate from Virginia to the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-79) where he supported ADAMS' proposals to negotiate a treaty with France; signer of DECLARATION of Independence; again a member of Congress (1784-89), U. S. Senator (1789-92).

Lees, the.Entry Details: the brothers, Arthur LEE, and William Lee, 1739-95, American merchant and diplomat; William Lee was appointed U. S. commercial agent in France (1777), negotiated a commercial treaty, never ratified, with Holland (1778); recalled by Congress (1779).

Leeuwarde.Entry Details: Leeuwarden, a commercial and industrial town, Friesland province, N Netherlands.

Legaré.Entry Details: Hugh Swinton, 1797-1843, American lawyer and statesman, elected (1837) to Congress as a Union Democrat; appointed Attorney General (1841), Secretary of State (1843) under TYLER.

Legge.Entry Details: James, 1815-97, Scottish missionary and sinologist; editor of The Chinese Classics, a translation with critical and exegetical notes, prolegomena, and copious indexes (London: 1861-86) 7 vol., of which volume I contains the Confucian Analects, the Great Learning, and the Doctrine of the Mean.

Legion of Honour.Entry Details: the French order, created by Napoleon (1802).

(Leicester Square).Entry Details: the square in the West End of London, near Piccadilly Circus.

Lei fassa furar a del.Entry Details: (Pr) had her (self) carried off by him (See also: Piere de Maensac: la donna se laisset furar ad el, the lady let herself be carried off by him).

Leighton House.Entry Details: house, formerly owned by Frederick, Lord Leighton, on Holland Park Road, London.

Lenin.Entry Details: Nikolai -- Vladimir Ilich Ulyanov -- 1870-1924, the Soviet statesman and Communist leader.

Lennox.Entry Details: Robert Lenox, 1759-1839, New York merchant; president of the New York Chamber of Commerce (1827-39).

Lenzini, Fr.Entry Details: Francesco, Sienese cleric who raised the liberty tree in Siena during the Napoleonic conquest, 7 April 1799.

Leon (1).Entry Details: region of NW Spain, comprising the modern provinces of León, Salamanca and Zamora.

[Leopold II] (1).Entry Details: 1747-92, Holy Roman Emperor (1790-92). As Grand Duke of Tuscany (1765-90), he was Leopold I.

[Leopold II] (2).Entry Details: 1797-1870, Grand Duke of Tuscany (1824-59), was son of FERDINAND III of Tuscany; grandson of LEOPOLD II, Holy Roman Emperor.

Leopold, Duke..Entry Details: see LEOPOLD II, Holy Roman Emperor.

Leopold, Peter.Entry Details: see LEOPOLD II, Holy Roman Emperor.

Leopoldine.Entry Details: reference to the Leopoldine reforms, carried out by LEOPOLD II, Holy Roman Emperor, who as Leopold I of Tuscany reorganized the Tuscan government, bringing about extensive changes in taxation, criminal punishment, and church affairs.

Leopoldo, Pietro.Entry Details: see LEOPOLD II, Holy Roman Emperor.

Le Paradis n'est pas artificiel.Entry Details: (Fr) Paradise is not artificial. (Poss. variation of Baudelaire, Les Paradis Artificiels).

le plus grand t de ce pays-ci/ entêté co.Entry Details: (Fr) the biggest t... of this country/ stubborn as a.

Le Portel.Entry Details: French fishing port on the Strait of Dover.

Lesbia.Entry Details: Clodia, wife of the consul Metellus Celer; a notorious profligate celebrated by Catullus, who referred to her as Lesbia.

les gradins/ quarante-trois rangées en c.Entry Details: (Fr) the steps/ forty-three tiers made of limestone.

Les hommes ont je ne sais quelle peur ét.Entry Details: (Fr) men have I don't know what strange fear/ of beauty.

Les membres de la Société Bourgeose/ de.Entry Details: (Fr) the members of the SOCIÉTÉ BOURGEOISE of LEEUWARDE.

les moeurs passent et la douleur reste..Entry Details: (Fr) customs go and pain remains. / "In pink crystal helmets, the mountebanks."

les SIX potences/ Absouldre, que tous no.Entry Details: (Fr) the SIX gallows/ Absolve, may you absolve us all. (See. Villon, Epitaphe de Villon Mais Priez Dieu que tous nous veiulle absoudre).

Let backe and side go bare.Entry Details: from the 16th century lyric Jolly Good Ale and Old, attributed to William Stevenson.

Lethe.Entry Details: the river of forgetfulness in Hades.

Letizia..Entry Details: Maria Letizia Ramolino, 1750-1836, mother of NAPOLEON.

Levant.Entry Details: the name given to that region, from Egypt to Turkey, along the E shores of the Mediterranean.

Le vieux commode en acajou.Entry Details: (Fr) la vieille the old ma- hogany chest.

Levine.Entry Details: Charles A., American pilot who, as a novice flyer, crossed the Atlantic in 1927; his plane, the Columbia, was almost wrecked during the crossing, but his luck held and he and his co-pilot reached Europe.

Leviticus.Entry Details: the Book of Leviticus in the Bible.

Lévy.Entry Details: Emil, 1855-1918, German philologist, author of Pro- vençal supplement dictionaire (8 vol., 1892-1925).

[Lévy-Bruhl].Entry Details: Lucien, 1857-1939, French philosopher, historian and anthropologist.

Lewis, P. Wyndham.Entry Details: Percy Wyndham, 1884-1957, the British writer and painter.

Lexington.Entry Details: see LEXINGTON AND CONCORD, battles of.

[Lexington and Concord, battles of].Entry Details: the opening engagements of the American Revolution, 19 April 1775.

Lex salica! lex Germanica.Entry Details: (L) the SALIC LAW! the German law.

Leyden.Entry Details: the industrial town of S Holland province, SW Netherlands.

Leyden Gazette.Entry Details: a Dutch newspaper, published in LEYDEN, in 1782.

li.Entry Details: (Ch) a measure of length, amounting to approximately 1890 feet.

Liberans et vinculo ab omni liberatos.Entry Details: (L) And freeing from every chain those who have been liberated.

Libertatem Amicitiam Fidem.Entry Details: (L) Liberty, Friendship, Loyalty. (See. John Adams, Works, I, 432-33, Adams' motto was Libertatem, amicitiam, fidem retinebis).

Liberty Tree.Entry Details: an elm which stood on Washington Street in Boston, on which unpopular persons were hung in effigy during the STAMP ACT agitation.

libris septem summam, scutorum.Entry Details: (L) in seven books, the sum of crowns.

Li-Chan.Entry Details: Liü-chan (Lu-shan), a mountain in Kiangsi province near Lake Po-yang; the residence of the scholar Lei-tsé-tsong (Lei Tzu-tsung), who refused to leave his mountain once he had seen to the courses of study at the academies founded by OUEN TI in AD 438. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, V, 44, 45).

Li-Chi.Entry Details: (Li Shih) d. AD 623, daughter of Emperor KAO-TSOU, in 617 she raised an army and came to the aid of her father in his struggles to gain the Empire; her husband was Chai Shao, a general in the army of Kao-tsou.

Li-ching.Entry Details: (Li Sheng) fl. AD 787, a captain in the imperial troops who had great success against the Tartars. In 787 it was discovered that he was having an affair with a daughter of Emperor SOU-TSONG. Li-ching became a remittance man in Kwangtung.

Li-Chun.Entry Details: (Li Shun) 778-821, Chinese emperor, son of Emperor TCHUN-TSONG, whom he succeeded in 806, ruled under the name HIEN-TSONG.

Lido.Entry Details: town on the N end of the island outside the Lagoon of Venice.

Lieou Ju.Entry Details: (Liu Ju) fl. AD 1084, historian at the court of Emperor CHIN-TSONG; one of those who helped SSE-MA-KOUANG compile the TSÉ-TCHI TONG-KIEN.

Lieou-kin.Entry Details: (Lau Chin) d. AD 1510. He and seven other palace eunuchs conspired to gain control over the young Emperor OU-TSONG by pandering to his tastes and enjoyments. So successful was the scheme that in 1508 the emperor decreed that all petitions had to pass through the hands of Lieou-kin. However, the emperor's uncle raised a rebellion and asked Lieou-kin's death as the price of peace. The emperor consented to imprison the eunuch, but when great amounts of treasure were found in his house, the emperor ordered Lieou-kin's execution.

(Lieou-ngan].Entry Details: (Liu An) fl. BC 130, Prince of HOAI-NAN; a leader of the literary revival during the reign of HAN-OU, although the Prince had little inclination toward the classics. (See. Mailla, Histoire Générale, III, 26).

Lieou-pang.Entry Details: (Liu Pang) 247-195, one of the two leaders of a revolt against the TSIN dynasty. It had been agreed that the first of the two generals to reach the capital should gain the principality of Tsin; Lieou-pang arrived first and Emperor TSE- YNG surrendered. However, the second general, HIANG-YU, was not satisfied with his bargain, and there were wars from 206 to 202 between the two. In 202 Lieou-pang defeated Hiang- yu and became emperor, founding the HAN dynasty and taking the title of KAO-HOANG-TI.

Lieou Pi.Entry Details: (Liu Pi) d. AD 806, a governor in SZECHWAN province who raised a rebellion because the territory under his control was not increased. Defeated in his first major battle against imperial troops, Lieou-pi, with all of his family, was sent to the capital and executed.

Lieou-siuen].Entry Details: (Liu Hsüan) fl. AD 1286, the minister of KUBLAI KHAN who persuaded the emperor to give up his plans to conquer Japan.

Lieou-Tchin.Entry Details: (Liu Chin) fl. AD 263, son of the Minor HAN emperor, Han Hou-chu (reign: 223-64)

Lieou-Tchi-Yuen.Entry Details: (Liu Chih-yüan) d. AD 948, a distinguished general and governor of SHANSI province under Emperor Chi Wang (reign. 934-37). When the emperor ordered his troops to attack the KHITAN Tartars, Lieou-tchi-yuen refused, knowing the imperial troops could not withstand the Khitans. After the Khitans withdrew from Kaifeng, the imperial capital, Lieou-tchi-yuen was proclaimed emperor by his army. He ruled under the name Kao Tsu (reign: 947-48), and founded the After HAN dynasty.

[Lieou-té].Entry Details: (Liu Tê) fl. BC 130, Prince of HO-KIEN, a leader of the literary revival during the reign of HAN-OU, the Prince spent much money and effort to recover and restore the Chinese classics (See. Mailla, Histoire Générale, III, 26)

Lieou-Tsong.Entry Details: (Lau Tsung) fl. AD 317, king of HAN.

Lieou-Y.Entry Details: (Lau I) fl. AD 282, a highly respected advisor of Emperor TCIN-OU-TI.

Lieou-yu.Entry Details: (Liu Yü) 356-422, the founder of the SUNG dynasty. In 399 he enlisted in the imperial army and was given a command of seventy men, so able was he that by 416 he was made commander-in-chief and Duke of SUNG. In 419 he caused Emperor TCIN-NGAN to be strangled and set up the latter's brother, Chin Kung Ti, as emperor. After sixteen months, Chin Kung Ti abdicated, and Lieou-yu took the throne with the title KAO-TSOU.

Lieou-yu-y.Entry Details: (Liu Yú-1) fl. AD 1725, an imperial examiner in letters for the province of SHANSI; he dealt successfully with a famine in his province and gained the approval of Emperor YONG-TCHING.

[Lightfoot, Robert].Entry Details: 1716-94, a loyalist of Rhode Island; judge of the British Court of Vice-Admiralty for the Southern District of North America.

Ligur' aoide.Entry Details: (Gr) a clear sweet song. (See: Appendix A).

[Liguria].Entry Details: region along the NW coast of Italy from Tuscany to France.

\"like an arrow the precise definition\".Entry Details: from The Unwobbling Pivot, XIV, 5; and poss. from Analects, XIII, iii, 1-7.

Li-ké-Yong.Entry Details: (Li K'o-yung) d. AD 908, a distinguished commander of the imperial troops. His campaigns against the Turfan invaders (a barbarian tribe in the province of Sinkiang, W China) were so successful that Emperor Chao Tsung (reign: 889-905) made him Prince of TCIN in 895.

Li Ki.Entry Details: (Li Chi) the Book of Rites compiled by the Elder and Younger Tai (fl. 1st-2nd century BC) from documents said to have come from CONFUCIUS and his disciples; the text was often revised and not completed until the 2nd century BC.

Liki.Entry Details: (Li Ki) fl. AD 807, a governor of a department in the province of KIANG-NAN who accumulated and hoarded the treasure of six departments, the emperor ordered that the money be put back in circulation to stimulate commerce.

Li Kiang.Entry Details: (Li Chiang) fl. AD 812, a minister of Emperor HIEN-TSONG.

Li koen.Entry Details: prob. Li-kieou-tching (Li-chiu-chêng), a large town in N China.

Li-kouang.Entry Details: (Li Kuang) fl. BC 144, a commander of the NW frontier of China whose task it was to guard against the Tartar tribes, or HIONG-NOU.

Likoue.Entry Details: Li-koué-tching (Li Kue-cheng) fl. AD 1644, commander of Peiping. After the death of Emperor HOAI-TSONG, he was forced to surrender the city to LI-TSE-TCHING, but he first demanded permission to give the emperor and empress a full imperial funeral.

Lilas, Les.Entry Details: Closerie des Lilas, restaurant in Paris, at the corner of Boulevard Saint-Michel and Boulevard des Montparnasse.

Lilibullero.Entry Details: Lillibullero, a song mocking the Irish Catholics, popular in England during the revolution of 1688, the whole song itself.

Lili Marlene.Entry Details: the most popular German war song of World War II.

Limoges.Entry Details: manufacturing and commercial city of Haute-Vienne department, W central France.

Lindaraja.Entry Details: prob. Lindaraxa, the Zegri princess in Gines Perez de Hita's Guerras Civiles de Granada.

Lindhauer.Entry Details: Gustave Landhauer, 1870-1919, German statesman, his government lasted seven, not "less than five, 11 days.

Ling Kong.Entry Details: (Ling Kung) d. BC 608, Prince of TCIN; "without virtue, without sense, his heart turned naturally to evil." (See: Mailla, Histoire Generale, II, 155).

Lin hing.Entry Details: Lü-hing, Chapter XXV of the SHU CHING. (See: section 21 of Chapter XXV).

Lin-Yun.Entry Details: (Lin Yun) fl. AD 806, a military officer serving under the rebel LIEOU-PI. He objected to the rebellion of his superior, and Lieou-pi ordered him to be beheaded; but Lin-yun was so brave that he was given his freedom.

[Li-ouang].Entry Details: (Li Wang) (reign: 878-841), known as the "Stern One. He was remorseless in his treatment of those who opposed him and was avaricious, always seeking money to carry out his cruel plans. Finally his people rose in rebellion, and Li-ouang fled to SHENSI.

Li-ouen.Entry Details: Li-ouen-tchong (Li Wen-chung) d. AD 1384, one of the best military officers serving Emperor HONG-VOU.

[Liou-ouang].Entry Details: (Liu Wang), imperial title of LI TSONGKOU.

Lipan.Entry Details: (Li Pan) d. AD 1618, king of the Koreans.

Lipus, Don.Entry Details: a son of Farinato de FARINATI.

Lir.Entry Details: Mamannan mac Lir, a Celtic sea god.

Li Sao.Entry Details: prob. the long Chinese poem by Ch'ü Yuan (343-290)

Lisboa.Entry Details: a district of Portugal, also Portuguese for LISBON.

Lisbon (2).Entry Details: a sweet, light-colored wine, produced in Estremadura and shipped from Lisbon, Portugal.

lisciate con lagrime/ politis lachrymis.Entry Details: (It) smoothed with tears/ (L) with polished tears.

[Li-siang-koue].Entry Details: (Li Hsiang-kuei) fl. AD 1355, a fighting companion of TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG.

Li-ssé.Entry Details: (Li Ssu) d. BC 208, prime minister of Emperor TSIN-CHI. Li-ssé convinced the emperor that all the unrest in the kingdom was the result of scholarly research and writing; he also suggested that it might be nice if all history could be destroyed so that Tsin-chi could appear as the "first emperor" of China All existing literature was ordered destroyed -- excepting only works on agriculture, medicine, and divination.

Lisses.Entry Details: prob. text should read: from Europe, two Misses (Wright). (See: John Quincy Adams, Diary, 330); poss. text should read: from Europe to U. S. (or Uni. Ss).

Li-ssé Yuen.Entry Details: (Li Ssu-yuan) 866-934, the adopted son of LI-KE-YONG. Like his father, he was a brilliant general and did much to preserve the After TANG dynasty. At the death of his half-brother, LI-TSUN-HIU, he was proclaimed emperor by the army, he ruled under the name MING-TSONG.

[Li-tsé-tching].Entry Details: (Li Tzu-ch'êng) 1606-45, a rebel against the MING dynasty. At the head of an army of brigands, he overran parts of Hupeh and Honan provinces (1640) and captured SHENSI province (1642). In 1644 he proclaimed himself first emperor of the Great Shun dynasty and marched on Peiping; the city fell and Emperor HOAI-TSONG killed himself. But OUSAN enlisted the aid of the MANCHUs and drove Li-tsé-tching out of Peiping. When Li-tsé-tching was slain in battle, the Manchus were left in control of China and established the Ch'ing dynasty (1644-1912).

Li Tsong.Entry Details: (Li Tsung) (reign: 1225-1265), fifth emperor of the Southern SUNG dynasty. He broke his treaty with the MONGOLs and attacked them in 1234; thereafter his reign was one of almost continual war with the Mongols.

Li Tsongkou.Entry Details: (Li Ts'ung-k'o) 892-936, commanding general of the imperial guards who later (934) came to the throne as the fourth emperor of the After TANG dynasty, ruling under the name Liu Wang). (reign: .934-36). His dynasty fell to the KHITAN Tartars.

[Li-tsun-hiu].Entry Details: (Li Ts'un-hsü) d. AD 926, the son of LI-KÉ-YONG. He overthrew the After LIANG dynasty, and in 923 set himself up as the first emperor of the After TANG dynasty, ruling under the name Chuang Tsung (reign: 923-26). He waged successful wars against the KHITAN Tartars, regaining the province of SZECHWAN for the Empire. Finally he gave himself up to sensuality and was assassinated by an actor.

Littleton.Entry Details: Sir Thomas, ?1407-81, English jurist and writer on the law. His work Tenures (1481 or 82) is the earliest printed treatise on English law, the text is the basis of COKE's commentary known as Coke upon Littleton.

Little Turtle.Entry Details: Meche Cunnaqua, d. 1812, Chief of the Mohegan Indians.

Litvinof.Entry Details: Maxim Maximovich Litvinov, 1876-1951, the Russian revolutionist and statesman.

Liu Ch'e.Entry Details: Liu Chi, d. AD 1375, Chinese poet and painter.

Liu-Heou.Entry Details: (Lu Hou) (reign: 187-179), the wife of KAO-HOANG-TI. She dominated her son, HIAO-HOEI-TI, during his reign, and after his death she continued to rule the Empire by placing puppet kings on the throne. She was an adept murderess, but an able ruler.

Liu-hoei.Entry Details: (Lu Hui) fl. AD 1069, a minister of Emperor CHIN-TSONG; opposed the reforms of OUANG-NGAN-CHE.

[Liu-hoei-king].Entry Details: (Lu Hui-ching) fl. AD 1069, a minister of Emperor CHIN-TSONG, supported the reforms of OUANG-NGAN-CHE.

Liveright, H..Entry Details: Horace Brisbin, 1886-1933, American publisher and theatrical producer, with Albert Boni founded the firm of Boni and Liveright (1918).

Liverpool.Entry Details: port city of Lancashire, NW England.

Livingston.Entry Details: Robert R., 1746-1813, American lawyer and statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1775-77, 1779-81); one of the committee which drafted the DECLARATION of Independence; first U. S. Secretary of Foreign Affairs (1781-83); U. S. minister to France (1801-04).

Livorno.Entry Details: (Leghorn) port and capital city of Livorno province in W Tuscany, Italy.

Lixos.Entry Details: the river in NW Africa by which HANNO stopped in his periplus; also name of the town established there -- the modern Larache.

Lixtae.Entry Details: the nomadic people of the LIXOS river area, NW Africa.

Lixtus mountain.Entry Details: the mountain area to the north of the LIXTAE, source of the LIXOS river.

Li-yen.Entry Details: (Li Yen) fl. AD 779, a mandarin serving in the government of Emperor TE-TSONG.

Li-yo.Entry Details: the Li Yo, a Chinese treatise on ceremonies and music.

Lloyd, L..Entry Details: James Lloyd, 1769-1831, U.S. Senator from Massachusetts (1808-13).

Loca Montis.Entry Details: (L) the regions of the mountain], name given to shares in the MONTE NUOVO.

Loco Signi.Entry Details: (L) in lieu of a sign (signature, seal).

Lodge.Entry Details: Henry Cabot, 1850-1924, American legislator, member of the House of Representatives (1887-93) and of the Senate (1893-1924), when chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the Senate, he was opposed to the Peace Treaty and the League of Nations (1919).

Lolli, Gorro.Entry Details: a nephew of Enea Silvio de PICCOLOMINI, Lolli served as the Sienese emissary to Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Lolme.Entry Details: John Louis de, 1740-1806, Swiss lawyer, author of The Constitution of England (1771).

Lombardo, Pietro.Entry Details: 1435-1515, Italian architect and sculptor, among his most famous works is the tomb of Dante at Ravenna.

[Lombardo, Tullio].Entry Details: ?1455-1532, Italian architect and sculptor, son of Pietro LOMBARDO, among his works are the VENDRAMINI tomb in Venice and four marble angels in Venice.

London Chronicle.Entry Details: not the London paper established in 1757; prob. a reference to the parliamentary debates and court decisions during the reign of JAMES I.

London Library.Entry Details: in St. James's Square, London, founded 1841.

Long Champ.Entry Details: Longchamp, the racecourse of Paris, in the Bois de Boulogne.

[Long-coto].Entry Details: (Lung Coto) fl. AD 1725, a near relation of Emperor YONG-TCHING and a prince of the Empire. In 1725 he was accused of extortion and embezzlement and sentenced to the rock pile in Tartary. In 1727 he was recalled by the Tribunal of Criminal Affairs and sentenced to death; sentence later commuted to life imprisonment.

Lord of the Fire.Entry Details: a spirit in ancient Chinese religion.

[Lorimer, George Horace].Entry Details: 1868-1937, American journalist, editor in chief of the Saturday Evening Post (1899-1936).

Loring.Entry Details: Frederic Wadsworth, 1848-71, American writer, poet and journalist.

Lorraine.Entry Details: region and former province in E France.

Lottieri, Zan.Entry Details: Zanobi Lottieri. (See Archivio Storico Italiano, Ser. IV, 111, Pt. 2, 184-197).

Lou (1).Entry Details: (Lü), the State of Lou was established by Tan, the Duke of Chou, in BC 1122, his son made his capital at Kieh-fu (in Shantung province, NE China) about 1115 and was called Duke Lou. Lou was the birthplace of CONFUCIUS.

Lou-chi.Entry Details: Lou-chi-Jong (Lu Shih-jong) d. AD 1285, a dishonest minister who served KUBLAI KHAN; he was known as the "second AHAMA." His intrigues gained him so many enemies that he was finally condemned to death, he was butchered and thrown into the street.

[Louis VII].Entry Details: ?1121-1180, King of France (1137-80), married ELEANOR of Aquitaine (1137), marriage annulled (1152).

[Louis, Duke of Parma].Entry Details: d. 1803, son-in-law of Charles IV of Spain; made king of Etruria in 1801.

Louisburg.Entry Details: Louisbourg, port city of E Nova Scotia, Canada.

Louis Quatorze.Entry Details: Le Siècle de Louis XIV by Voltaire (1751).

Lou-kia.Entry Details: (Lü Chia) fl. 2nd-3rd century BC, a diplomat in the service of Emperor KAO-HOANG-TI. He was sent to give the seal of office to Chao T'o (who had proclaimed himself Prince of Yuei) and to receive his declaration of allegiance. Lou-kia was so successful that the emperor appointed him minister of state. He left an account of his travels throughout the kingdom.

Lourpee.Entry Details: prob. a pseudonym for an unsuccessful French painter.

Lou Tai.Entry Details: (Lu-t'al), the "Stag Tower" built by Emperor CHEOU-SIN for his mistress, TAN-KI.

LYCABS.Entry Details: Lycabas, a member of the crew that attempted to...

Lou-tchéou.Entry Details: (Lü-ch'ou), a city, prob. in northern China.

[Lou-teng-yun].Entry Details: (Lú Têng-yun) fl. AD 1635, an officer of the imperial army serving Emperor HOAI-TSONG; he fought engagements against the Manchu forces then invading China.

Lowell.Entry Details: Amy, 1874-1925, the American poet and critic.

Lo Yang.Entry Details: city in N Honan province, E central China; founded in BC 1108, served as capital of several dynasties; also known as Honan.

L.P..Entry Details: prob. Le Paradis quoted in text three lines above.

Lucca.Entry Details: capital of Lucca province, Tuscany, central Italy.

Lucifer.Entry Details: name of the planet Venus when it is the morning star; also Satan, the fallen angel.

Lucina.Entry Details: a minor Roman deity of childbirth; an aspect of Juno, who is the goddess of childbirth.

lukoi oresteroi ede leontes.Entry Details: (Gr) mountain wolves and lions. (See: Appendix A).

Lussurioso incestuoso, perfide, sozzure.Entry Details: (It) Lustful, incestuous, perfidious, filthiness and great guzzling, / murderer, greedy, stingy, proud, unfaithful/ maker of false money, sodomist, uxoricide.

Lutèce.Entry Details: Lutetia Parisiorum, ancient name for Paris.

lux enim/ ignis est accidens.Entry Details: (L) for light/is an attribute of fire. (See: Grosseteste, De luce seu de inchoatione formarum, ed. Baur, 51, 56).

Lux enim per se omnem in partem.Entry Details: (L) For light of herself into every region. (See: Grosseteste, De luce seu de inchoatione formarum, ed. Baur, 51).

Luzerne, Chevalier de.Entry Details: Anne César Chevalier de la Luzerne, 1741-91, French diplomat; ambassador to America (1779-83), played a major role in the Paris peace conference, ambassador to England (1788-91).

Lyaeus.Entry Details: a name for DIONYSUS, especially connected with his role as the god of wine and ecstasy.

Lycabs.Entry Details: Lycabas, a member of the crew that attempted to abduct DIONYSUS. (See Ovid, Metamorphoses, III).

Lydia.Entry Details: ancient country in the center of W Asia Minor.

Lyman, Colonel..Entry Details: prob. William Lyman, d. 1811, brigadier-general of the Massachusetts militia during the Revolution, member of the Massachusetts legislature (1787) and senate (1789), member of the House of Representatives (1793-97).

Lynx (Lynxes).Entry Details: the lynx is an animal sacred to DIONYSUS.

M..Entry Details: poss. Robert McAlmon, 1895-1955, American novelist and poet, poss. Benito MUSSOLINI.

Macao.Entry Details: island west of the mouth of the Pearl river, Kwangtung province, SE China.

Maccoboy:.Entry Details: the Americanization of Macouba, a town of Martinique which was one of the principal foreign sources of snuff in the 18th and 19th centuries.

[Macdonagh, Thomas].Entry Details: 1878-1916: Irish patriot engaged in the 1917 rebellion of Ireland, executed, member of the Celtic Renaissance movement in literature.

Macer:.Entry Details: prob. Macareus, a companion of EURYLOCHUS. (See Ovid, Metamorphoses, XIV, 223 ff).

MacGorvish's bank.Entry Details: poss. either Barclay's or Westminster Bank, London.

McHenry:.Entry Details: James, 1753-1816, American politician, during the Revolution served as aid to General WASHINGTON and to LAFAYETTE, member of the Continental Congress (1783-86), delegate to the Constitutional Convention (1787); Secretary of War (1796-1800). While a member of John ADAMS' cabinet, McHenry remained loyal to the interests of Alexander HAMILTON.

ma che si sente dicho.Entry Details: (It) but that is felt, I say. (See: Cavalcanti, Donna mi prega).

Ma Chr..Entry Details: (Ma Shih) fl. AD 77, mother of Emperor Han Chang Ti (reign: 76-89); her wisdom and virtue aided the young emperor when he took the throne at the age of eighteen.

McIntosh, Captain:.Entry Details: captain of the English ship MARTHA, which was captured by the BOSTON in 1778.

Mackay, Elsie]:.Entry Details: 1894-1928, English aviatrix and screen actress, daughter of James Lyle Mackay, Viscount Inchcape (head of Peninsular and Oriental Steamship Co.), married to Dennis WYNDHAM (1917-22). In 1928 she accompanied Capt. Walter HINCHLIFFE on his disastrous flight across the Atlantic.

McKean, Thos..Entry Details: Thomas, 1734-1814, American statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-83) and its president (1781); signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, governor of Pennsylvania (1799-1808).

Mackintosh, Sir James:.Entry Details: 1765-1832, English scholar who defended the French Revolution in his Vindiciae Gallicae (1791), as a member of Parliament (1812-32), he supported penal and parliamentary reforms.

Maclay:.Entry Details: William, 1734-1804, American statesman, as a member of the Senate (1789-91), he was a strong opponent of HAMILTON's financial measures.

Macmillan Commission:.Entry Details: MacMillan Committee, a British committee on finance and industry (1929) under the chairmanship of Lord MacMillan. The Committee placed major blame for the depression not on the maintenance of the gold standard itself, but upon the short-sighted handling of it by major nations and upon the gold hoarding policies of the U. S. and France.

Macmorral.Entry Details: Dermod Mac Murrough, ?1110-1171, King of LEINSTER.

MacNarpen and Company.Entry Details: pseudonym for Macmillan and Company, the publishers.

Madeira (1).Entry Details: largest island of the group W of Morocco.

Madeira (2).Entry Details: wine made on the island of MADEIRA, malmsey, sercial, and bual are the best known.

Madison.Entry Details: James, 1751-1836, fourth President of the U. S., member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1780-83), the Constitutional Convention (1787); as a member of the House of Representatives (1789-97), Madison led the Democratic-Republican party opposition to HAMILTON's financial measures, Secretary of State (1801-09), President (1809-17).

Madonna in hortulo.Entry Details: (L) Madonna in the Garden, painting by STEFANO da Verona.

Maensac, Pieire de:.Entry Details: Pieire de, a poor knight of Auvergne, he and his brother, Austors, divided their possessions. Austors received the castle anu Pieire became a troubadour. Pieire ran away with the wife of Bernart de TIERCI, taking her to the castle of ROBERT, Dauphin of Auvergne. When de Tiercitried to regain his wife, the Dauphin protected Pieire and defeated de Tierci's attack. (See: Make It New, 26-27).

Maestro di pentore:.Entry Details: (It) Master of painting. (See: Piero dei FRANCHESHI).

mag duce dono/ felicitatem dominante et.Entry Details: (L) to the great duke/ gracious lord and sovereign and FERDINAND I.

magis decora poeticis fabulis:.Entry Details: (L) more suitable to poetic myths. (See: Livy, Praefatio 6).

Magna Charta:.Entry Details: the charter which the English barons forced King JOHN to sign on 15 June 1215 at Runnymede.

magna Nux animae:.Entry Details: (L) the great (Gr) night (L) of the soul. (See: St. John of the Cross, Dark Night of the Soul).

Magnifice ac potens domine, domini mi si.Entry Details: (L) To the magnificent and potent lord, my most excellent lord,/ humble advice permitted.

Magnifico, compater et carissime.Entry Details: (L) Magnificent, my father and most dear.

Mahamou.Entry Details: (Mahamu) d. AD 1418, chief of the YUEN Mongols, he paid homage to Emperor YONG-LO.

Maintenon, de:.Entry Details: Françoise d'Aubigné, Marquise, 1635-1719, mistress and second wife of Louis XIV of France.

Mais, qu'est-ce qu'on pense, / De la met.Entry Details: (Fr) But, what is thought/ of metallurgy in England, what do they/ think of METEVSKY?

Make it new Day by day make it new:.Entry Details: from The Great Digest, II, 1. (See: Appendix B).

Malacca.Entry Details: roughly, the area of the Malay Peninsula.

Malaspina, Marquis Antony Mary.Entry Details: fl. 1622, member of the Malaspina, an ancient family of Tuscany.

Malatesta (3).Entry Details: the Malatesta family of Rimini, prominent from the 13th to the 16th century.

Malatesta, Carlo.Entry Details: ?1364-1429, man of letters and patron of the arts, uncle of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

[ Malatesta da Verrucchio].Entry Details: 1212-1312, called "Old Mastiff"; great-great grandfather of Sigismondo MALATESTA. (See: Inferno, 27, 46).

[Malatesta, Domenico].Entry Details: 1418-65, younger brother of Sigismondo, known popularly as Malatesta Novello: "Novvy."

[Malatesta, Galeazzo].Entry Details: Lord of Pesaro and cousin of Sigismondo; known as l'Inetto (the Unfit); in 1444 he allowed Alessandro SFORZA to overrun and capture Pesaro; it has been claimed that Galeazzo sold the city to Sforza.

[Malatesta, Galeazzo Roberto].Entry Details: 1411-32, brother of Sigismondo and heir to the lordship of Rimini; he retired to a cell and lived the life of an ascetic, leaving Sigismondo, then twelve years old, to deal with the enemies of the Malatesta family.

[Malatesta, Lucrezia]..Entry Details: a daughter of Sigismondo MALATESTA by Isotta degli ATTI.

[Malatesta, Pandolfo]:.Entry Details: d. 1427, Lord of FANO, father of Sigismondo.

[Malatesta, Paolo]:.Entry Details: ?1247-83?, son of MALATESTA DA VERRUCCHIO; brother of Giovanni Malatesta, the lover of Francesca da Polenta (See: Inferno, 5).

[Malatesta, Parisina]:.Entry Details: d. 1425, wife of Niccolò d'ESTE, daughter of Carlo MALATESTA. When Niccolò discovered that Parisina was having an affair with his natural son, Ugo ALDOBRANDINO, he had them both beheaded.

Malatesta, Roberto.Entry Details: d. 1482, known as The Magnificent, son of Sigismondo In 1463 he was forced to surrender Fano, which he had held four months, to Federico d'URBINO, who commanded the forces of PIUS II. During the War of Ferrara (1480-84) Roberto fought for the Papacy, and was acclaimed as the deliverer of the Church when he saved Rome for Sixtus IV.

Malatesta, Sallustio]:.Entry Details: 1448-1470, son of Sigismondo MALATESTA and Isotta degli ATTI, Sallustio was murdered by his half-brother, Roberto MALATESTA.

[Malatesta, Sigismondo]:.Entry Details: Sigismondo Pandolfo Malatesta, 1417-68, patron of the arts, built the TEMPIO MALATESTIANO in Rimini, made war against Pope PIUS II and was excommunicated (1460); lost all possessions except Rimini (1463).

Malatesta de Malatestis ad Magnificum Do.Entry Details: (L) Malatesta of the Malatestas to his Magnificent Lord and Father.

Malemorte:.Entry Details: Malemorte-sur-Corrèze, village in Corrèze department, S central France; site of a once important castle.

Malesherbes:.Entry Details: Chrétien Guillaume de Lamoignon de, 1721-94, French statesman and writer on politics and law; banished by LOUIS XV but recalled (1774) by LOUIS XVI, minister of the interior (1775-76).

Malespina, Simone:.Entry Details: Simone Malaspina, a captain in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Malmaison:.Entry Details: a château near Paris; residence (1809-14) of the Empress Josephine, and later of Maria Christina of Spain and of the Empress Eugénie.

Malta:.Entry Details: the British island in the Mediterranean.

Mana aboda.Entry Details: title of a poem by T. E. HULME (see: Personae, 252), aboda (Heb): work, achievement.

Manchester Cardiff:.Entry Details: railroad line in England, running from Manchester to Cardiff, Wales.

Manchu:.Entry Details: a Tartar tribe originally descended from the NUTCHÉ Tartars. The Manchu power was established in 1587 by Nurhachu, in 1644 the Manchu brought about the fall of the Ming dynasty and established the Ch'ing dynasty (1644-1912).

Mandarin(s):.Entry Details: members of the mandarinate, the scholar ruling class, or civil service, of China which rose about BC 600. The mandarins were disliked, but respected, by the people of China.

Manes:.Entry Details: ? 216-276?, the Persian sage, founder of the sect of MANICHEANS; for his teaching he was condemned and crucified.

Manfredi, Astorre:.Entry Details: member of the ruling Manfredi family of Faenza.

[Mangu Khan]:.Entry Details: (reign 1249-59), emperor of the Mongols, he put down all feudal opposition to his rule, reduced the tax burden, and curbed the power of the nobles. In 1259 he invaded SZECHWAN province and besieged Ho-chou (60 miles N of Chungking); the city resisted, and when plague broke out in the Mongol ranks, the soldiers killed Mangu Khan and retired.

Manhattan:.Entry Details: the borough of New York city.

Manicheans:.Entry Details: followers of the religious system founded by MANES, it is a system based on a dualism of good and evil, of a Good and an Evil One, both of equal power, existing in the universe.

Manilla:.Entry Details: Manila, former province of the Philippine Islands; the city of Manila on SW Luzon.

Manitou:.Entry Details: the Algonquian Indian name for the natural power which permeates all things.

Mansour:.Entry Details: (Mansur) fl. AD 1522, a prince of the Tartar tribes which occupied the area of Turfan, in Sinkiang province, W China.

Mantegna:.Entry Details: Andrea, 1431-1506, Italian painter who worked for the Gonzaga family of Mantua doing frescoes (1460-1506).

Mantua:.Entry Details: capital of Mantova province, Lombardy, N Italy.

Manuel:.Entry Details: Manuel I Comnenus, 1120-80, emperor of the Eastern Roman Empire, his reign was marked by military victories against Italians, Venetians, Serbs, and Turks, but he was defeated by the Seljuks in Phrygia (1176).

[Manutius, Aldus]:.Entry Details: 1450-1515, Italian printer and classical scholar, founder of the Aldine Press and of the New Academy, a group of Hellenic scholars.

Manxman:.Entry Details: an inhabitant of the Isle of Man.

Marblehead..Entry Details: town in NE Massachusetts, on the Atlantic coast.

Marches:.Entry Details: the region in central Italy extending from the eastern slopes of the Apennines to the Adriatic coast.

Marengo:.Entry Details: village in Alessandria province, NW Italy; scene of the battle in which NAPOLEON defeated the Austrians (14 June 1800).

Marescotti, Caloanes:.Entry Details: prob. a member of the Sienese BALÍA. C. 1622,

[Maria Francisca].Entry Details: 1734-1816; Maria I, Queen of Portugal (1777-1816) she was both sickly and weak-minded.

[Maria Magdalena].Entry Details: fl. 1622, mother of FERDINAND II of Tuscany, sister of Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor. Since her son became Grand Duke of Tuscany at the age of ten, she served not only as his guardian (tutrice), but also as royal regent, hence the references in letters quoted to Their Highnesses, meaning mother and son.

[Marie Louise].Entry Details: 1791-1847, the daughter of Emperor Francis I of Austria; second wife of NAPOLEON. She was also known as Marie da Parma.

Maritain:.Entry Details: Jacques, 1882- , the French neo-Thomist theologian and philosopher.

Marozia.Entry Details: d. 945, wife of Alberic I, Prince of Rome, mistress of Pope Sergius III.

Mars:.Entry Details: the Roman god of war; also the planet Mars.

Marshall..Entry Details: John, 1755-1835, the American jurist, one of the American commissioners to France (1797-98), member of the House of Representatives (1799-1800), Secretary of State (1800-01), Chief Justice of the Supreme Court (1801-35). Marshall established the basic principles of Constitutional interpretation by his decisions.

Martha.Entry Details: an English merchant ship, commanded by Captain McINTOSH, which was captured (1778) by the BOSTON, an American ship commanded by Captain Samuel TUCKER.

Martin:.Entry Details: Joseph William, 1884- , American politician; member of the House of Representatives (from 1925), Republican party leader in the House since 1939.

Martineau.Entry Details: Harriet, 1802-76, English novelist and economist, author of many books, including Illustrations of Political Economy (1832-34).

Martinique:.Entry Details: island in the Windward Islands, West Indies.

Martin's:.Entry Details: an inn between Salem and Boston, Massachusetts.

Maryland.Entry Details: a middle Atlantic state of the U.S.A., the MASON-DIXON line which forms the border between Maryland and Pennsylvania, IS often used to indicate the division between the North and the South of the U.S.

Maryland, the.Entry Details: an American ship which was directed to bring Thomas PAINE from France to America (c. 1787).

Masefield:.Entry Details: John, 1878- , the English poet laureate (since 1930), playwright and novelist.

Ma se morisse! / Credesse caduto da sè,.Entry Details: (It) But if he should die! / Believed fallen by himself, but if he should die. (See: Varchi, Storia Fiorentino, III, 262).

Mason and Dixon:.Entry Details: Mason and Dixon Line: the boundary between Pennsylvania and Maryland; surveyed by the English astronomers Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon (1763-67).

Mass:.Entry Details: the performance of the sacrament of the Eucharist in the Catholic Church.

[Massachusetts Colonal Charter].Entry Details: the charter grantedfirs (1628) to the New England Company and then (1629) to the Massachusetts Bay Company. Although once annulled (1684), the charter formed the basis of Massachusetts government until the state constitution was adopted (1780).

[Massachusetts Colonial Legislature].Entry Details: a legislative body consisting of a lower house, the House of Representatives, and an upper house, the Council.

[Massachusetts State Constitution].Entry Details: written in large part by John ADAMS (1779), adopted (1780).

Mastai..Entry Details: Giovanni Maria Mastai-Ferreti, 1792-1878, Pope Pius IX (1846-78), fled Rome in the insurrection of 1848, restored by the French (1850), became an extreme reactionary and supported the House of Savoy.

\"Master thyself, then others shall thee.Entry Details: variation of Chaucer, Ballade of Good Counsel "Reule wel thyself, that other folk canst rede. (Robinson, 631) (See: M. E. SPEARE, The Pocket Book of Verse, 1, where the line is rendered: "Subdue thyself, and others thee shall hear. ").

Ma-tchéou.Entry Details: (Ma Ch'ou) fl. AD 637, a minister serving Emperor TAI-TSONG.

Mathews, Elkin.Entry Details: London publisher, published several of Pound's early works, 1908-1916.

Matlock..Entry Details: Timothy Matlack, d. 1829, American Revolutionary statesman; assistant secretary to the Continental Congress (1775), member of the Pennsylvania constitutional convention (1776) and of the committee to draft the constitution of Pennsylvania.

Mattias Passion.Entry Details: the Passion according to St. Matthew by Johann Sebastian BACH (1729).

Mauleon, Savaric de.Entry Details: d. 1236, French warrior and troubador whose loyalties vacillated between Henry III of England and Louis VIII of France. (See: "Troubadors, their sorts and conditions" in Literary Essays, 94-108).

Max.Entry Details: Max Beerbohm, 1872-1956, the English writer and caricaturist.

[Maxim, Hiram Stevens].Entry Details: 1840-1916, inventor of the Maxim automatic gun.

Mazzei.Entry Details: Philip, 1730-1816, Italian physician who came to Virginia in 1773, he was a strong supporter of the American Revolution and was an American agent in Italy (1779-83).

Mead.Entry Details: G. R. S., 1863-1933, English writer, editor of The Quest, a quarterly review.

Meath.Entry Details: former kingdom in Leinster province, Ireland.

Medicii.Entry Details: Italian family powerful in Florence and Tuscany from the 14th to the 16th centuries.

Medici, Alessandro de'.Entry Details: 1511-1537, Duke of Florence (1531-37); murdered by his kinsman Lorenzino de' MEDICI because of his tyrannical rule.

Medici, Cosimo.Entry Details: Cosimo de' Medici, 1389-1464, Florentine banker, patron of the arts, and ruler of the Florentine Republic; called Pater Patriae; founder of the elder branch of the Medici family.

Medici, Francesco de'.Entry Details: 1541-1587, Grand Duke of Tuscany (1574-87); son of Cosimo I de' Medici.

Medici, Giohanni.Entry Details: Giovanni de' Medici, 1360-1428, Florentine merchant and founder of the Medici family; from his two sons COSIMO (1389-1464) and Lorenzo (1395-1440) derive the two great branches of the family.

Medici, Giovanni de'.Entry Details: 1421-1463, favorite son of Cosimo de' MEDICI.

Medici, Giuliano de'.Entry Details: d. 1478, brother of Lorenzo de' Medici; stabbed to death by Bernardo Bandini and Francesco de Pazzi.

Medici, Lorenzino de'.Entry Details: 1515-1547, grandson of Lorenzo the Younger (1463-1507); murdered his distant kinsman, Alessandro de' MEDICI, in 1537.

Medici, Lorenzo de'.Entry Details: 1449-92, known as Lorenzo il Magnifico; Florentine statesman, ruler and patron of arts and letters; one of the great figures of the Italian Renaissance.

Medici, Piero de'.Entry Details: 1416-69, Italian merchant prince, son of Cosimo de' MEDICI.

Medici, Pietro de.Entry Details: poss. Pietro de' Medici, 1554-1604, son of Cosimo I de' MEDICI, Grand Duke of Tuscany.

Medici bank.Entry Details: the Medici Bank in Florence, established by Cosimo de' MEDICI.

Medon.Entry Details: a member of the crew which tried to abduct DIONYSUS as he was on his way to NAXOS. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, III, 671).

Medusa.Entry Details: one of the three Gorgons; her face turned to stone anything that met its gaze.

Meerkemaer.Entry Details: fl. 1780, a Dutch broker employed by the banking house of VAN STAPHORST.

Melchizedek.Entry Details: a pre-Aaronic and pre-Levitical priest-king to whom Abraham paid tithes, a prototype of the high priest.

Meli.Entry Details: Melitta, town on the Atlantic coast of North Africa, founded by HANNO, just south of AKRA.

Mellon.Entry Details: Andrew William, 1855-1937, American financier, largely interested in coal, coke and iron industries as well as international banking, U. S. ambassador to Great Britain (1932-33).

meminisse juvebit.Entry Details: (L) meminisse juvabit: it will be pleasant to recall. (See. Aeneid, I, 203).

Memling.Entry Details: Hans, ?1430-95, painter of the early Flemish school.

Memnons.Entry Details: Memnon, son of Tithonus and EOS; a large statue near Thebes, Egypt (supposed to be of Memnon), was reputed to produce a musical sound when struck by the light of dawn.

mémoires des académies/ des sciences de.Entry Details: (Fr) memoirs of the Academies / of Sciences of Paris. (See Mailla, Histoire Générale, XI, 364).

Mencius.Entry Details: (Mêng-tzu or Mêng K'o) 372-289, Chinese philosopher who was a follower of CONFUCIUS, author of the second of the Four Books of the Chinese classics, the Book of Mencius.

Mencken, Henry.Entry Details: Henry Louis, 1880-1956, the American editor, author and critic.

Mendoça, de.Entry Details: poss. Diego di Mendozza, ambassador to Rome from Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor.

Menelik.Entry Details: Menelik II, 1844-1913, Emperor of Ethiopia (1889-1913), in a war with Italy (1896) Menelik freed Ethiopia from Italian control.

Meng Kong.Entry Details: (Meng Kung) d. AD 1246, an officer of the imperial troops serving Emperor Li Tsung (reign: 1225-65). Meng-kong was the leader of several imperial campaigns against the Mongol.

Meninas, Las.Entry Details: painting by VELASQUEZ, in the Prado.

mens sine affectu.Entry Details: (L) a mind without feeling (passion). (See John Adams, Works, I, 114, where the phrase is quoted from a work by Algernon Sidney).

Mercury.Entry Details: the Roman equivalent of the god HERMES, the caduces of Mercury, the insignia of the medical branch of the U. S. Army, is a wing-topped staff with two snakes winding about it.

Merino.Entry Details: a breed of sheep which originated in Spain; known for its very fine and heavy wool.

Merry Mount.Entry Details: by 1627, the new name of Mt. WOLLASTON.

Messiah (1).Entry Details: a poem by Alexander POPE, first published in The Spectator, no. 378 (14 May 1712).

Messina.Entry Details: capital of Messina province in NE Sicily, the great earthquake at Messina occurred on 28 December 1908, when 90 percent of the buildings were destroyed.

Metastasio.Entry Details: Pietro, 1698-1782, Italian poet and dramatist; court poet at Vienna from 1729.

Metathemenon Te Ton/ Krumenon.Entry Details: (Gr) if those who use a currency give it up in favour of another. (See: Appendix A).

Metello.Entry Details: Alexandre Metello-Souza-y-Menezes fl. 1726, Portuguese ambassador to Emperor KANG HI of China. Metello and the Jesuit Antoine Magalhaens reached Peiping in 1727 and tried to make a treaty that would give the Portuguese special privileges in the China trade. The emperor assumed, however, that the two had merely come to pay tribute to him, and the talks on trade had no result.

Metternich.Entry Details: Clemens Wenzel Nepomuk Lothar, Furst von, 1773-1859, the Austrian statesman, intimately involved in the Congress of Vienna (1815).

Meudon.Entry Details: SW suburb of Paris on the Seine; the château, built by Louis XIV, surrounded by the Forêt de Meudon.

Miaco.Entry Details: the present city of Kyoto, Japan; established as the capital of Japan (AD 784) and remained officially the capital until 1869 when the government was removed to Tokyo.

Miao Haokien.Entry Details: (Miao Hao-chien) fl. AD 1318, author of a work on the cultivation of mulberry trees and the production of silk, Emperor GIN-TSONG had copies of the work circulated among the provinces.

Micah.Entry Details: fl. BC 710, Hebrew prophet, author of the book of Micah. (See. Micah, 4, 5).

Midas.Entry Details: the legendary king of Phrygia whose touch turned things to gold.

Middle Kingdom.Entry Details: one of the many names for the Chinese Empire, others are Flowery Kingdom and Celestial Empire.

Middletown.Entry Details: city in S Connecticut, S of HARTFORD.

Mie.Entry Details: Mei-tchéou (Mei-ch'ou), a large town in SZECHWAN province, China.

Mifflin.Entry Details: Thomas, 1744-1800, American Revolutionary officer and statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-76; 1782-84) and its president (1783); aide-de-camp to General WASHINGTON (1775), rose to the rank of major general later, member of the Constitutional Convention (1787).

\"mi-hine eyes hey\".Entry Details: from Julia Ward Howe, Battle Hymn of the Republic.

Milan.Entry Details: capital of Milano province, Lombardy, N Italy.

Milé Buddha.Entry Details: Mille (or Maitréya) Buddha or the Goddess of Mercy, a reincarnation of BUDDHA. During the reign of Emperor CHUNTI there was much unrest, many famines, earthquakes, and heavenly disturbances, when the emperor started work on the diversion of the Hwang-Ho, there was a surge of popular resentment and it was rumoured that Buddha was soon to descend to save China from the Mongol dynasty. This rumour was used for political purposes by the WHITE LILY SOCIETY.

mille cinquecento cavalli/ E li homini d.Entry Details: (It) and fifteen hundred horses and Messer Sigismondo's (MALATESTA) men/ were only thirteen hundred.

Mills bomb.Entry Details: the Mills hand grenade used by British and Allies in World War I, invented by Sir William Mills.

Mi mise, il mio sposo novello.Entry Details: (It) My recently betrothed sent me. (See. St. Francis of Assisi, Cantico Secondo, stanza 1: Lo mio sposo novello).

[Min].Entry Details: fl. BC 2119, Empress of Siang (2146-2118), mother of Emperor CHAO KANG.

Ming histories.Entry Details: the Ming Chi Kang Mu, a history of the MING dynasty, this work, finished in 1742, did not receive imperial approval, and the T'ung Chien Kang Mu San Pien was substituted for it in 1775. Emperor KIEN-LONG's redaction of the Ming histories was published under the title Yu Chih Kang Chien.

Ming Ouan.Entry Details: Ming-ouang (Ming Wang), the dynastic title assumed by HAN-LIN-EUL.

Ming rebellion.Entry Details: the Ming forces which resisted the Manchu Emperor Shun Chih throughout his reign (1644-62).

Ming T'ang.Entry Details: the "Temple of Light" (or "Wisdom"), the temple where the imperial family of China worshipped its ancestors.

Ming Tsong.Entry Details: (Ming Tsung) (reign 926-34), proclaimed emperor by the army but refused for a time to function as anything but regent. In 932 the art of printing was discovered; the nine classics were printed by imperial orders from wooden blocks and sold to the public.

[Min-kong].Entry Details: (Min Kung) d. BC 478, Prince of TCHIN.

Mi pare che avea decto hogni chossia.Entry Details: (It) It seems to me that he had said everything.

Mirabel.Entry Details: Comte Montagnini, fl. 1782, minister plenipotentiary of Victor Amadeus III, King of Sardinia.

Miranda.Entry Details: Francisco de, 1750-1816, Venezuelan revolutionist and leader of the Venezuelan struggle for liberty, in 1806 he sought foreign and led an expedition to the Venezuelan coast, but the military venture was a failure, he was a commander of the forces during the revolution of 1810 and was dictator for a short time. prob. the character in Shakespeare's The Tempest.

Mir sagen/ Die Damen/ Du bist Greis.Entry Details: (Ger) The ladies say to me,/you are an old man.

Miseria servitus, ubi jus vagum.Entry Details: (L) Misera. Slavery is a misery, where rights are undefined.

Missouri.Entry Details: central state of the U. S., capital is Jefferson City.

Mitchell.Entry Details: Samuel Latham Mitchill, 1763-1831, American physician, historian, student of natural history, and statesman, served for a time as Professor of Chemistry and Natural History at Columbia College, edited several volumes of the Medical Repository, wrote a Life of Tammany, the Indian Chief; member of the House of Representatives (1801-04, 1810-13) and of the Senate (1804-09).

Mitchell, Weir.Entry Details: Silas Weir Mitchell, 1829-1914, American physician, author of several volumes of poetry and fiction, founder of the FRANKLIN INN CLUB.

Mithras.Entry Details: ancient cultic god of Iran and India, by the 2nd century AD, the worship of Mithra had spread throughout the Roman Empire, largely because the cult was popular with the Roman legions. Mithraism consisted of an ethic based on loyalty, on a mystery cult, and on rituals of blood baptism and a sacred banquet.

Mitteleuropa.Entry Details: Central Europe, especially that portion of Europe which the advocates of Pan-Germanism proposed to form into an empire.

m'l'a calata.Entry Details: (It) he put that on me; he fooled me.

Mme la Duchess d'Agen a 5 ou 6 enfants.Entry Details: (Fr) Madame the Duchess d'AYEN has five or SIX children/ contrary to the custom of the country.

Mockel.Entry Details: Albert Henri Louis, 1866-1945, Belgian-French poet and critic; founder and editor (1886-92) of the journal LA WALLONIE, magazine of the Belgian symbolists.

Modena.Entry Details: capital of Modena province, N central Italy.

Modon Brandos.Entry Details: prob. Modon, a Greek town in Morea, S of Mavarino.

Moffat.Entry Details: Thomas Moffatt, d. after 1779, loyalist of Rhode Island, comptroller of the customs at New London (c. 1770), left America in 1775.

Mohamed.Entry Details: see MOHAMED BEN ABT EL HJAMEED.

Mohamed Ben Abt el Hjameed.Entry Details: prob. a merchant in Gibraltar, C. 1908.

[Mohammed].Entry Details: 570-632, Arabian prophet, founder of the Mohammedan religion.

[Mohammed VI].Entry Details: 1861-1926, last Ottoman sultan (1918-22); deposed in 1922 when Turkey became a republic.

Mongol (Mongols).Entry Details: the wandering barbarian tribes which occupied a vast territory to the north of China; they were unified and brought to political prominence under the leadership of GHENGHIS KHAN.

Monroe.Entry Details: James, 1758-1831, fifth president of the U. S., member of the Continental Congress (1783-86), and of the U. S. Senate (1790-94), minister to France (1794-96) and to England (1803-07), Secretary of State (1811-17) and of War (1814-15); President (1817-25).

Monsieur Adams il y a cent ans que je/ n.Entry Details: (Fr) Mister ADAMS (John Quincy), I haven't seen you for a hundred years. (See J. Q. Adams, Diary, 83).

[Montagu, George].Entry Details: 1737-88, fourth Duke of Manchester; English ambassador to France to treat for peace (1783).

Monte.Entry Details: (It) mountain, collection, heap, (bank). (See. MONTE DEI PASCHI).

Monte Cogruzzo.Entry Details: prob. a castle, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

Monte dei Paschi.Entry Details: the Sienese bank, founded in 1624 and still in existence, the "Mountain of the Pastures" bank, with credit backed by the Sienese public lands, the pastures of the Maremma, as security, was established under a grant from FERDINAND II of Tuscany. (Also called in text: BANK, MONTE, MONTE NUOVO, MONTE PASCHALE, MOUNT, MOUNTAIN, NEW MONTE, NEW MOUNT, and NEW MOUNTAIN).

Montefiore.Entry Details: a town in Garfagnana, N Tuscany.

Monte Gioiosa.Entry Details: prob. Giojosa, a town of Sicily on the N coast; built at the foot of the mountain on which stood Giojosa Vecchio (Old Giojosa).

Monte non vacabilis publico.Entry Details: poss. (Medieval L) the public (funds) of the Monte (dei Paschi) will not remain idle.

Monte Nuovo.Entry Details: the New Mountain or MONTE DEI PASCHI.

[Monte Odoriso].Entry Details: one of the five castles in the Abruzzi; given to SORDELLO for his services by CHARLES I of Naples and Sicily (1269).

Montepulciano.Entry Details: erroneous reference to Montemassi, town in central Italy, SW of Siena. (See RICCIO).

[Monte San Silvestro].Entry Details: one of the five castles in the Abruzzi; given to SORDELLO for his services by CHARLES I of Naples and Sicily (1269).

Montfort, Simone de.Entry Details: Simon IV de Montfort l'Amaury, ?1160-1218, count of Montfort and earl of Leicester; leader of the crusade against the ALBIGENSES (1209-29), killed at the siege of Toulouse.

Monthieu.Entry Details: John Joseph de, fl. 1780, a business partner of BEAUMARCHAIS and connected with RODERIQUE HORTALEZ & CO.; Monthieu arranged the sale and rental of armed vessels to America during the Revolution.

Monticello [21/98].Entry Details: the residence of Thomas JEFFERSON; near Charlottesville, Virginia.

Moore.Entry Details: Sir Francis, 1558-1621, English law reporter; his most important work, often called "Moore's Reports," is Cases Collect and Report (1663).

More, Sir Thos..Entry Details: Sir Thomas, 1478-1535, the English statesman, humanist and author.

Morea..Entry Details: the Peloponnesus, south part of the mainland of Greece. In 1464 Sigismondo MALATESTA led an unsuccessful crusade against the Turks in Morea.

Morgan: Daniel.Entry Details: 1736-1802, American Revolutionary soldier, captain of a company of Virginia riflemen.

Morgan (1).Entry Details: John Pierpont, 1837-1913, the American banker and financier.

Morgan (2).Entry Details: William, 1750-1833, author of The Memoirs of the Life of the Rev. Richard Price (1815).

[Morgenthau, Henry].Entry Details: 1856-1946, American diplomat; ambassador to Turkey (1913-16) and to Mexico (1920).

Morgenthau, Henry Jr..Entry Details: 1891- , U. S. Secretary of the Treasury (1934-45).

Morris, Gouverneur.Entry Details: 1752-1816, American statesman; member of the Continental Congress (1778-79) and of the Constitutional Convention (1787), member of the Senate (1800-03), a very influential figure in New York state politics.

Morris, Robt.Entry Details: Robert, 1734-1806, American financier and statesman; member of the Continental Congress (1776-78); signer of the DECLARATION of Independence; member of the Senate (1789-95).

Morse.Entry Details: Samuel Finley Breese, 1791-1872, the American artist and inventor.

mortaretti.Entry Details: (It) mortaletto: a small mortar used for firing a bonfire.

Mortier.Entry Details: fl. 1780, a Dutch broker employed by the banking house of VAN STAPHORST.

Most Serene M. Dux.Entry Details: reference to FERDINAND II of Tuscany.

Mougden.Entry Details: (Mukden), city in S Manchuria which controls the north-to-south trade in S Manchuria; became the Manchu capital in 1625, served as the base for the Manchu invasion of China (1644), was capital during the Manchu rule over China (1644-1912).

Mt Alban, Lord.Entry Details: Montalbano, member of the Sienese BALIA (c. 1622).

Mount of Pity.Entry Details: Monte di Pietà, a Sienese bank with credit based upon personal collateral, a kind of pawnshop, in existence before and finally merged with MONTE DEI PASCHI. (Also called in text. HOCK SHOP, PAWN SHOP, MOUNT, and PITY).

Mt Tai Haku.Entry Details: 300 miles from heaven pine needle carpet 56/47 from the Chinese of Li Po.

Mou-Ouang.Entry Details: (Mu Wang) (reign: 1001-946), fifth emperor of the CHOU dynasty; famous for his military campaigns. He decreed that punishments might be redeemed by a money payment, and some three thousand offenses were made expiable by this method.

Mouquin.Entry Details: a famous restaurant in New York, C. 1900.

Mou-Tsong.Entry Details: (Mu Tsung) (reign 821-25), an inept emperor who was too fond of amusement and who let eunuchs run the government, he died of drinking various concoctions, among which he hoped to find the elixir of life.

Mou Ye.Entry Details: (Muh) the battle field in the north of HONAN, in the country of K'i, where the forces of WU WANG and CHEOU-SIN met; in this battle (BC 1122) Emperor Cheou-sin was defeated and the CHANG dynasty brought to an end. (See: Classic Anthology, ode 236).

Mozarello.Entry Details: a poetaster of the time of Pope Leo X (1513-21).

Münch.Entry Details: Gerhardt, 20th century pianist, often played concerts in Rapallo.

Murray.Entry Details: William Vans, 1760-1803, appointed minister to the Hague (1798), replacing John Quincy ADAMS; was instrumental in preparing the way for recognition of an American minister to France.

Murray's barracks.Entry Details: the barracks in Brattle Street, Boston, where the 29th Regiment of His Majesty's Regulars were quartered (1770).

[Murray, William].Entry Details: 1705-93, first earl of Mansfield, English jurist and parliamentary debater.

Musée de Cluny, le.Entry Details: the Cluny Museum, a 14th-15th century Gothic and Renaissance structure in Paris, built by Pierre de Chaslus, abbot of Cluny; it houses a collection of French art of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance.

Musée del Prado.Entry Details: the Prado, Spanish national museum of painting and sculpture, in Madrid.

Muses.Entry Details: the nine Greek goddesses who were patrons of the arts and sciences.

mus ingens, ingens, noli meum granum com.Entry Details: (L) huge, huge mouse, don't eat my grain. (See: A. Lacharme, Confucii Chi-King, I, 9, 7, p. 47, Classic Anthology, 113).

Mustafa.Entry Details: prob. a merchant in Gibraltar, C. 1908.

Mycenian.Entry Details: reference to Mycenae, ancient city on the plain of Argos.

\"My Lady of Ventadour\".Entry Details: for the sources of this lyric, see Carl Appel, Bernart von Ventadorn (1915), numbers 7:4-5, 8:1-2, 12. 8, 22.63; 44:50.

[Mytilene].Entry Details: the island of Lesbos, in the Aegean.

Naishapur.Entry Details: Nishapur, town in NE Iran; birthplace of Omar Khayyam. (See- Rubaiyat, stanza 8).

Nana.Entry Details: in the legends which gathered about the historical BUDDHA, she is said to have been a virgin who miraculously gave birth to Buddha after the figure of the Supreme Being appeared to her in the form of a white elephant.

Nanking.Entry Details: city in W Kiangsu province, E China, on the south bank of the Yangtze; founded by the MING dynasty in 1368 and served as the Ming capital (1368-1403); known as the Southern Capital.

Nan-koan.Entry Details: the "South Pass" a few miles north of Nankow, Hopeh province in NE China, also the tribe of NUTCHÉ Tartars which takes its name from the region of the pass.

Nantasket.Entry Details: Nantasket Beach, village in E Massachusetts.

Nantes.Entry Details: manufacturing and commercial city of Lore-Inférieure department, NW France.

Nan-Young.Entry Details: a disciple of CONFUCIUS. (See: Analects, V, i).

Nan-yuei.Entry Details: (Nan-yueh), the State of Yuei (Yueh) in Honan province, E central China, along the Hwang Ho.

Napishtim.Entry Details: Uta-napishtim, a character in the Babylonian epic, Gilgamish, he reveals to Gilgamish "knowledge deep-hidden." (See: Gilgamish, Tablet XI).

[Napoleon I].Entry Details: Napoleon Bonaparte, 1769-1821, Emperor of the French (1805-14).

[Napoleon II].Entry Details: François Charles Joseph Napoleon, 1811-32, son of NAPOLEON I and MARIE LOUISE; titular king of Rome.

Napoleon III.Entry Details: Charles Louis Napoleon Bonaparte, 1808-73, known as Louis Napoleon; Emperor of the French (1852-71); called Barbiche because of his goatee.

Nascita, La.Entry Details: (It) the birth; reference to the Birth of Venus by Sandro BOTTICELLI.

natae praelibati margaritae/Ill D. Nicol.Entry Details: (L) Margaret, daughter of the afore-named illustrious Lord Niccolò, Marquis of ESTE, and his wife.

naturans.Entry Details: (L) in accord with nature, natural action.

Nauphal.Entry Details: Néaufles-Saint-Martin, district of Normandy, location of an important fortress in the Middle Ages.

Nausikaa.Entry Details: Nausicaa, daughter of the Phaeacian king, Alci- nous, in Odyssey (VI), Odysseus approaches her as she is playing ball on the beach, just after she had finished washing the household linen.

nautilis biancastra..Entry Details: prob. (It), nautilo biancastro: a white-colored shell, poss. that in BOTTICELLI's painting of Venus.

Navighero.Entry Details: prob. Andrea Navagero, 1483-1529, Venetian poet and epigrammatist; poss. a reference to the work Navgervis, Sive de Poetica Dialogus by Girolamo FRACASTOR.

Navy Board.Entry Details: Navy Board of the Eastern Department, the American Continental Navy board of direction; established in Boston (1777) upon the recommendation of John ADAMS.

Naxos.Entry Details: largest island of the Cyclades, in the Aegean Sea; the island was once a center for the worship of DIONYSUS.

nec benecomata.Entry Details: (L) or fair-tressed. (See. Andreas Divus, trans., Odyssey, XI).

nec ivi in harum.Entry Details: (L) nor went I to the pigsty/ Nor into the pigsty did I enter. (See: AC EGO IN HARUM).

Necker.Entry Details: Jacques, 1732-1804, French statesman; minister of finance (1776-81), director-general of finance (1788-90).

nec lupo committere agnum.Entry Details: (L) nor entrust a lamb to a wolf. (See: John Adams, Works, IX, 571).

Nec Spe Nec Metu.Entry Details: (L) With neither hope nor fear. (The motto was in the rooms of Isabella d'Este in the Ducal Palace, Mantua).

Nedham.Entry Details: Marchamont, 1620-78, English political writer; author of The Case of the Commonwealth of England Stated (1650).

Negus, the.Entry Details: title of the sovereign of Ethiopia, see HAILE SELASSIE.

Nekuia.Entry Details: (Gr) The Evocation of the Dead, name of the Eleventh book of the Odyssey. (See: Appendix A).

nel clivo ed al triedro.Entry Details: (It) in the slope and at the corner.

Nel fuoco/ D'amore mi mise, nel fuoco d'.Entry Details: (It) In the fire/ of love he put me, in the fire of love he put me. (See: St. Francis of Assisi, Cantico Secondo, where text reads: In foco amor mi mise).

Nelson, Colonel.Entry Details: Thomas, 1738-89, American Revolutionary patriot, colonel in the 2nd Regiment of Virginia, member of the Continental Congress (1775-77), signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, governor of Virginia (1781).

Nel ventre tuo, o nella mente mia.Entry Details: (It) In your belly, or in my mind.

Nemi.Entry Details: Lake Nemi, a small crater lake in the Alban Hills of Latium, Italy; here was the sacred grove and the temple of Diana, guarded by a priest who held the post until he was killed by another who sought the office. (See: Frazer, The Golden Bough).

Nenuphar.Entry Details: prob. a reference to TCHEOU-TUN one of his best known writings is a satire, veiled under the symbolism of flowers, in which the writer identifies himself with the water-lily (nenuphar), 'the Lady Virtue sans pareille.'

N.E.P..Entry Details: New Economic Policy of the U.S.S.R., instituted by LENIN in 1921.

ne povans desraciner.Entry Details: (O Fr) not being able to uproot.

Neptune.Entry Details: the Roman god of the sea.

Nerea.Entry Details: poss. reference to the Nereids, sea-maidens who were the daughters of Nereus, Homer's 'Old Man' of the sea.

[Neroni, Dietisalvi].Entry Details: d. 1482, a wealthy citizen of Florence who conspired to overthrow the Medici rule of Florence after the death of Cosimo de' MEDICI (1464). Neron, acting as financial advisor to Piero de' MEDICI, advised Piero to call in all his debts, this caused Piero to lose much of his popularity and gained for him a reputation of avarice. In 1466 Neron's plot was uncovered and he was exiled from Florence.

Nestorians.Entry Details: members of the Nestorian Church, originally the ancient church of Persia, which is related to Catholicism but not of the Catholic communion. The greatest period of Nestorian expansion was from the 7th to 10th centuries, when missions were sent to India and China; in 631 they brought Christianity into China. The famous Nestorian tablet (in Sian, SHENSI province) is a record, in Chinese and Syriac, of the progress of Christianity in China from 631 to 781, when the tablet was erected.

Nestorno, Giovan.Entry Details: Giovanni di Toma, an officer in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Neuchatel.Entry Details: a Swiss Canton, in the Jura Mountains.

Neufchastel.Entry Details: Neufchatel, town NE of Rouen, France; chief town of the Bray region.

Neville.Entry Details: Henry, 1620-94, English political writer; author of Discourses Concerning Government (1698).

Nevsky.Entry Details: the Nevsky Prospekt in St. Petersburg, at the end of the Nevsky Prospekt is the Znamenskays Place, the site of the Moscow station.

Newbolt, Sir Henry.Entry Details: Sir Henry John Newbolt, 1862-1938, the English poet.

New Discourse, the.Entry Details: prob. LOU KIA's record of his travels about the Chinese Empire when he was minister of state for Emperor KAO-HOANG-TI.

[New York State Convention].Entry Details: a convention called to amend the constitution of New York State (August-November 1821).

Ney.Entry Details: Michel, 1769-1815, French soldier in the Revolutionary and Napoleonic armies, created marshal of France (1804); commanded the Old Guard at Waterloo (1815); tried, condemned for treason and shot.

[Ngaiycou-chilitala].Entry Details: (Ai'yco Shihlitala) d. AD 1378, King of the Mongols; he was the successor of Emperor CHUNTI, who, after the Yuan dynasty fell, retreated to Korea and ruled the Mongol tribes there.

Ngan-yong.Entry Details: 54/34 Ngan-yong-tching (Ang-yung-chêng), a city in northern China.

Nice.Entry Details: city of SE France, on the Mediterranean.

Nicea.Entry Details: poss. reference to the 'Nicean barks' of Poe's poem, To Helen, therefore reference to Helen (ELEANOR of Aquitaine and HELEN of Troy).

Nicolao.Entry Details: fl. 1133, a sculptor who worked on the Duomo of Ferrara.

nihil humanum alienum.Entry Details: (L) nothing human is foreign. (See. Terence, Heauton Timorumenos, 77: Homo sum: humani nihil a me alientum puto).

Nine vases of Yu.Entry Details: the nine vases which Emperor YU had cast in bronze and engraved with a geographical description of the nine provinces of the Empire, the vases were to be found in the capital of CHOU, the principality.

Ninghia.Entry Details: (Ningsia), a province in W Inner Mongolia.

Ninkiassou.Entry Details: (Ninchiassu) (reign: 1225-34), Emperor of the KIN dynasty, his reign was one of almost continual war with the Mongols of OGOTAIKHAN.

Nipchou.Entry Details: (Nerchinsk), town in the S central Chita Region of the U.S.S.R., on the Shilka river. In 1689 the Treaty of Nerchinsk between China and Russia was signed here, the treaty required Russia to withdraw from the AMUR valley region, and served to check Russian colonization in that area to some extent.

Nismes.Entry Details: Nimes, a manufacturing and commercial city of Gard department, S France; noted for its ancient Roman buildings, among which is a Corinthian temple (the Maison Carrée) which was restored in 1789 and converted into a museum (1832).

Noah, Mordecar.Entry Details: 1785-1851, American journalist and diplomat; as U. S. consul to Tunis and special agent to Algiers (1813-15), he gained the release of Americans held prisoner by Algerian pirates; founder and editor of several New York newspapers, surveyor of the Port of New York (1829-33).

Noailles.Entry Details: a distinguished French family, head of the family during the time John ADAMS was in France was Philippe de Noailles, Duc de Mouchy (1715-94), marshal of France, guillotined in 1794.

Noel, Noel, the green holly.Entry Details: poss. variation of Shakespeare, As You Like It: 'Heigh ho! sing, heigh ho! unto the green holly.'

No hay amor sin celos/ Sin segreto no ha.Entry Details: (Sp) Sin secreto: There is no love without jealousy/ Without secrecy there is no love. (Sin Secreto No Hay Amor is a play by Lope de Vega, 1624).

Noi facciam sgannar per Mussolini.Entry Details: (It) We'd have our throats cut for MUSSOLINI.

Noigandres.Entry Details: (Pr) a term of uncertain meaning. from a song of Arnaut DANIEL, Er vei vermeills, vertz, blaus, blancs, gruocs; the last line of the first strophe ends with the following: 'E jois le grans, e l'olors d'enoi gandres.' (See: Lavaud, Les Poesies d'Arnaut Daniel, (1910) 81, for a note on the meaning of gandres).

Nollet, J..Entry Details: Jacobus, fl. 1780, an official of the city of SCHIEDAM, Holland.

noman.Entry Details: the name Odysseus assumes when with the Cyclops. (See: Odyssey, IX, 336).

non è una hontrada è un homplesso.Entry Details: (It: Tuscan dialect) non è una contrada è un complesso it is not a country, it's a complex.

non intendeva di quella materia.Entry Details: (It) he did not understand such matter.

non vi sed saepe legendo.Entry Details: (L) not by violence but by frequent reading. (See: John Adams, Works, II, 248).

[Norman, Montagu Collet].Entry Details: 1st Baron Norman of St. Clere, 1871-1950, English financier; governor of the Bank of England (1920-44).

Nor seeks the carmine petal to infer/ No.Entry Details: variation of Tennyson, a song from The Princess: Now sleeps the crimson petal, now the white.

[North, Frederick].Entry Details: 2nd Earl of Guilford, 1732-92, English statesman; prime minister under George III (1770-82). As prime minister, North made himself the agent of the king's plans to control the American colonies, supported the STAMP ACT and the tax on tea.

North, the.Entry Details: in general, that part of the U. S. north of the MASON-DIXON line and the Ohio River.

Northwestern railway.Entry Details: pseudonym for the Northern Pacific Railroad, an American railway system from Duluth and St. Paul, Minnesota, to Seattle, Washington, and Portland, Oregon, chartered by special act of Congress (1864); construction began (1870) and the railway was opened in 1883. Of the land granted by the U. S. government for the construction of the Northern Pacific, over 2,500,000 undistributed acres were still held by the company in 1948.

Notes for Princesses.Entry Details: a work on the lives of the princesses of the Chinese Empire before the time of TCHANG-SUN-CHI (d. AD 636), its author.

Notes on Conduct.Entry Details: a treatise, consisting of twelve sections, on 'How a king should conduct himself,' written by Emperor TAI-TSONG (AD 649) for his son.

Notre dame de Clery.Entry Details: the church of Our Lady in Clery, a town in Loiret department, SW of Orléans.

Nous.Entry Details: (Gr) mind, sense, wit; purpose, reason, intellect. (See Appendix A).

Nous sommes en attendant charmés de voir.Entry Details: (Fr) Meanwhile we are delighted to see / that the states of the other provinces and consequently the / entire republic have, following the example of the States of FRIESLAND/ recognized / (signed) the members of the SOCIÉTÉ BOURGEOISE. (See John Adams, Works, VIII, 56).

Novanglus.Entry Details: John ADAMS used the pen name 'Novanglus' [i.e. New Englander] to sign a series of articles (BOSTON GAZETTE, 1774-75) in which he sought to demonstrate that the laws of England could not be made to apply to the American colonies, the articles were an answer to a series of loyalist papers by Daniel Leonard (Massachusetts Gazette and Post Boy, 1774-75), who signed himself 'Massachusettensis.'

nox animae magna.Entry Details: (L) the soul's great night. (See: St. John of the Cross, Dark Night of the Soul).

Nutché.Entry Details: (Nü-chên), a Tartar tribe, formerly of north Korea near the head waters of the Yalu River. They were long dominated by the KHITAN Tartars, but in AD 1114 they defeated the Khitan; their chieftain, AKOUTA, proclaimed the KIN dynasty of the Nutché Tartars.

Oberon.Entry Details: the narrative poem by C. M. Wieland (1780).

Ob pecuniae scars (c)itatem.Entry Details: (L) on account of scarcity of money.

O'Brien.Entry Details: Lewis, fl. 1780, an Irishman whom John ADAMS met in Spain.

Obsta principils.Entry Details: (L) resist the beginnings. (See. Ovid, Remed. Amor, 91).

Ocean.Entry Details: Oceanus, in early Greek cosmology the river that encircled the plain of the earth.

Odes, the.Entry Details: the Book of Odes, or SHIH CHING.

Odyssey.Entry Details: the Homeric epic of the wanderings of ODYSSEUS.

Oedipus.Entry Details: Greek hero who inadvertently murdered his father and married his mother, the story is told in Sophocles' Oedipus Rex.

Oedipus of the Lagunes.Entry Details: prob. a Venetian publication of D'ANNUNZIO caricatures.

OEuvre de M. le Duc de Vauguyon.Entry Details: text should read ouvrage (See John Adams, Works, III, 285) (Fr) the work of the Duke of VAUGUYON.

Offa.Entry Details: Offa II, ruler of Mercia (757-796), one of the best and most powerful of the Anglo-Saxon kings.

of the two usuries, the lesser.Entry Details: now put down: variation of Shakespeare, Measure for Measure, III, II, 7: 'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, the merriest was put down and the worser allowed by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm.

of the Wabash cannon ball.Entry Details: from a popular American song, The Wabash Cannon Ball.

Ogni Santi.Entry Details: a canal in Venice; Pound lived in Venice (1908) near the conjunction of the San Trovaso and Ogni Santi canals.

Ogotar.Entry Details: Ogotai Khan, 1185-1241, second Khan of the Mongols, succeeding GENGHIS KHAN in 1228. With the help of his minister, YELIU-TCHUTSAI, he gave to the Mongols and the people they conquered a regular administration, taxation, and criminal jurisprudence.
