In 1236 he issued paper money and started a system of regular governmental examinations. He campaigned in Korea, China, and Central Asia and managed to extinguish the KIN Tartars in 1234.

Ohio canal.Entry Details: see CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO CANAL CO.

o-hon dit que'ke fois au vi'age....Entry Details: (Fr: imitation of colloquial language) it is sometimes said in the village/ that a helmet has no use/ none at all/ It is good only to give courage/ to those who don't have any at all.

Oh to be in England now that Winston's o.Entry Details: variation on Browning, Home Thoughts from Abroad.

Oklahoma City.Entry Details: capital of the state of Oklahoma.

Old Dynasty.Entry Details: poss. the TCHEOU dynasty of China.

Old Worker's Hill.Entry Details: the Shen Nung Tan ("Altar dedicated to Shen Nung," the mythical emperor of China who invented the plow). Commonly known as the Temple of Agriculture, situated in Peiping directly across from the Tien Tan, or "Altar of Heaven." In 1726, Emperor YONG-TCHING revived the ancient rites connected with the Altar of Agriculture.

Oleron.Entry Details: Ile d'Oléron, an island in the Bay of Biscay, noted for its Laws of Oleron, a medieval code of maritime laws which forms the basis of modern maritime law.

Oliver (2).Entry Details: Andrew, 1706-44, secretary and lieutenant-governor of Massachusetts Colony (1756-71); stamp officer for the STAMP ACT in Massachusetts. Oliver advocated the dispatch of British troops to America and the prosecution of Samuel ADAMS for his political agitation.

Oliver (3).Entry Details: Peter, 1713-91, a Massachusetts loyalist. As chief justice of Massachusetts Colony (1771-76) Oliver agreed to accept special monetary grants from the English Crown to the Massachusetts judiciary, and this action prompted the legislature to impeach him, however, Governor Thomas HUTCHINSON blocked the proceedings. In 1774 several Massachusetts grand juries refused to serve under Oliver because of his loyalist sympathies.

Olivet.Entry Details: the Mount of Olives, east of Jerusalem.

olofans, 1'.Entry Details: Olifant, Roland's horn. (See: The Song of Roland).

Oltrepassimo.Entry Details: prob. pseudonym for Prince Filippo-Massimiliano Massimo, 1843-1915, created first Prince Lancellotti (1865) by PIUS IX; from his half-brother, Prince Camillo-Carlo-Alberto Massimo, he purchased the DISCOBOLUS.

omnia, quae sunt, lumina sunt.Entry Details: (L) everything that exists is light. (Possibly suggested by Grosseteste, De luce seu de inchoatione formarum, ed. Baur, 57, where text reads omnia esse unum ab unis lucis perfectione ea, quae sunt multa, esse multa ab ipsius lucis diversa multiplicatione).

Ongla, oncle.Entry Details: (Pr) Nail, uncle. (See: Arnaut Daniel, Loferm voler qu'el cor m'intra).

Ohis.Entry Details: Don Luis de, Spanish minister at Washington in 1819; negotiated the treaty between the US and Spain which gave Florida to the US. When Spain ratified the treaty (1821) there was much popular sentiment against Spain in America.

Orage.Entry Details: Alfred Richard, 1873-1934, English journalist, editor of the New Age.

Oranienbaum.Entry Details: town in the Leningrad Region of Soviet Russia, was an imperial residence 1727-1914.

Ora vela, ora a remi, sino ad ora di ves.Entry Details: (It) Now sailing, now rowing, until the (hour of) sunset. (Possibly from Luchino dal CAMPO).

Orbe.Entry Details: town in Vaud Canton, W. Switzerland, on the Orbe River.

Orbem bellis, urbem gabellis, Urbanus oc.Entry Details: (L) URBAN VIII filled the world with wars, the city with taxes.

Orbetello.Entry Details: town of Grosseto province in Tuscany.

oricalchi.Entry Details: (L) of copper. (See: Homeric Hymn VI To Aphrodite, 9).

Orleans.Entry Details: town of the Loiret department, Ncentral France.

ormoulu.Entry Details: ormolu, brass made to imitate gold.

Orsini.Entry Details: Count Aldobrando Orsini, fl. 1440, Signore of Pitigliano.

Ortes.Entry Details: Ortos (Ordos) a Tartar tribe occupying the territory of Ordos, a desert region south of the Hwang Ho in Suryuan province, central Inner Mongolia.

O se credesse.Entry Details: (It) or if he would believe. (See: Varchi, Storia Fiorentino, III, 262).

O se morisse, credesse caduto da sè.Entry Details: (It) or if he would die, believed fallen by himself. (See Varchi, Storia Fiorentino, III, 262: o che egli non morisse non si credesse lui esser caduto da se.

Ostend.Entry Details: port city of W Flanders province, N Belgium.

ostendit incitatque. Vir autem.Entry Details: see DE LIBRO CHI-KING SIC CENSO

Oswald.Entry Details: Richard, 1705-84, English statesman. In 1782 he was given authority to make peace with the American colonies at the Paris peace negotiations, however, he did not sign the definitive Treaty of Versailles (3 September 1783).

O sweet and lovely/ o Lady be good..Entry Details: from the song by George Gershwin, Oh, Lady Be Good.

oth fugol outbaer.Entry Details: the line should read SUMNE FUGOL OTHBAER.

Otis.Entry Details: Samuel Allyne, 1740-1814, American statesman, member of the Constitutional Convention (1784), Secretary of the U. S. Senate (1789-1814).

Otis, James.Entry Details: 1725-83, American lawyer and patriot, advocate general of Boston (1756-61) but resigned in protest against the issuing of writs of assistance, head of the Massachusetts Committee of Correspondence (1764), opposed the STAMP ACT and organized the Stamp Congress (1765); also wrote on Latin and Greek prosody.

Otreus, King.Entry Details: legendary king of Phrygia, when APHRODITE lay with ANCHISES, she told him that her father was King Otreus, for she wished to keep her identity a secret. (See. Homeric Hymn V to Aphrodite, lllff).

O troubled reflection/ O Throat, O throb.Entry Details: from Whitman, Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking.

Ou (2).Entry Details: (Wu) one of the THREE KINGDOMS; the kingdom of Wu controlled the territory south of the Yangtze.

Qua-chi.Entry Details: (Wa Shih) fl. AD 1559, a princess of Kwangsi province; she led Chinese troops against Japanese pirates that were attacking the southeast coast of China.

Ouang Chi (1).Entry Details: (Wang Shih) fl. AD 15, he and his five brothers were of the family of Wang Mang, the Usurper (reign 9-23).

Ouang Chi (2).Entry Details: (Wang Shih) d. AD 1297, wife of KANOUEN, commander of Tchang-tcheou. Rather than become the wife of TCHIN-TIAO-YEN, the murderer of her husband, Ouang Chi leapt into the funeral pyre of Kanouen. Emperor TIMOUR was much impressed by the deed and built a memorial for her.

Ouangchin.Entry Details: (Wang Shen) fl. AD 1403, a Buddhist priest serving in the temple of Chin-lo-koan, outside the city of Nanking.

Ouang-mi.Entry Details: (Wang Mi) fl. AD 107, a mandarin who attempted to bribe YANG-TCHIN.

Ouang-Ngan-ché.Entry Details: (Wang An-shih) 1021-86, became confidential advisor and minister of state to Emperor CHIN-TSONG (1069). He and the emperor began reforms based on Ouang's new and "more correct" interpretations of the Classics. state administration of commerce, state support for farmers, compulsory military service, a state system of barter, a new land tax system. In the face of much opposition, the emperor put Ouang's reforms into practice, but Ouang tried to move too rapidly and lived to see all his reforms abolished. After his death he was disgraced and his tablet removed from the Confucian Temple.

Ouang-po.Entry Details: (Wang Po) d. AD 959, a statesman, mathematician, and personal counselor to Emperor CHI-TSONG.

Ouang Siaopo.Entry Details: (Wang Hsiao-po) fl. AD 993, a man of the people who roused Szechwan province to revolt against their governor in 993. There was little money in the province, since the conquering SUNG troops had carried it away a few years before; the mandarins were fleecing the people, the rich were buying up small farms and depriving the poor of land and food. Imperial troops soon put down the rebellion, and Emperor TAI-TSONG appointed a governor who improved the condition of the poor.

Ouang-siun.Entry Details: (Wang Hsün) fl. AD 280, a general serving Emperor TCIN-OU-TI; engaged in campaigns against the kingdom of Wu, one of the THREE KINGDOMS.

Ouang tchi.Entry Details: Ouang-tchu (Wang Chu) d. AD 1282, chief officer of the city of Peiping. He led the conspiracy to assassinate AHAMA, the chief minister of KUBLAI KHAN; Ouang-tchu lured Ahama to the palace late at night and killed him with an iron mace. Kublai had Ouang executed.

[Ouang-tsai-gin].Entry Details: (Wang Tsai-Jen) d. AD 847, favorite concubine of Emperor OU-TSONG.

[Ouang-tsiuen-pin].Entry Details: (Wang Chuon-pin) fl. AD 965, a general serving Emperor TCHAO-KOUANG; he was in charge of the expedition which succeeded in overcoming the HEOU-CHOU.

Ouang Yeou.Entry Details: (Wang Yeou) fl. AD 9 21, a rebel commander of the troops of LI-TSUN-HIU, Prince of Tein, he invited the Khitan Tartars to attack some cities of China, which they did.

Quan Li.Entry Details: (Wan Li), title of the reign of Emperor CHIN-TSONG.

Quan-soui!.Entry Details: (Ch) (Wan-sui). Ten thousand years. (One of the forms of address to the Emperor of China).

Quantse.Entry Details: prob. Ouantçe (Wan Tzu) fl. AD 1291, one of KUBLAI KHAN's ministers of state.

Ouanyen.Entry Details: (Wan-yen), family name of the rulers of the KIN dynasty of the NUTCHÉ Tartars.

Quei.Entry Details: (Wei), a principality in the general region of the modern Sian, a city of SHENSI province, NE central China, on the We river where it joins the Hwang Ho.

Ouei-Kao.Entry Details: (Wei Kao) d. AD 805, a general of the imperial troops who won significant victories over the Tartars. As governor of a province for 21 years he gained more fame, for during that time the people of his province paid exactly the tax demanded by the emperor from the province-- and no more.

Ouei-Lie.Entry Details: Ouei-lié-ouang (Wei-Lieh Wang) (reign: 425-401), during the reign of this emperor nothing much happened, except that the tripods of YU began making noises- which meant that the end of the TCHEOU dynasty was near.

Ouei-Tching.Entry Details: (We Cheng) d. AD 643, an astute minister of Emperor TAI-TSONG.

Ouen (3).Entry Details: Ouen-knang-hien (Wên-chiang-hsien), a town in SZECHWAN province.

Ouen Kong.Entry Details: (Wên Kung) d. BC 609, Prince of LOU; a benevolent and capable ruler.

Ouen ti.Entry Details: (Wen Ti) (reign: 424-453). In spite of the opposition of the state of OUEI, he extended the power of the emperor over much territory. He was fond of literature and the arts and paid attention to education by establishing national colleges.

Ouen-ti (2).Entry Details: (Wen ti) (reign: 581-605), first emperor of the Sui dynasty (589-618). He commanded that no man should be put to death before his case had been reported three times; however, this led to great government corruption, for it gave a wide margin of safety to corrupt mandarins Because the emperor was uneducated, he had great contempt for scholars and classical education, he preferred simple and direct language to the rhetoric of the Classics.

Ouen Tiensiang.Entry Details: (Wên T'ien-hsiang) 1236-83, one of the most patriotic men in Chinese history; he served the last five emperors of the Southern SUNG dynasty as minister and general. All his efforts to stem the Mongol invasions and preserve the dynasty failed, and when the dynasty fell he was taken prisoner (1279). Because he would not pledge his loyalty to the Mongols, he was executed by KUBLAI KHAN.

Ouen-Tsong.Entry Details: (Wen Tsung) (reign: 827-41). He began his reign by cutting government expenditures, dismissing three thousand women from the royal harem, and giving audiences to his ministers every other day; but he lacked firmness of purpose, and soon the power of the court was usurped by the eunuchs. At this time the eunuchs became a national danger, but all efforts to get rid of them failed.

Ouen yan Tchin hochang.Entry Details: Ouanyen-tchin-ho-chang (Wan-yen Chen Ho-shang) d. AD 1232, prince royal of the KIN dynasty and an officer of the Kin troops during the battles between the Kin and the Mongols.

Ou-heou.Entry Details: (Wu Hou) 625-705, one of the concubines of Emperor TAI TSONG, after his death she became the empress of KAO-TSONG in 656, and for the next forty years she was one of the most important figures in Chinese political history. Cruel and unscrupulous, she controlled two emperors and became virtual ruler of the Empire. She forced her husband to make her co-ruler (they were known as 'The Two Holy Ones') and finally took over all his power. During the years 684-705 her son TCHONG-TSONG was nominally the emperor, but the period is often known as the reign of Empress Ou-heou.

Ou-Kiar.Entry Details: (Wu Ch'ieh) fl. AD 1135, a captain of the imperial troops who served Emperor Kao Tsung (reign. 1127-63).

Ousan.Entry Details: Ou-san-kouei (Wu San-kuel) d. AD 1678, a commander of the imperial forces during the last years of the MING dynasty. In 1643 Ou-san-kouei received news that Peiping had fallen to the rebel LI-TSE-TCHING and that the emperor had committed suicide, after making conditions about the treatment of the Chinese, Ou-san gave his allegiance to the Manchus. As a result, the Manchus captured Peiping and established their dynasty over China.

où sont les heurs.Entry Details: (Fr) where are the (O Fr) good times. (Variation of Villon: Où sont les neiges d'antan).

Ou-tchao.Entry Details: Ou-tchao-y (Wu Chao-1) fl. AD 953, wishing to start a college, he requested permission of the Prince of Chou to have the SHU CHING and the SHIH CHING printed (953), the permission was granted.

Ou Ti (1).Entry Details: (Wu Ti) (reign: 483-94), he paid attention to the laws of the kingdom and cut down the number of retainers at court; however, while he worried about rebellion within the Empire, he forgot to consider the threat of the rising power of the kingdom of OUEI.

Ou Ti (2).Entry Details: (Wu Ti) (reign: 503-50) founder of the LIANG dynasty; a good emperor who helped his people during famine and purged the court of corruption. He became a Buddhist and imported three thousand Buddhist priests to the capital; during his reign more than thirteen thousand Buddhist temples were built in the Empire. In 528 Ou-ti became a Buddhist monk, but soon his ministers asked him to attend to the business of the Empire, and he was absolved of his vows.

Outline of the Historical View of the Pr.Entry Details: Esquisse d'un tableau historique des progrès de l'esprit humain (1801-04) by CONDORCET, in which he traces the human development through nine epochs to the French Revolution and predicts that the tenth epoch will be the ultimate perfection of man.

Ou-Tsong.Entry Details: (Wu Tsung) (reign: 841-47). His one important decree was that all Taoist and Buddhist priests and nuns in the Empire should return to their homes and stop living in idleness and immorality.

Ou Tsong.Entry Details: (Wu Tsung) (reign 1506-1521), a weak and childish emperor, after he had been persuaded to execute the eunuch LIEOU-KIN, he chose KIANG-PING, a military adventurer, as his chief advisor. Ou-tsong came to the throne as a minor, but as he grew older he did not grow wiser. He devoted himself to leisure and frivolity and left no heir.

Ou-yen.Entry Details: prob. a confusion of Ou-han (Wu Han) and Kou-yen (Ku Yen), both fl. AD 26, and both were Chinese generals who were created Princes of the Empire, they were especially successful in the wars against the brigands. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, III, 285).

Overyssel.Entry Details: Overijssel, a province in E Netherlands.

O Voi che siete in piccioletta barca..Entry Details: (It) oh you who are on a very small boat. (See: Paradiso, 2, 1).

O woman shapely as a swan.Entry Details: from Padraic Colum, I Shall Not Die for Thee in Collected Poems, 134.

Paddock.Entry Details: Adino, a Boston coachmaker who was John ADAMS' captain when Adams served in the Boston civilian night watch just after the Boston Massacre (5 March 1770).

Paichen.Entry Details: - Sina-pacheng (Hsina-plaishêng), prob. the modern city of Sining (or Hsining) in Tsinghai province, W central China.

Paine, Robert.Entry Details: - Robert Treat Paine, 1731-1814, American jurist, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-78) and signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, judge of the Massachusetts supreme court (1790-1804).

Palace of the Doges.Entry Details: in the Piazza di San Marco, Venice.

[ Palaeologus, John].Entry Details: 1391-1448, John VIII, ruler of the Eastern Roman Empire (1425-1448); to obtain western aid against the Turks he appeared at the Councils of Ferrara and Florence (1438-39).

Palgrave.Entry Details: Francis Turner, 1824-97, English poet and critic, professor of poetry at Oxford (1885-95); edited the poetry anthology Golden Treasury of the best Songs and Lyrical Poems in the English Language (1861, 1897).

Palio, the.Entry Details: - the horseraces held in Siena twice a year: on the festivals of Our Lady's Visitation (July 2) and of her Assumption (August 15), the race course is three times around the Campo, and in the race there is one horse representing each contrade, rival social groups which come from different districts of Siena.

Palla, Lunarda da.Entry Details: fl. 1454, prob. tutor and secretary of Sallustio MALATESTA, Sigismondo's son.

Palladio.Entry Details: - Andrea, 1518-80, Italian architect who adopted the principles of Roman architecture to the requirements of the Renaissance; his works include the SAN GIORGIO MAGGIORE and the Capuchin churches in Venice. English architects of the Georgian period developed the designs called "Palladian."

Palmer.Entry Details: Joseph, 1718-88, American soldier; as a colonel of the Colonal militia he participated in the defense of the coast near Boston, in 1777 appointed brigadier-general and given command of the Massachusetts militia defending Rhode Island.

Palmerston, Lord.Entry Details: Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston, 1784-1865, the English statesman; prime minister (1855-58; 1859-65).

Palux Laerna.Entry Details: Palus Lernae, the swamp of Lerna where Hercules killed the Hydra, the poisonous snake. (See: Propertius, II, XXVI, 48).

Pandone, Parcelio.Entry Details: 1405-85, Italian poet of the court of Naples; served Sigismondo MALATESTA at Rimini (1456) and wrote De amore Iovis in Isottam. (See: Basinio da PARMA).

Panisks.Entry Details: minor gods of the forest, half-man, half-goat, from (Gr) Paniskos, dim. of PAN.

Pao Sse.Entry Details: (Pao Ssu) C. 8th century BC, concubine of Emperor YEOU OUANG, earthquakes preceded her coming to the throne, and the great eclipse of the sun on 29 August 775 followed it. She enslaved the emperor and incited him to the wildest acts of folly.

Paphos.Entry Details: town on the SW coast of Cyprus; famous as a place of the worship of APHRODITE.

Paradiso.Entry Details: the third section of Dante's Divina Commedia.

Paris (2).Entry Details: the son of Priam, King of Troy; stole HELEN of Troy from her husband, Menelaus.

Parliament.Entry Details: the legislative body of Great Britain.

[Parma, Basinio da].Entry Details: Basinio de Basinii, ?1425-57, poet and humanist of Rimini; born in Parma, he was a noted student of Greek; engaged in a famous literary debate with Parcelio PANDONE on the values of Greek studies.

Paschi di detta Città.Entry Details: (It) Bank of ever mentioned city. (See: MONTE DEI PASCHI).

Pasepa.Entry Details: fl. AD 1269, a Lama who provided the Mongols with an alphabet; in gratitude, KUBLAI KHAN raised him to the rank of head Lama.

Pasiphae.Entry Details: wife of Minos, King of Crete; sister of CIRCE and mother of the Minotaur.

Passy.Entry Details: in the 18th century a village to the NW of Paris, in which the American delegation (FRANKLIN, DEANE, and Arthur LEE) stayed; now a fashionable section of Paris.

Pasti.Entry Details: Matteo de', d. 1468, Veronese sculptor and medalist; sent by Sigismondo MALATESTA to Candia to make a portrait of the Turkish emperor, MOHAMMED II, he was arrested by the Venetians, who suspected him of being in league with the Turks against them. He was released, however, and returned to Rimini.

\"Past runn'd Latium '\".Entry Details: variation of W. S. Landor, Pastruined Ilion Helen lives.

Patchin.Entry Details: Patchin Place, a court off Sixth Avenue, Greenwich Village, New York.

Paterson.Entry Details: William, 1658-1719, British financier, chief founder of the BANK OF ENGLAND (1694).

Paucity, Mt.Entry Details: a desolate range of mountains in Manchuria, called by the Chinese the "Mountains of Poverty."

Paul, St..Entry Details: d.c 67, the Christian apostle, missionary and martyr.

Pavia.Entry Details: capital of Pavia province of Lombardy, N Italy, the Church of San Michele in Pavia is an excellent example of 12th century Lombard Romanesque architecture.

Paxton.Entry Details: Charles, 1704-1788, British commissioner of customs at Boston and head of the Board of Commissioners; left America in 1776.

Pa Yang.Entry Details: Pan-yang, poss. the city of P'ing-yang in Shansi province. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IX, 485).

Pe.Entry Details: Pé-koan, (P'e-k'ou) the North Pass which lies to the north of NAN-KOAN; also the tribe of NUTCHÉ Tartars which takes its name from the region of the pass.

Peabody.Entry Details: George, 1795-1869, American financier and philanthropist; in 1835 he negotiated a loan from the British to save the finances of Maryland; became a London broker in 1837 and did much to promote Anglo-American relations.

[Pearse, Patrick Henry].Entry Details: 1879-1916, Irish author and Sinn Fein leader, commander in chief of the Irish forces in the Easter Rebellion (1916), executed after surrendering his troops.

[Pedro I].Entry Details: 1320-1367, King of Portugal (1357-67); son of Alfonso IV and "husband" of Ignez da CASTRO.

Pei-kiu.Entry Details: (Pei Chü) fl. AD 607, he was sent by Emperor YANG-TI to be governor in SI-YU and turned his journey to good account by mapping the country.

[Peiping].Entry Details: (formerly Peking), the city in Hopeh province, NE China; capital of China during the YUAN and subsequent dynasties.

Pé-kin.Entry Details: (Pe Chin) d. BC 1063, ruler of the principality of LOU.

Pellegrini..Entry Details: Giampietro Domenico, under-secretary in the Italian Ministry of Finance (1943); appointed Minister of Finance (20 September 1943) in the government of the SALÖ Republic, official in the Consigliere Nazionale and the Corporazione della Previdenza e del Credito.

Peloponnesus.Entry Details: the south part of the mainland of Greece; also called MOREA.

pence of Peter.Entry Details: Peter's Pence, a hearth tax of one penny to support the Papacy.

Penn, John.Entry Details: ?1741-88, American Revolutionary leader; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1775-80) and a signer of the DECLARATION of Independence.

[Pennabill]].Entry Details: a town in the Apennines, SW of Rimini, between Mt. CARPEGNA and the Marecchia river; home of Giovanni MALATESTA.

Penthesilea.Entry Details: queen of the Amazons, she and her followers came to the and of Troy after the death of Hector.

Pentheus.Entry Details: grandson of CADMUS and King of Thebes; when DIONYSUS returned to Thebes, Pentheus denied his divinity and refused to worship him; advised by a stranger (the god in disguise) to spy on the woman worshippers, he was torn to pieces by them when discovered. (See Ovid, Metamorphoses, III, 511-733).

Perdicaris.Entry Details: Ion, an American who was kidnapped (1904) by the Moroccan brigand RAIS ULI, the affair gave rise to the slogan in America: "Perdicaris alive or Raisuli dead."

Péreira.Entry Details: Antoine Péreyra, fl. 1689, a Jesuit missionary in China, he served with GERBILLON on the commission to negotiate a treaty between China and Russia (1689).

Pergusa.Entry Details: Pergus, a lake in Sicily near the city of Enna, near the lake PERSEPHONE was seized by Pluto and carried off. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, V, 386).

Périgueux.Entry Details: capital of Dordogne department, SW France; the historical capital of Périgord.

Perimedes.Entry Details: member of the crew of ODYSSEUS. (See: Odyssey, XI, 23).

Perkeo.Entry Details: fl. 1720, fool in the court of Karl Philip, Perkeo's tub is the Great Vat of Heidelberg, which according to Scheffel's song was emptied by Perkeo alone, a wooden figure of Perkeo stands on the wall of the vat room.

per l'argine sinistra dienno volta.Entry Details: (It) would turn to the left side. (See: Inferno, 21, 136).

per legem terrae.Entry Details: (L) by the law of the land.

per pares et legem terrae.Entry Details: (L) by peers and the law of the land. (See: John Adams, Works, III, 471-72).

Perpetua.Entry Details: St. Perpetua, d. 203, a Carthaginian martyr.

Perseis.Entry Details: or Perse, mother of CIRCE and PASIPHAE.

Persephone.Entry Details: the daughter of ZEUS and DEMETER, she was carried off to the lower world by Hades, but was allowed to return to the world in the spring and summer.

Perugia.Entry Details: city in central Italy, capital of Umbria; site of an excellent 14th century cathedral and a fountain with sculptures by Nicolò and Giovanni Pisano.

Pèsaro.Entry Details: port city and capital of Pesaro e Urbino province in central Italy; it was held by the Malatesta's in the 13th century, then by the Sforza, and then by the dukes of Urbino until 1631, when it passed to the Holy See.

Pétain.Entry Details: Henri Philippe, 1856-1951, marshal of France; convicted of "intelligence with the enemy" (1945) and sentenced to life imprisonment; during the First World War he saved France by halting the Germans at Verdun (1916).

Petano.Entry Details: poss. Coltano, near Pisa, location of the DTC, 1945.

Peter I.Entry Details: Peter the Great, 1672-1725; emperor (1721-25) and tsar (1682-1725) of Russia; founder of the modern Russian state.

Petty, Sir William.Entry Details: 2nd Earl of Shelbourne, 1st Marquis of Lansdowne, 1737-1805, English statesman; secretary of state under Pitt (1766-68), attempted conciliation toward the American colonies; first lord of the treasury and prime minister (1782-83); conceded American independence.

Pe-y.Entry Details: (Pe I), the ancestral house of FEI-TSEI, who became Prince of TSIN and founder of the house which was to become the TSIN dynasty.

Peyan.Entry Details: Poyang Hu, a lake in N Kiangsi province, SE China; China's second largest lake, into which flows the HAN river.

Peyen.Entry Details: Péyen-témour (P'eyen Temur) d. AD 1362, King of the Koreans.

Péyen.Entry Details: Péyen-tiémour (P'eyen T'iehmur) fl. AD 1450, a Mongol general who took charge of the captured Emperor YNG-TSONG; he also participated in the Mongol attack on Peiping (1450).

Phaebidas.Entry Details: Phoebidas, a Spartan commander, who seized the stronghold of Thebes in Boeotia (382 BC). (See: John Adams, Works, IV, 286).

Phaethusa.Entry Details: a daughter of HELIOS. (See: Odyssey, XII, 132).

Pharamond.Entry Details: C. 5th century BC, legendary king of the Saline Franks; supposedly he published the code of the Salic laws, which included penal and civil laws.

Pharisees.Entry Details: one of the two great Jewish religious parties that arose in the synagogue; they insisted on strict adherence to the laws of the Jewish religion, both the Written and the Oral Law. The other party, the Sadducees, accepted only the teaching of the Torah.

Philadelphia.Entry Details: the city of Pennsylvania; meeting place of the First CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774), Second Continental Congress (1775-76; 1777; 1778-89), Constitutional Convention (1787); served as capital of the US (1790-1800).

Philiasia.Entry Details: Phliasia, the territory of Phlius, a town in the north-east of the Peloponnesus.

Philip.Entry Details: Philip IV, 1605-65, King of Spain (1621-65), his portrait by VELÁSQUEZ hangs in the PRADO.

Phlegethon.Entry Details: the river of fire in Hades.

Phoenician cities.Entry Details: the cities on the Atlantic coast of Africa which were founded by HANNO: KARIKON, GUTTA, AKRA, MELI, ARAMBO.

Phrygia.Entry Details: ancient country in W central Asia Minor.

phtheggometha/thasson.Entry Details: (Gr) let us raise our voices without delay. (See: Appendix A).

Piacenza.Entry Details: town in the region of Veneto, N Italy.

Piazza (2).Entry Details: prob. the Piazza di San Marco, Venice.

Piazza Chapel.Entry Details: (It) Chapel Square. (The Piazza del Duomo, Siena).

Piccinino, Giacomo.Entry Details: d. 1465, son of Niccolò PICCINI- NO; an Italian condottiere, connected by marriage with Francesco SFORZA; murdered at Naples.

Piccinino.Entry Details: Niccolò, 1375-1444, Italian condottiere serving Fillippo Maria VISCONTI, Duke of Milan; captured Bologna (1438) and ruled it until 1443.

Piccolomini, Aeneas Silvius..Entry Details: Enea Silvio de, 1405-64, Pope Pius II (1458-64); an author, humanist, and patron of writers; in literature he is known as Aeneas Silvius.

Piccolomin, Nicolò.Entry Details: poss. Francesco di Niccolò Piccolomini, 1520-1604, professor of philosophy at the University of Siena.

Pickering, Tim.Entry Details: Timothy, 1745-1829, American general and statesman; during the Revolution he was a member of the Board of War (1777) and quartermaster general (1780-85); Postmaster General of the US (1791-95); Secretary of War (1795) and then Secretary of State (1795-1800). John ADAMS dismissed him from his last office because Pickering's anti-French attitude was not in line with Adams' foreign policy and because of Pickering's political manipulations.

Pickthall, Marmaduke William.Entry Details: 1875-1936, English novelist living in the Near East; he was converted to Mohammedism.

Pien.Entry Details: Pien-kuan-chi (Pien Chuan-shih), a woman of the principality of SONG; CONFUCIUS married her in BC 532, but divorced her later. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 190).

Pig and Piffle.Entry Details: prob. the English magazine Sport and Country.

Pi-kan.Entry Details: (Pi Kan) 12th century BC, uncle of CHEOU-SIN, last emperor of the YIN dynasty, when Pi-kan objected to the excesses of Cheou-sin, the emperor had him disembowelled on the spot. (See: Analects, XVIII, 1).

Pilate, Pontius.Entry Details: fl. AD 33, procurator of Judea under Emperor Tiberius, tried and condemned Christ.

[Pili, Ugolini dei].Entry Details: fl. 1420, Italian soldier serving as captain under Pandolfo MALATESTA.

Pilkington, Sir J..Entry Details: Sir John, fl. 1454, the case of Sir John Pilkington (32 H. VI. 25) was one which substantiated the fact that Ireland is a dominion separate and divided from England. (See: Coke, Reports, 7, 22b).

Pillars, the..Entry Details: the Pillars of Heracles. (See: STRAIT OF GIBRALTAR).

Pinckney.Entry Details: Charles Cotesworth, 1746-1825, American statesman; sent to France on a special mission (1796-97) but because the French refused to recognize his status he was forced to leave France for Amsterdam, there he was approached by members of the French government who offered terms under which negotiations might start (the main point was the Jay Treaty), this incident became the famous XYZ Affair.

Ping Tching.Entry Details: (P'ing-ch'êng), capital of the kingdom of OUEI (376-494).

Pinyang.Entry Details: Ping-ngan (Ping-an), the modern city of Keijo (or Seoul) in Korea; served as capital of the Korean dynasty (1392-1910).

Piombino.Entry Details: town in Tuscany; ruled by the VISCONTI family.

piquée de ce badinage.Entry Details: (Fr) stung by this banter. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IV, 500).

[Pisano, Antonio]..Entry Details: ?1397-1455, Veronese painter and medalist, employed by Sigismondo MALATESTA in the building of the Tempio, patronized by Lionello d'ESTE; also known as Vittore Pisano.

Pistoja.Entry Details: Pistoia, town in N Tuscany, near Florence.

Pitro, Mr..Entry Details: a blacksmith in the service of Francesco SFORZA.

Pitt.Entry Details: William, "the Elder Pitt," 1708-1778, the English statesman, was opposed to the STAMP ACT and British taxation of the American Colonies.

Pitt..Entry Details: William, "the Younger Pitt," 1759-1806, the English statesman, prime minister (1783-1801; 1804-06).

[Pius XI].Entry Details: Achille Ambrogio Damiano Ratti, 1857-1939, Pope (1922-39), subprefect of the Vatican Library (1911-18), nuncio (1919-20), cardinal and archbishop of Milan (1921).

placet sic.Entry Details: (L) it pleases thus. (placet: an affirmative vote, yea).

Placuit oculis.Entry Details: (L) she pleased the eyes. (See: "ET AMAVA PERDUTAMENTE...").

Plan of Government.Entry Details: The Plan, the first of three sections into which Charles Francis Adams has divided John Adams' major works relating to the form of American government; the other sections are titled: The Model, The Defence. (See: John Adams, Works, IV, 185-VI, 217).

Plarr.Entry Details: Victor Gustave, 1863-1929, librarian of the Royal College of Surgeons of England; author of In The Dorian Mood (1896) and other works.

Pleiades.Entry Details: the cluster of stars in the constellation of Taurus; the seven daughters of Atlas.

Plotinus.Entry Details: ? 205-270, the Roman philosopher, a leader of the Neoplatonic school.

Plura diafana.Entry Details: (L) more things diaphanous. (See: Grosseteste, De iride seu de iride et speculo, ed. Baur, 73).

Pluto.Entry Details: a name of Hades; god of the nether world. (See: PERSEPHONE).

Poggio.Entry Details: Gian Francesco Poggio Bracciolini, 1380-1459, Italian humanist; known for his discoveries of lost Latin classics in various monasteries.

Poicebot.Entry Details: Gaubertz, a monk of Provence who became a troubadour. (See. Make It New, 25).

Potters.Entry Details: formerly spelled Poictiers; city of Vienne department W central France, site of a 12th century Romanesque Gothic cathedral and the remains of the palace of the former counts of Poitou.

[Poitiers, Guillaume].Entry Details: 1071-1127, ninth Duke of Aquitaine and seventh Count of Potters; the earliest troubadour whose songs are extant; the grandfather of ELEANOR of Aquitaine.

Pola.Entry Details: or Pulj, a fortified seaport at the S tip of the Istrian Peninsula, NW Yugoslavia; S of Trieste.

Pole, Cardinal.Entry Details: Reginald Pole, 1500-58; created cardinal by Pope Paul III (1536); opposed to the divorce and religious reforms of HENRY VIII.

Polenta..Entry Details: Ostasio da Polenta; an ally of the Venetians in 1441, he was yet deprived by them of Ravenna and exiled to Candia with his family.

Polhonac.Entry Details: Héracle III, Viscount of Polignac. His wife, Adelande de Claustra, was admired by Guillaume de Saint-Didier, who addressed love-songs to her, she agreed to accept him if so urged by her husband, whereupon Guillaume wrote the song (Dona, 1eu vos soy messatgiers) in which a husband intercedes with his wife in the interest of a rejected lover. The Viscount received the song, admired it, sang it to his wife, and thus "set the feast" for Guillaume.

Poliorcetes.Entry Details: (Gr) taker of cities; the epithet was applied to Sigismondo MALATESTA by PISANELLO.

Pollon d'anthropon iden.Entry Details: (Gr) And of many men he saw (the cities, and knew their mind). (See: Appendix A).

Polo.Entry Details: Marco, ?1254-1324?, Venetian traveler; visited KUBLAI KHAN in 1275 and returned to Venice in 1295. In 1296 he was taken prisoner by the Genoese against whom Polo, with the Venetians, was fighting; he dictated his memoirs while in prison in Genoa.

Pomona.Entry Details: the old Italian goddess of fruit trees.

Ponce.Entry Details: Juan Ponce de León, ?1460-1521, Spanish governor of Puerto Rico and discoverer of Florida, which he found while looking for the Fountain of Youth (Easter Sunday 1513).

Pondo.Entry Details: locality in central Italy; taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

Pone metum, / Metum, nec deus laedit.Entry Details: (L) Lay aside fear, / fear, nor does God harm. (See: Tibullus, III, X, 15).

Pong.Entry Details: Pong-choul-hien (Pêng-shui-hsien), a town in Szechwan province.

Pongchan.Entry Details: (Peng-shan), a district city in the province of Szechwan.

[Por, Odon].Entry Details: 1883- , Italian writer on social and economic problems and on Italian Fascism.

Portoferraio.Entry Details: seaport of Elba Island; where Napoleon lived during his exile (1814-15).

Possum ego naturae / non meminisse tuae!.Entry Details: (L) Can I forget thy nature! (See: Propertius, II, xx, 28).

Potemkin.Entry Details: Grigori Aleksandrovich, 1739-91, Russian statesman; the chief favorite of Catherine II, he was created field marshal in 1784; constructed a fleet in the Black Sea, created prince of Tauris (1787).

pouvrette et ancienne oncques lettre ne.Entry Details: (Fr) povrette et ancienne oncques lettre ne leuz. poor and old never did I read a letter. (See: Villon, Testament, "Ballade Pour Prier Nostre Dame").

[Poynings, Sir Edward].Entry Details: 1459-1521, English soldier and diplomat, as governor of Ireland, he summoned the Drogheda Parliament (1494) that enacted Poynings's law providing that every act of that parliament must be approved by the English privy council to become valid.

praemunires.Entry Details: (Law) offenses made punishable by forfeiture of property and imprisonment; also the form of writ for prosecuting such offenses.

Prataline.Entry Details: locality in central Italy, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

Prayer: hands uplifted and pities those.Entry Details: from The Fourth Satire of Dr. John Donne, versifyed by Alexander Pope; variation of Henry IV, part 2, III, i, 31.

Pré Catalan.Entry Details: a restaurant in the Bois de Boulogne, Paris.

Predappio.Entry Details: town in NE Italy, where MUSSOLINI was born.

preraphaelite.Entry Details: a society of artists formed in England in 1848 and known as the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood; the original members were Holman Hunt, John E. Millais, D. G. Rossetti, James Collinson, Thomas Woolner, Frederick George Stephens, and W. M. Rossetti.

President of Magdalen.Entry Details: prob. Sir Herbert Warren, 1853-1930, president of Magdalen College, Oxford (1885-1928).

Presqu'isle.Entry Details: Presque Isle, once a military fort in N Maine, first controlled by the British in Canada and then relinquished to the Americans; now a village.

Preston.Entry Details: Thomas, captain of the British troops involved in the Boston Massacre (1770); he was defended by John ADAMS, who obtained an acquittal.

Priapus.Entry Details: god of fertility; son of DIONYSUS and APHRODITE.

Price.Entry Details: Richard, 1723-91, Welsh moral and political philosopher; attacked the British policy toward the American Revolution in his Observations on Civil Liberty and War with America (1776); was a friend of Benjamin FRANKLIN and John ADAMS.

Primavera.Entry Details: a reference to Giovanna, the lady of Guido CAVALCANTI, to whom he addressed some of his ballate. (See: La Vita Nuova, XXIV, 20-23).

Primrose.Entry Details: one of the three principal characters in Rene CREVEL's Les Pieds dans le plat (1933), where she is Lady Primerose, marquise of Sussex.

Princes Mogul.Entry Details: the princes of the Mongolian tribes which, in AD 1635, formed a confederation under the hegemony of TAI-TSONG, the Manchu leader.

Prishnip.Entry Details: prob. Gavrilo Princip, who assassinated Francis Ferdinand at Sarajevo (28 June 1914).

Procuratio nomine patris.Entry Details: (L) procuration in the name of the father.

Programma di Verona, Il.Entry Details: the Program of Verona, the manifesto detailing the principles of action of the Fascist Republican Party, SALÖ Republic, October 1943.

Proteus.Entry Details: a sea-deity, the guardian of the herds of POSEIDON; he had knowledge of future events and would disclose this knowledge if one could catch and hold him while he changed shape.

Protot, Robert.Entry Details: prob. Robert Pinot, Secrétaire Général du COMITÉ DES FORGES in the first World War, serving under the presidency of François de WENDEL; author of Le Comité des Forges de France au service de la nation (Août 1914-Novembre 1918) published in 1919.

Province, the.Entry Details: the royal province of New York, established 1685-1776, the area of the present state of New York.

Province House.Entry Details: the official building of the Province of Friesland, the Netherlands.

Psellos.Entry Details: Michael Constantine Psellus, 1018-1105?, Byzantine philosopher, politician, writer, and early Neoplatonist.

Pujo.Entry Details: Arsène Paulin, 1861-1939, American lawyer and legislator; member of the House of Representatives (1903-13), chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency (1911-13) and head of the so-called "money trust" investigation.

Purtheo, Aloysius.Entry Details: fl. 1450, prob. Benedictine abbot of the basilica SANT APOLLINAIRE, Ravenna; he agreed, for 200 gold florins, to allow Sigismondo MALATESTA to take marble from the church and use it in the TEMPIO.

Puvis.Entry Details: Pierre Puvis de Chavannes, 1824-98, French muralist; some of his best work is in the Sorbonne and the Panthéon.

Pym, Bill.Entry Details: William, a pseudonym used by a writer on the side of the English in the London Evening Post (1765); John ADAMS answered Pym under the pseudonym of Earl CLARENDON.

Pyrenees.Entry Details: the mountain range on the French-Spanish border.

qua al triedro, / e la scalza.Entry Details: (It) here at the corner, / and the barefooted one.

Quackenbos (or Quackenbush).Entry Details: prob. a resident in a New York boarding house, C. 1890. (See. Indiscretions, in Quarterly Review of Literature, V, 2 (1949) 125).

Quade, Mons.Entry Details: an associate of Baldy BACON, for further description of Quade, see. Pavannes and Divisions, 45-46.

Quan ben m'albir e mon ric pensamen.Entry Details: (Pr) When I consider well in my courtly thought. (See: Sordello, III, 17).

quand vos venetz al som de l'escalina..Entry Details: (Pr) when you come to the top of the stair. (See Purgatorio, 26, 146: que vos guida al som de l'escalina).

Quand vous serez bien vieille..Entry Details: (Fr) When you are very old. (See: Ronsard, Sonnets pour Hélène, II, 42).

Quarterly Review.Entry Details: published (London) since 1809; the reference is to the issue for November 1829.

quasi tinnula, / Ligur' aoide. Si no'us.Entry Details: (L) as if ringing (Gr) clear, sweet song: (Pr) If I see you not, Lady with whom I am most concerned, / Not seeing you is not the reward for my fair thought. (See. Catullus, LXI, 12-13, Odyssey, XII, 183).

Que la lauzeta mover'.Entry Details: (Pr) When I see the lark on the move. (See: Bernart de Ventadorn, no. 43).

Qu'est-ce qu'on pense ? On don't pense.Entry Details:
(Fr) What do they think?
They don't think.

Que tous les mois avons nouvelle lune.Entry Details: (Fr) That every month we have a new moon.

que vos vers expriment vos intentions, /.Entry Details: (Fr) that your verses express your intentions, / and that the music conform. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, I, 93).

Qu'il fit la sottise de Moscou.Entry Details: (Fr) That he did the folly of Moscow. (See: J. Q. Adams, Diary, 104).

qu'ils veillèrent à la pureté du langage.Entry Details: (Fr) that they looked to the purity of the language/ and that one should use only suitable terms. (See. Mailla, Histoire Générale, XI, 365).

Quincy (1).Entry Details: city in E Massachusetts, 8 miles S of Boston, birthplace and home of John ADAMS and John Quincy ADAMS; earlier called MERRYMOUNT and Mt. WOLLASTON.

Quincy (2).Entry Details: prob. Edmund Quincy, 1703-88, friend of John ADAMS, father-in-law of John HANCOCK and Jonathan Sewall. (See: Adams, Works, II, 81).

Quincy (3).Entry Details: Josiah, Jr. , 1744-75, American lawyer, with John ADAMS he served as counsel for Captain PRESTON in the Boston Massacre affair of 1770; known for his political pamphlets written in support of the Revolution; younger brother of Samuel QUINCY, the loyalist.

Quincy, Saml.Entry Details: Samuel, 1735-89, American lawyer and friend of John ADAMS; became solicitor-general of Massachusetts under the Crown, a loyalist, he left the country in 1776.

quindi Cocito, Cassio membruto.Entry Details: (It) then COCYTUS, CASSIO with powerful limbs. (See: Inferno, 34, 52 and 67).

Quinn, John.Entry Details: 1870-1924, American lawyer; authority on modern Irish literature and drama; collector and patron of modern art.

Rabateau, Jehan.Entry Details: member of the Council of CHARLES VII of France.

Ragusa.Entry Details: a port of Dalmatia; from 1205 to 1358 under the control of Venice.

Rais Uli.Entry Details: Ahmed Ibn-Muhammed Raisuli, 1875-1925, Moroccan brigand who kidnaped Walter Harris, Ion PERDICARIS (1904), and Sir Harry Maclean (1907); to avoid war with America and England, the sultan of Morocco met the ransom demanded by Raisuli.

Ram and Bull.Entry Details: reference to the ram (March) and bull (April) in the astrological frescoes in the SCHIFANOJA, Ferrara.

Rambottom, Georgio.Entry Details: Georgio Ranbutino, fl. 1454, a stone mason working on the TEMPIO of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Ranger, the.Entry Details: the ship commanded by John Paul JONES in 1777.

Ran-ti.Entry Details: (Jap) Ran-tai for (Ch) Lan-t'ai: "Orchid Tower Palace." (See: SO-GIOKU).

Rapallo.Entry Details: town of Liguria, NW Italy, on the Gulf of Rapallo, residence of Pound (1924-1945).

Rapin.Entry Details: Paul de Rapin de Thoyras, 1661-1725, French historian; author of Histoire d'Angleterre (8 vols., 1723) covering English history up to the accession of William and Mary.

Raquel.Entry Details: a Jewish merchant whom Ruy DIAZ, noted for his cunning, cheated.

Ravenna.Entry Details: town of Ravenna province, N Italy.

Read.Entry Details: George, 1733-98, American constitutional lawyer from Delaware; Daniel Leonard, John ADAMS' opponent in the NOVANGLUS correspondence, studied law with him.

Redimiculum Metellorum.Entry Details: (L) Matellarum: a Chaplet of Chamber-pots; title of a book of poems published (1930) by Basil BUNTING.

Red Lion.Entry Details: an inn between Philadelphia and Bristol, Pennsylvania.

Reeve.Entry Details: Sir Thomas, d. 1737, English jurist, author of Lord Chief Justice Reeve's Instructions to his Nephew concerning the study of law.

Regalia principis.Entry Details: (L) the rights royal of a prince. (See: John Adams, Works, III, 545).

Regent's canal.Entry Details: a canal along the north edge of Regent's Park, London.

Reggio, Bernardo.Entry Details: Bernardo da Reggio, an officer in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Regis optimatium populique.Entry Details: (L) of the king, of the aristocrats, of the people too. (See: Polybius, Fragm., VI; quoted by Jonathan Swift, A Discourse of the Contests and Dissensions between the Nobles and Commons of Athens and Rome; quoted by John Adams, Works, IV, 383).

regnicoles.Entry Details: (Fr from L) inhabitants of a kingdom.

Reile.Entry Details: Honore Charles Michel Joseph, 1775-1860, aide-de-camp to NAPOLEON (1808).

Reithmuller.Entry Details: Richard Henri Riethmueller, 1881-1942?, instructor in German at the University of Pennsylvania (1905-07); author of Walt Whitman and the Germans (1906).

Rembrandt.Entry Details: Rembrandt Harmensz van Rijn, 1606-69, the Dutch painter.

Remus.Entry Details: with his brother, ROMULUS, a founder of the city of Rome.

Rena, Orazzio della.Entry Details: Horatio or Horace, fl. 1622, prob. associated with the guardians of FERDINAND II of Tuscany.

Rennert.Entry Details: Hugo Albert, 1858-1927, scholar of Romance languages, University of Pennsylvania; Pound was his student (1905-06).

Replevin.Entry Details: (Law) the return to, or recovery by, a person of goods or chattels wrongfully taken or detained, upon giving security to try the matter in court and return the goods if defeated in the action.

repos donnez à cils/ senza termine furge.Entry Details: (Fr) give rest to (O Fr) those (It) without end acts (L) Immaculate Queen/ (Fr) The tears that I created flood me/ Late, very late have I known you, Sadness. (See: Villon, Grand Testament, rondeau after stanza 165).

Republic, the.Entry Details: the SALO Republic, as distinguished from the monarchy of occupied Italy, 1943-45.

Republican Party.Entry Details: formerly the Whig Party; the present day Republican Party was founded in 1854. It is often called the party which represents the interests of big business.

Resanesi.Entry Details: people of Resina, a city on the bay of Naples; the site of ancient Herculaneum.

Rhodes.Entry Details: the island in the Aegean Sea, in antiquity a center of trade.

Rhodez.Entry Details: Rodez, an ancient town in Provence.

RICCI.Entry Details: Mathieu or Matteo, 1552-1610, founder of the modern Catholic missions of China; he arrived at Macao in 1582. One of his most important acts was to determine the correct Chinese name for God, he decided that TIEN and CHANG TI were accurate. Without pronouncing on the meaning of these terms, CLEMENT XI decided on T'ein-chu (actually the name of one of the eight demi-gods of ancient Chinese mythology); modern sinologists have confirmed RICCI's opinion. This confusion of terms greatly hindered the Christianization of China. RICCI died in Peiping, and is the only foreigner mentioned by name in the dynastic histories of China.

Riccio.Entry Details: Guido, Sienese hero at the siege of Montemassi; Simone Martini's fresco of him (1328) is in the Palazzo Publico, Siena.

Richard I.Entry Details: Richard Coeur de Lion, 1157-99, King of England (1189-99).

Richardson, Roy.Entry Details: captain in charge of Prisoner Training, DTC, Pisa.

Richelieu, Rue.Entry Details: Rue de Richelieu, street of Paris; runs past the Bibliothèque Nationale and the Palais Royal to the Louvre.

Riley, Whitcomb.Entry Details: James Whitcomb Riley, 1849-1916, the American poet.

Rimini.Entry Details: (Ariminum), seaport of Forli province, N Italy, seat of the MALATESTA family.

Rimini bas reliefs.Entry Details: prob. a reference to the bas reliefs in the TEMPIO of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Rives, Amber.Entry Details: Amélie Rives (Princess Troubetzkoy), 1864-1945, author of The Quick and the Dead.

Roane.Entry Details: Spencer, 1762-1822, American jurist and political writer; served as judge of the General Court (1789) and in 1794 was elected to the Virginia Court of Appeals. A Jeffersonian Republican, he asserted the supremacy of the states.

Robbia, de la.Entry Details: Della Robbia, the Florentine family of sculptors and ceramicists; their terra cotta enamels bear the name Della Robbia ware.

(Robert].Entry Details: 1169-1234, Dauphin of Auvergne, he protected the troubadour Piere de MAENSAC against the attack of Bernart de TIERCI.

Rocca.Entry Details: the fortress which Sigismondo MALATESTA built at Rimini; started in 1437, finished 1446.

Rodenbach.Entry Details: Georges, 1855-1898, Belgian poet of the symbolist group, associated with the 19th century Belgian literary revival.

Rodendo con denti una bachetta che havea.Entry Details: (It) Chewing with his teeth a stick he had in his hands.

Roderique Hortalez.Entry Details: Roderique Hortalez & Co., a mock company set up by BEAUMARCHAIS to sell military supplies to the American colonies during the Revolution.

Rogier.Entry Details: Charles Latour, 1800-85, Belgian statesman; opposed union with the Low Countries, premier of Belgium (1847-52).

Rohan, La Comtesse.Entry Details: prob. the Duchesse de Rohan, fl. 1924, French writer and painter.

Roi je ne suis, prince je ne daigne.Entry Details: (Fr) I am not the king, I do not condescend to be the prince. (From the motto of the House of Rohan: Roi ne puis, prince ne daigne, Rohan suis.)

Roma, Agniolo da.Entry Details: Agnolo, an officer in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Romagna.Entry Details: region of Italy which now forms the provinces of Bologna, Ferrara, Ravenna, and Forli.

RUSH.Entry Details: Benjamin, ?1745-1813, American physician and political leader; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1776-77) and signer of the DECLARATION of Independence; surgeon in the Continental Army (1777-78), member of the Pennsylvania constitutional ratification convention (1787), treasurer of the US Mint (1797-1813).

Rossetti.Entry Details: Dante Gabriel, 1828-82, the English painter and poet, founder and leader of the Pre-Raphaelite school of painting (1848).

Rostovseff.Entry Details: Michael Ivanovich Rostovtzeff, 1870-1952, American historian; professor of classical philology and ancient history at St. Petersburg (1901-18), professor of ancient history at U. of Wisconsin (1920-25) and at Yale (1925-39); author of History of the Ancient World (1924-26), Social and Economic History of the Hellenistic World (1941).

[Rothschild, Mayer Amschel].Entry Details: 1743-1812, usually considered to be the founder of the house of Rothschild.

Rothschilds-.Entry Details: the house of Rothschild, a family of international bankers, founded by Mayer Amschel ROTHSCHILD.

Rourke.Entry Details: Tiernan O'Rourke, d. 1172, king of Breifne and ruler of part of Meath (1144), in 1152 his wife was carried off by Dermod MacMurrough (See: MACMORRAL).

Rouse.Entry Details: William Henry Denham, 1863-1950, British educator and classical scholar, translated Homer (1939) and much East Indian literature.

Rousselot.Entry Details: Abbé Jean Pierre, 1846-1924, French pioneer in experimental phonetics and in the study of dialect as related to geography and genealogy; author of Précis de Prononciation Française (1902).

Rowe.Entry Details: John, fl. 1774, an important merchant of Boston.

Rubicon.Entry Details: the river of N central Italy, just north of RIMINI.

Rufiano.Entry Details: poss. Rufina, a village of Firenze province, Tuscany, central Italy, or Ruffano, a town in southern Italy.

Rummel, W..Entry Details: Walter Morse Rummel, 1887-1953, German pianist and composer; especially interested in 12th-13th century French songs.

Runing Mede..Entry Details: Runnymede, a meadow on the south bank of the Thames in Surrey, S England; the MAGNA CHARTA was signed here by King JOHN in 1215.

Rupe Tarpeia.Entry Details: the Tarpeian Rock, the cliff in Rome where criminals and traitors were hurled to their death; the exact location of the rock is disputed.

Rush.Entry Details: Benjamin, ?1745-1813, American physician and political leader; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1776-77) and signer of the DECLARATION of Independence; surgeon in the Continental Army (1777-78), member of the Pennsylvania constitutional ratification convention (1787), treasurer of the US Mint (1797-1813).

Rushworth.Entry Details: John, ?1612-90, English historian, author of Historical Collections (8 vols. 1659-1701), a work covering the period 1618-48.

Russell (1).Entry Details: Lord John, 1792-1878, English statesman, prime minister (1846-52).

Russell (2).Entry Details: Jonathan, 1771-1832, American diplomat, charge d'affaires in England when the War of 1812 broke out; one of the five American commissioners who negotiated the treaty of Ghent with Great Britain in 1814.

Russian, the.Entry Details: the Russian army of Emperor ALEXANDER I.

Rutledge (1).Entry Details: Edward, 1749-1800, American lawyer; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-77) and signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, member of the South Carolina legislature (1782-96) and governor of South Carolina (1798-1800); brother of John RUTLEDGE.

Rutledge (2).Entry Details: John, 1739-1800, American statesman; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-76, 1782-83), governor of South Carolina (1779-82), associate justice of the US Supreme Court (1789-91), appointed Chief Justice (1795) but the appointment was not confirmed.

Ruyter, De.Entry Details: Michel Adriaanszoon de Ruyter, 1607-76, Dutch admiral and naval hero; active in the cause for Dutch freedom.

[Sacchi, Bartolommeo].Entry Details: Latin name: Platina, 1421-81, Italian humanist and historian.

Sachs.Entry Details: Hans, 1495-1576, the German Meistersinger of Nuremberg.

[Sackville, John Frederick].Entry Details: Duke of Dorset, 1745-99; English ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary to France (1783-89).

Sacrum, sacrum, inlumination coitu.Entry Details: (L) a sacred thing, a sacred thing, the cognition of coition.

Sadducees.Entry Details: a sect of Jews at the time of Christ; urban and aristocratic, the Sadducees were firm upholders of the prescriptions of the Law and were religiously conservative, denying immortality and resurrection.

[Sade, Hippolyte de].Entry Details: d. 1780, appointed Chef d'Escadre of France in 1776; a distinguished naval commander.

Sadowa.Entry Details: the village in Czechoslovakia where the Austrians suffered a major defeat in the Franco-Prussian War.

Sagittarius.Entry Details: the southern constellation represented as a centaur shooting an arrow.

Sagramoro.Entry Details: Sacramoro Sacramori, fl. 1454, counsellor and secretary to Sigismondo MALATESTA.

[Sagundino, Nicoló].Entry Details: spokesman at Rome for the Venetian Senate; charged by the Venetians to try to make peace between Pope PIUS II and the MALATESTA family.

Saint Archangelo, Petracco.Entry Details: Petraccio da Sant'Arcangelo, a captain in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Saint Boniface, Richard.Entry Details: see Count Ricciardo di SAN BONIFAZZIO.

St Catherine's chapel.Entry Details: in the church of San Domenico, Siena.

St. Clement of Alexandria.Entry Details: Titus Flavius Clemens, ?150-220?, Greek theologian of the early Christian church.

S. Domenico.Entry Details: San Domenico, a church in Siena.

St Etienne.Entry Details: the Basilica of St. Etienne, a 12th century church in Périgueux.

St. George.Entry Details: d.c. 303, Christian martyr; adopted in the time of Edward III as the patron saint of England.

St George.Entry Details: prob. a reference to a figure of St. George as patron saint on a Sienese cart.

[S. Girolamo degli Schiavoni].Entry Details: a church on the Tiber near which the body of Giovanni BORGIA floated; a witness near the church saw the cloak of Borgia floating and the assassins throwing stones on it to make it sink.

Saint Hilaire.Entry Details: church in Potters, France; built in the 11th century.

St James.Entry Details: the Court of St. James's, London

St James Campostella.Entry Details: a church in Galicia where there is a shrine to St. James; a famous object of pilgrims during the Middle Ages.

[St. John, Henry].Entry Details: Viscount Bolingbroke, 1678-1754, English statesman, orator and author, his best known work is the Idea of a Patriot King (1749)

[St. John of the Cross].Entry Details: Juan de Yepis y Alvarez, 1542-91, the Spanish mystic.

St Joseph.Entry Details: a military fort on the Great Lakes, John ADAMS requested the English to relinquish it to the Americans.

St. Louis Till.Entry Details: American soldier, DTC, Pisa, where he was executed.

St. Mark.Entry Details: patron saint of Venice, the flag of St. Mark is the Venetian standard.

St. Mary's.Entry Details: a military fort on the Great Lakes, John ADAMS requested the English to relinquish it to the Americans.

St. Nicholas.Entry Details: Church of St. Nicolo der Mendicoli, originally built in the 7th century, but restored many times since, it is on the Campo S. Nicolo in Venice.

S. Pantaleone.Entry Details: prob. the Church of S. Pantalon, on the Campo S. Pantalon, Venice.

S. Pietro.Entry Details: poss. ST. PETER'S or SAN PIETRO IN VINCOLI.

St Trophime.Entry Details: church in Arles, Provence; constructed 11th-15th century.

Sala.Entry Details: river in the Netherlands, the north mouth of the Rhine; Sala, its ancient name, is applied to the inhabitants along its banks: the Salian Franks; the modern name of the river is Ijssel.

Saladin.Entry Details: ?1137-93, the Moslem warrior and great opponent of the Christian crusaders.

Salamis.Entry Details: island E of Greece, in the Gulf of Aegina, off Salamis the allied Greek fleet defeated the Persians (480 BC).

Salem.Entry Details: the city in Massachusetts; once an important center of fishing, shipping, and ship-building.

[Salic Law, the.Entry Details: the laws of the Salian Franks, first compiled (c. 508-11) by Clovis I; the code was the fundamental law of the Merovingian and Carolingian rulers and the early Holy Roman emperors. (See: SALA).

Salisbury plain.Entry Details: a tract of land in Wiltshire, S England, near the city of Salisbury.

[Salm, Rhinegrave de].Entry Details: one of the negotiators of the Treaty of Paris (1783).

Salmacis.Entry Details: the water nymph who loved Hermaphroditus. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, IV, 285-388).

Salo.Entry Details: the Salò Republic, founded in northern Italy in October 1943, a remnant of the Fascist regime.

Saluzzo, Marchese.Entry Details: Sallusto, whose daughter, Ricciarda di Sallusto, married (1431) Niccolo d'ESTE and became the mother of his sons, Ercole and Sigismondo.

Salviati.Entry Details: prob. the Fondamenta del Banco Salviati, Venice.

Salzburg.Entry Details: the city in Austria, famous for its annual Mozart festival.

Sa Mo.Entry Details: the southern part of Kyushu Island, Japan; the ancient fief of the Satsuma lords.

Sanazarro.Entry Details: Jacopo Sannazaro, 1456-1530, the Neapolitan poet who wrote about the murder of Giovanni BORGIA.

[San Bartolomeo in Galdo].Entry Details: town in Benevento province, Campania, S Italy.

San Bertrand.Entry Details: prob. Saint-Bertrand, a village of Haute-Garonne department, S France.

[San Bonifazzio, Count Ricciardo di].Entry Details: Podestà of Mantua and husband of Cunizza da ROMANO; when Ricciardo discovered the intrigue between his wife and SORDELLO, the poet was forced to flee to Provence. However, political troubles between Sordello and San Bonifazzio were equally important in causing his flight.

San Casciano.Entry Details: San Casciano in Val di Peas, a town in Firenze province, central Italy; near Florence.

San-chan.Entry Details: (San-shan), a mountain in the province of KIANG-NAN.

Sancho.Entry Details: King Sancho, a character in Lope de Vega's Las Almenas de Toro. (See Spirit of Romance, 203-204).

Sandusky.Entry Details: once a military fort on Sandusky Bay in N Ohio, first controlled by the British in Canada and then relinquished to the Americans.

[San Giorgio dei Greci].Entry Details: the Greek Orthodox Church on the Ponte dei Greci, Venice.

San Giorgio Maggiore.Entry Details: one of the islands of Venice; also the church thereon.

San Giovanni.Entry Details: San Giovanni di Siena, a church of Siena.

Sangko.Entry Details: (Sang Ko) d. AD 1291, served as first minister to KUBLAI KHAN (1288-91), he was a villain, clever and apt at flattery, who sacrificed the honor of the Empire to his own interests. He was executed in 1291.

San Juan.Entry Details: see ST. JOHN OF THE CROSS.

San Marco.Entry Details: the Piazza and Basilica of San Marco, Venice.

San Marino.Entry Details: the republic on the Italian peninsula.

San Martino.Entry Details: a locality in central Italy, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by Pope PIUS II (c. 1460).

San Piero.Entry Details: San Pietro, the church and monastery south of Perugia.

San Pietro in Vincoli.Entry Details: Saint Peter in Chains, a church of Rome, on the Esquiline near the Baths of Titus, built in 442.

San Remo.Entry Details: seaport of Imperia province, NW Italy, on the Ligurian Sea.

San Samuele.Entry Details: church on the Campo San Samuele, Venice.

San Sepolchro.Entry Details: Sansepolcro, town of Arezzo province, central Italy.

San Stefano der Cavalieri.Entry Details: a church in Pisa richly hung with banners of the Turks and Arabians, trophies of the victories of the Knights of San Stefano.

Santa Maria.Entry Details: a church in Trivio; on the same site Sigismondo MALATESTA built the TEMPIO.

Santa Maria dei Miracoli.Entry Details: a church in Venice, decorated by the sculpture of Pietro and Tullio LOMBARDO.

Sant Apollinaire.Entry Details: the Basilica of San Apollinare in Classe, from the basilica, Sigismondo MALATESTA took marble for the TEMPIO.

[Santiago de Cuba].Entry Details: seaport and capital of Oriente province in E Cuba.

San Trovaso.Entry Details: a church on the Campo San Trovaso, Venice.

San Vio.Entry Details: church of San Vio on the Campo San Vio in Venice. Also the Festival of San Vio (15 June) held in honor of the suppression of the conspiracy of Baiamonte Tiepolo, on the festival day, the doge went to the church of San Vio to give a thank offering for the deliverance of the Republic.

San Vitale.Entry Details: a 6th century Byzantine church in Ravenna.

San Zeno (1).Entry Details: the Bastia San Zeno, or San Zenone, in Verona.

San Zeno (2).Entry Details: San Zeno Maggiore, a Romanesque church in Verona.

Saracens.Entry Details: term commonly used in the Middle Ages to designate the Arabs and, by extension, Moslems in general -- whether Arabs, Moors, or Turks.

Sardegna (2).Entry Details: a reference to VICTOR AMADEUS III.

Sardinia.Entry Details: island in the Mediterranean Sea, W of Italy.

Sarlat.Entry Details: a town in SW central France.

Sarsfield, Count.Entry Details: poss. a French emissary to the Hague. (See Adams, Works, III, 283).

Sartine.Entry Details: Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbet Gabriel de, comte d'Alby, 1729-1801, French statesman; minister of marine (1774-80).

Sauter.Entry Details: George, 1866-1937, a Bavarian portrait painter who lived in London (1895-1915).

Savil, Mrs..Entry Details: fl. 1758, wife of Dr. Elisha Savil, a friend of John ADAMS.

Savio.Entry Details: the river in north central Italy.

Sbrigara.Entry Details: a locality in central Italy, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by Pope PIUS II (c. 1460).

[Scala, Can Grande della].Entry Details: 1291-1329, lord of Verona and the greatest member of the Ghibelline family that ruled Verona from 1277-1387, he was a friend and protector of DANTE.

scavoir faisans et advenir a haute a Chi.Entry Details: (Fr) making known and to come to high/ nobility of family and house and great deeds / valor affection our aforesaid cousin / power, royal authority he and his descendents and/ as they desire to have henceforth forever in their arms quartering/ three golden flower-de-luce on scalloped azure field.. / enjoy and use. 1431, council at CHINON, the KING, l'Esne de la TRIMOUILL, VENDOISE, Jehan RABATEAU.

Schacht-.Entry Details: Hjalmar Horace Greeley, 1877- , German financier, president of the Reichsbank under Hitler.

Schifanoja.Entry Details: or Schifanoia, the Palazzo Schifanoia, palace of the ESTE, in Ferrara; famous for the frescoes of Cosimo TURA and Francesco del COSSA; built by Alberto d'ESTE (1391), extended by Borso d'ESTE.

Schneider (2).Entry Details: Joseph-Eugène, 1805-75, French industrialist; with his brother Adolphe SCHNEIDER, he organized the SCHNEIDER-CREUSOT iron works (1836).

Schneider Creusot..Entry Details: Schneider-Creusot, the iron works organized (1836) by Joseph-Eugène and Adolphe SCHNEIDER; once the world's largest steel plant.

Schoeney's daughters.Entry Details: Schoeneus' daughter, Atalanta. (See Ovid, Metamorphoses, X, 560-707). (Schoenyes 1S the spelling in Arthur Golding's translation of the Atalanta episode, Metamorphoses).

Schoners.Entry Details: a restaurant, poss. in Bolsano, Italy.

Schorn, Henry.Entry Details: the widow of Henry Schorn provided John ADAMS with a secret mailing address in Amsterdam (1781).

Schuyler, Filippo.Entry Details: Philip John Schuyler, 1733-1804, American statesman; member of the US Senate (1789-91); a supporter of Alexander HAMILTON's financial program.

Schweighauser.Entry Details: fl. 1778, a French commercial agent at Brest with whom John ADAMS, representing the American government, had dealings.

Scios.Entry Details: Chios, a large Ioman island off the coast of Asia Minor; claimed to be the birthplace of HOMER.

Scirocco..Entry Details: a hot southeast wind in the Mediterranean areas.

Scott (2).Entry Details: Winfield, 1786-1866, American soldier; Whig candidate for the Presidency in 1852.

Scottch Kirrrk.Entry Details: the Scotch Presbyterian Church in Venice.

Scudder's Falls.Entry Details: on the SCHUYLKILL, N of Philadelphia.

scudo.Entry Details: (It) crown. (a monetary unit, varying in value with locality and date).

Scylla.Entry Details: the sea-monster, living in a cave opposite Charybdis; she had SIX heads, each with a triple row of teeth, and barked like a dog. (See: Odyssey, XII, 80-100).

Seance Royale.Entry Details: (Fr) royal interview (one held by LOUIS XVIII in 1815).

se casco, non casco in ginocchion'.Entry Details: (It) if fall, I do not fall on my knees.

Se-choui.Entry Details: (Se-shul), river in KIANG-NAN; joins the HOANG-HO.

[Second National Bank of the United Stat.Entry Details: the central bank of the US which acted as a fiscal agent for the government and also conducted a general commercial business. The bank, capitalized at $35,000,000 and operating twenty-five branches, grew especially prosperous under the management of Nicholas BIDDLE; its prosperity drew to it much criticism from the frontier, and many claimed that it was too powerful and that it operated in the interests of the East alone. The bank's attempt to renew its national charter was defeated during the administration of JACKSON. The First National Bank, established by Hamilton, lasted 1791-1811; the second bank from 1816 to 1836.

Sed et universus quoque ecclesie populus.Entry Details: (L) And the whole population of the church, too.

Sedgwick.Entry Details: Theodore, 1746-1813, American jurist and statesman; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1785-88), the House of Representatives (1789-96, 1799-1801), and of the Senate (1796-99).

Segur, Mount.Entry Details: site of a castle in Provence which was besieged during the Albigensian crusade.

seipsum seipsum diffundit, risplende.Entry Details: (L) itself, it diffuses itself, (It) it shines. (See: Grosseteste, De luce seu de inchoatione formarum, ed. Baur, 51).

Seitz.Entry Details: a captain in the Provost section, DTC, Pisa.

Selinga.Entry Details: town on the border between Russia and Manchuria.

Selsey.Entry Details: prob. Selsey Bill, headland on the S coast of England.

Semiramis.Entry Details: the ship that took Maria Anna Elisa BONAPARTE, Grand Duchess of Tuscany, from Lucca (1814).

senesco/ sed amo.Entry Details: (L) I am getting old, but I love.

Senni, Virginia.Entry Details: née Marotti, prob. Venetian woman whose life and that of her son was saved by the operation of Dr. WALLUSCHNIG (1925).

Se pia, / O empia, ma risoluto/ E terrib.Entry Details: (It) If pious / or impious, but decided/ and terrible deliberation. (See: Varchi, Storia Fiorentina, III, 262).

Sequit bonorum descriptio.Entry Details: (L) There follows a description of property.

Serenely in the crystal Jet.Entry Details: poss. variation of Verlaine, Clair de Lune.

Sergeant XL.Entry Details: Sergeant Lauterback, Disciplinary Sergeant, DTC, Pisa.

Sergeant, Jonathan.Entry Details: Jonathan Dickinson Sergeant, 1746-98, American lawyer; New Jersey delegate to the first CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774).

Serpentine.Entry Details: the lake in Hyde Park, London.

settant'uno R. superiore Ambrosiana.Entry Details: (It) seventy-one R. superior Ambrosian. (a catalogue number in the AMBROSIANA).

Seu Gin.Entry Details: (Sui Jen-chi), a mythical king of China who followed the reign of YEOU; he introduced the use of fire and wood, accounting by tying knots in string, and the beginnings of trade; the name means "producer of fire and wood."

Sevilla.Entry Details: (Sp) Seville, capital of Seville province and of Andalusia in SW Spain.

Sewall.Entry Details: Stephen, 1704-60, American jurist; judge of the supreme court of Massachusetts in 1739 and chief justice in 1752; he was opposed to the British WRITS OF ASSISTANCE.

sexaginta quatuor nec tentatur habere pl.Entry Details: (L) sixty-four, nor tries to get any.

Sforza, Alessandro.Entry Details: 1409-73, Lord of Pesaro and Cotignola, brother of Francesco SFORZA, it is assumed that he obtained PESARO (1444) through some rather underhanded agreement with Galeazzo MALATESTA, whose granddaughter, Constanza Varna, he married.

[Sforza, Drusiana].Entry Details: daughter of Francesco SFORZA, married to Giacomo PIC CININO.

Sforza, Francesco.Entry Details: 1401-66, Italian condottiere, overthrew the Ambrosian republic (1447) and obtained the dukedom by force and strategy; ruled Lombardy and other parts of north Italy until his death. Married Bianca Maria VISCONTI (1441).

[Sforza, Galeazzo Maria].Entry Details: 1444-1476, Fifth Duke of Milan (1466-76), son of Francesco SFORZA and Bianca Maria VISCONTI, hence the portmanteau name given him in the text: 'Galeaz Sforza Visconti.'

[Sforza, Polissena ].Entry Details: d. 1449, natural daughter of Francesco SFORZA; in 1441 Sigismondo MALATESTA married her to cement his alliance with Sforza; eight years later she died, believed to have been poisoned by Sigismondo.

shagreen.Entry Details: the rough skin of the shark, shagreen leather.

Shah Nameh.Entry Details: Shah Namah, the great Persian epic (the book of kings) written by FIRDAUSI (c. 1010).

shamen.Entry Details: shamans, those who practice shamanism; in this case BUDDHISTS.

[Shansi].Entry Details: province in NE China, one of the Five Northern Provinces.

Shantung.Entry Details: province in NE China; one of the Five Northern Provinces.

sha-o.Entry Details: (Shao) the Succession Dance, which mimed the peaceful accession of Emperor CHUN (Shun). (See- Analects: III, XXV; VII, xin; XV, x).

[Shensi].Entry Details: province in NE central China; one of the Five Northern Provinces.

Shepard, Bill.Entry Details: William Pierce Shepard, 1870-1948, professor of Romance Languages at Hamilton College, New York, teacher of Pound (1903-05).

Sherman.Entry Details: Roger, 1721-93, American jurist and statesman, judge of the Connecticut superior court (1766-67; 1773-88), member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-81, 1783-84) where he supported John ADAMS' proposals to negotiate a treaty with France, signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, member, House of Representatives (1789-91) and the Senate (1791-93).

Shih Ching.Entry Details: the Book of Odes, supposedly collected and edited by CONFUCIUS.

Shirley.Entry Details: William, 1693-1771, English lawyer and governor of Massachusetts Colony (1741-49, 1753-56), in 1754 he started the issuing of WRITS OF ASSISTANCE in the colony.

Shogun.Entry Details: the Japanese title of commander-in-chief, the title arose in the 8th century during the wars against the Ainu. The shoguns became a quasi-dynasty which held the real civil and military power in Japan, while the imperial dynasty was theoretically and ceremoniously supreme.

[Shu Ching].Entry Details: the Book of History, supposedly collected and edited by CONFUCIUS.

Siang.Entry Details: (Hsiang), the territory in central Hunan province, SE central China, that is watered by the Siang river.

[Siang-tchong].Entry Details: (Hsiang Chung) d.c BC 609, son of OUEN KONG and successor to LOU, however, after his father's death, Siang was killed by a relative, who usurped the dukedom.

Siao-ho.Entry Details: (Hsiao Ho) d. BC 193, the advisor of LIEOU-PANG, Prince of Han, much of Lieou-pang's success in founding the HAN dynasty is due to the efforts of Siao-ho, who kept the army supplied, provided accurate maps, and helped to create a new penal code.

[Siao-tsé].Entry Details: (Hsiao Tz), the son of KAO-TI, in AD 483 he became emperor under the name Wu Ti (reign: 483-494). However, the reference may be to Siao-tsé-leang (Hsiao Tzu-liang), who was the son of Emperor Wu Ti and who did collect antique vases, this Siao became emperor in 494, ruling less than a year, under the name Chao Nieh.

Sicheus.Entry Details: Sichaeus, Dido was married to Sichaeus, who was her uncle and a priest of Heracles; he was murdered for his treasure by Dido's brother, Pygmalion.

sic: beneplacitu nostro/ Ad regis nutum.Entry Details: (L) beneplacito. thus: in accordance with our (royal) good pleasure/ to endure at the King's command. (See: Coke, Institutes, IV, 74; John Adams, Works, III, 521, 524).

Sic loquitur nupta/ Cantat sic nupta.Entry Details: (L) so the bride speaks, so she sings.

Si come avesse l'inferno in gran dispitt.Entry Details: (It) as he greatly despised hell. (See: Inferno, 10, 36).

Sié.Entry Details: (Sie) town in the principality of Chin, in SHANSI province, NE China.

Sieff.Entry Details: Israel Moses, British merchant; reputed anonymous owner of the London tabloid, the Daily Mirror, during the late 1930's.

Siki.Entry Details: Battling Siki, a light heavyweight boxing champion of the 1920's, a Senegalese of brutish strength.

Silenus.Entry Details: a satyr, sometimes described as the son of Hermes or Pan; companion of DIONYSUS; sometimes known as a musician.

Silk War.Entry Details: war between Venice and Ragusa at the beginning of the 15th century; Pandolfo MALATESTA led the Venetians against Ragusa in 1420, but did not capture it.

Silla.Entry Details: locality in the African Sudan, west of Timbuctoo and on the Niger, final stop of the FASA in the reincarnation of WAGADU.

S'il règne un faux savoir.Entry Details: (Fr) if a false knowledge reigns. (See: John Adams, Works, III, 362, where he quotes from the Mercure de France (February 1783): s'il y regne un faux savoir, pire que l'ignorance ..).

simplex munditus.Entry Details: (L) plain in her neatness. (See: Horace, Odes, I, 5).

Singki.Entry Details: (Hsing Chi) d. AD 1352, a commander of the imperial troops serving Emperor CHUNTI; his sudden death from a wound gave the rebels against the throne an unexpected victory in Kiangsi province.

Si no'us vei, Domna don plus mi cal, / N.Entry Details: (Pr) If I see you not, Lady with whom I am most concerned, / Not seeing you is not the true reward for my fair thought. (See: Appel's Bernart von Ventadour, 235).

Sin star.Entry Details: prob. Antares, a star in the Chinese constellation of Sin. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 222).

Sintien.Entry Details: (Hsin-tien) prob. a town close to Ch'ang-an, the capital of the TANG dynasty, in Shensi province. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, VI, 350).

Si pulvis nullus /Erit, nullum tamen exc.Entry Details:
(L) even if there is no dust.
/ brush it off. (See: Ovid, Ars Amatoria, I, 151).

sirenes.Entry Details: prob. a reference to the four marble angels in Venice carved by Tullio LOMBARDO.

Sirens.Entry Details: the mythical creatures who had the power of drawing men to destruction by their song. ODYSSEUS escaped them by plugging the ears of his men with wax and having himself lashed to the mast of his ship. (See: Odyssey, XII). According to one legend, the Sirens drowned themselves in a fit of pique after Odysseus escaped them.

Siria.Entry Details: village in Arad province, western Rumania.

Sirmio.Entry Details: Sermione, a peninsula and village in Brescia province of Lombardy, N Italy.

Sitalkas.Entry Details: a Thracian king of the tribe of Odrysae, d. 424 BC.

Si tuit li dolh ehl planh el marrimen.Entry Details: (Pr) Si tuit li dolh elh plor elh marrimen: If all the griefs, tears and anguish and the pain. (See: Bertran de Born, Planh on the death of Henry the young King).

Si tut li dolh el plor/ tuit lo pro, tui.Entry Details: (Pr) If all the grief and the tears/ all the worth, all the good. (See entry above for source).

Siuen-ouang.Entry Details: (Hsuan Wang) (reign: 827-781), a good emperor who put himself under the guidance of trustworthy counselors, although the kingdom was bothered by attacks from barbarians, Siuen managed for some time to repel them with the royal troops. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 35).
