[Siuen-tsong].Entry Details: (Hsuan Tsung) (reign: 847-60). An emperor of intelligence and decision, he became known as the second TAI-TSONG.

Siu-tcheou.Entry Details: (Siu-ch'ou), a department of the province of KIANG-NAN.

6th Anne chap. XXXVII section 9.Entry Details: an Act of Parliament (1707) which provided for the encouragement of trade with America.

Si-yu.Entry Details: (Hsi-yu), a large region of western China, outside the limits of SHENSI province; the territory of the Tartars.

Sligo.Entry Details: seaport of county Sligo in N Eire on Sligo Bay.

Slomismyk.Entry Details: Henry Slominsky, 1884- , author of Heraklit und Parmenides (1912).

Smith.Entry Details: William Brooke, a young painter Pound knew in Philadelphia (c. 1905), Pound dedicated A Lume Spento (1908) to him.

Smith, Adam.Entry Details: 1723-90, Scottish economist, author of Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations (1776).

Smith, Robert.Entry Details: 1757-1842, US Secretary of the Navy (1801-09) and Secretary of State (1809-11). President MADISON requested Smith to resign his last post because his foreign policy was not in accord with Madison's and because Madison could not stand his prose style.

Smith, W..Entry Details: William Loughton Smith, ?1758-1812, American statesman; member House of Representatives (1789-97); US minister to Portugal (1797-1801). He was a supporter of HAMILTON's financial policies and a heavy speculator in government paper.

Snag.Entry Details: nickname of a prisoner in a "security cage" near Pound, DTC, Pisa.

Snow.Entry Details: Herbert Kynaston, 1835-1910, editor of Theocritus and teacher of Greek at Eton. He changed his name from Snow.

Soane et Loire.Entry Details: Saône-et-Loire, a department in E central France.

Société Bourgeose.Entry Details: an early form of the chamber of commerce, but having a more direct control over the actions of the government.

Soffici.Entry Details: prob. a member of the Sienese BALIA (c. 1622).

So-Gioku.Entry Details: Sung Yü, 3rd and 4th century, Chinese poet. (See: The Man-Wind and the Woman-Wind in Waley, 170 Chinese Poems, 41).

Sogliano.Entry Details: a locality in central Italy, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by Pope PIUS II (c. 1460).

Solois.Entry Details: a promontory on the Atlantic coast of North Africa, HANNO stopped there on his periplus.

Somnus.Entry Details: the Roman god of sleep. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, XI, 592).

Soncinus, Hieronymus.Entry Details: Gerolamo Soncino, Italian printer of the 16th century.

Song.Entry Details: (Sung) poss. the principality founded in BC 1113 by Emperor TCHING-OUANG.

Son of Heaven.Entry Details: a title of the emperor of China; poss. reference to CHANG-TI.

Sons of Liberty.Entry Details: groups which organized throughout the American Colonies to resist enforcement of the STAMP ACT (1765).

[Soong, Charles Jones].Entry Details: d. 1924, member of the prominent Soong family of China; he was a Methodist missionary in Shanghai and made his fortune as a Bible manufacturer and salesman.

Sorano.Entry Details: a town of Tuscany in the province of Grosseto.

Soranzo, Sorantia.Entry Details: daughter of Giovanni SORANZO, Doge of Venice; she was exiled from Venice in 1320 and permitted to return only to attend her father when he was ill (1328).

Sordello (1).Entry Details: ?1180-1255?, Italian troubadour who lived much of his life in Provence; son of a poor cavalier, Sier ESCORT. He came to the court of Count Ricciardo di SAN BONIFAZZIO, fell in love with the Count's wife, Cunizza da ROMANO, and helped her brothers to abduct her; he was then forced to flee to Provence. Later he took military service with CHARLES I of Naples and Sicily. Sordello's most important poem is the planh on the death of Blacatz. (See: Purgatorio, 6 and '7, Browning's Sordello; and Make It New, 27).

Sordellus de Godio.Entry Details: Sordello da GOITO, Podestà of Mantua; generally thought to be the same person as SORDELLO.

Sorella, mia sorella, / che ballava sobr.Entry Details: (It) sister, my sister, / who danced over a golden coin.

So-shu.Entry Details: poss. a reference to the Chinese poet Li Po (d. AD 762); or to Chuang Tzu (So-shu is the Japanese version), who was a Taoist philosopher of China (fl. 4th century BC).

Souan yen.Entry Details: (Suan Yen) fl. BC 2722, one of the favorite governors of Emperor CHIN-NONG.

SPAHLINGER.Entry Details: Henry, 1882-, Swiss bacteriologist; inventor of an anti-tuberculosis serum.

Sounou.Entry Details: (Su Nu or Surnama) d. AD 1724, a prince of royal blood and descended from an older branch of the Manchu princes than was Emperor YONG-TCHING. Sounou was regarded as a threat to the throne and spent most of his life in exile, serving as general of the eastern Tartars.

Sou-ouel.Entry Details: (Su Wei) fl. AD 580, advisor to YANG-KIEN, the Duke of Soui.

Sousa, De.Entry Details: Robert de Souza, 1865-1946, a minor French symbolist poet.

South, the old.Entry Details: used in reference to the aristocracy of the Southern states of the US before the Civil War (1861-65).

South Chariot.Entry Details: more commonly called the "south-pointing chariot"; the ancestor of the mariner's compass, said to have been invented by TCHEOU KONG.

South Country.Entry Details: prob. a reference to the area comprising the modern province of Anhwei; this region was the birth place of TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG, founder of the MING dynasty.

Southern Barbarians.Entry Details: the tribes of the region of YUEI, a state in Honan province along the Yellow River. All barbarian tribes to the south went under the generic name of the Nan.

South Han.Entry Details: or Nan-han, roughly the area of the provinces of Kwangsi and Kwangtung in SE China, this principality lasted from 905-971.

South Horn.Entry Details: the estuary of four small rivers on the SW coast of Sierra Leone, W Africa.

Sou Tsi.Entry Details: (Su Chi) fl. BC 288, a member of the court of TCHAO-SIANG-OUANG who thought it badinage when the prince divided China into two parts and called himself "l'empereur d'occident"

Sou-tsin.Entry Details: (Su Ch'in) d. BC 317, a Taoist philosopher who was for a time a minister of the State of TSIN. He tried to organize a confederation of the Six States against the growing power of Tsin, he succeeded and gained great wealth and power. He then became minister of the State of Yen, but was involved in an intrigue with the queen-dowager and was assassinated.

Sou Tsong.Entry Details: (Su Tsung) (reign: 756-63). At the start of his reign the barbarians held both the eastern and western capitals of the Empire, his reign was one of continual wars with barbarians and rebels, but he was served by able generals.

Sparta.Entry Details: or Lacedaemon, the ancient city of Greece.

Speare.Entry Details: Morris Edmund, 1884-, American educator and literary scholar; edited The Pocket Book of Verse (1940).

Spencer, Ambrose.Entry Details: 1765-1848, American lawyer and politician who was associated with DeWitt CLINTON's Republican party machine in the politics of New York State; chief justice of the New York supreme court (1819-23), member of House of Representatives (1829-31).

Spencer, H..Entry Details: Ezra Pound's instructor at the Cheltenham Military Academy, Ogontz, Pennsylvania (1898).

Spensers.Entry Details: see Hugh le DESPENSER, the elder and the younger.

Speranzo, Nic..Entry Details: prob. member of the Consiglio de' DIECI.

Spinello.Entry Details: a locality in central Italy, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by Pope PIUS II (c. 1460).

spingard.Entry Details: (It) spingarda: swivel-gun, or a military catapult.

Spire, André.Entry Details: 1868- French writer and strong advocate of Zionism.

Spirit of Mountains.Entry Details: spirit of the ancient Chinese religion.

Sponsa Cristi-.Entry Details: (L) the Bride of Christ: (the Church), reference is to Sponsa Christi mosaics in the church of S. Maria in Trastevere, Rome.

S. P. Q. Amst. faustissimo foedere junct.Entry Details: (L) Senate and People of Amsterdam -- in very fortunate union joined.

Spring and Autumn, the.Entry Details: Spring and Autumn Annals, the Ch'un Ch'1u. This, the last of the Five Classics, is a chronological record of the chief events in the State of LOU (Lu) between 722-484; it is generally regarded as the work of Confucius, whose native state was Lou.

S.P. Senensis ac pro eo amplissim/ Balia.Entry Details: (L) Collegium civicae: The Senate and People of SIENA and on their behalf the most honorable BALIA, the College of civic vigilance of the entire city.

STATE TRIALS.Entry Details: A collection of legal records and proceedings in English history, including trials of political and criminal cases.

Ssé-ma Kouang.Entry Details: (Ssu-ma Kuang) 1019-1086, a distinguished statesman, historian, and scholar. His greatest work was the TSÉ-TCHI TONG-KIEN, A Comprehensive Mirror for the Aid of Government.

Ssetcheou.Entry Details: (Ssu-ch'ou), a town near the modern city of Fengyang in the province of Anhwei.

Stadtholder, the.Entry Details: see WILLIAM V, Prince of Orange.

stagirite.Entry Details: a native of Stagira, here ARISTOTLE.

Stael, Madame de.Entry Details: Anne Louise Germaine Necker, baronne de Staêl-Holstein, 1766-1817, French-Swiss woman of letters.

Stalin.Entry Details: Joseph Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili, 1879-1953, Russian statesman and Communist leader.

Stamboull.Entry Details: Stambul, the oldest part and main Turkish residential section of Istanbul.

Stammbuch of Sachs.Entry Details: (Ger) genealogical record of SACHS (perhaps of the Hans Sachs family, or of the meistersingers of all ages).

Stamp Act.Entry Details: A revenue law passed by the English Parliament (1765) that extended the British stamp tax to America and required all publications and legal documents issued in the colonies to bear a stamp.

staria senza più scosse.Entry Details: (It) it would rest without further tossing.

State Trials.Entry Details: Prob. State Trials and Statutes at Large by John Seldon.

Stealing of the Mare, the.Entry Details: Title of one of a cycle of romances by Abu Obeyd, translated from the Arabic by Lady Anne Blunt and put into English verse by Wilfred Scawen BLUNT, published in London (1892).

Steele.Entry Details: Lt. Colonel John Steele, commanding officer of the DTC, Pisa.

Stefano.Entry Details: Stefano da Verona, 14th-15th century Veronese painter.

Stephen, order of..Entry Details: The Order of St. Stephen, a chivalric order founded by Cosimo I de' MEDICI after the battle of Marciano, in 1554, on the feast of St. Stephen, Pope and Martyr. The Dukes of Tuscany were the hereditary Grand Masters of the Order.

Stone Cottage.Entry Details: Stone Cottage, Coleman's Hatch, Sussex, where Yeats and Pound spent several winters (1913-1916).

Stony Hill.Entry Details: Stony-field Hill, a part of Stony Acres, John Adams' property in BRAINTREE, Massachusetts.

Stourbridge.Entry Details: Municipal borough of Worcestershire, W central England, on the Stour.

Stowe.Entry Details: A town in Oxfordshire, outside Buckingham, England.

Stretti.Entry Details: (It) embraced one another (a popular Italian song).

Strozzi, Filippo.Entry Details: 1426-91, banished by the Medici, he returned to Florence in later years and began to build the famous Strozzi Palace.

Stuart, Mary.Entry Details: Mary Queen of Scots, 1542-87, ruled in Scotland (1561-68). The reference is probably to the murder of David Rizzio (1566), an Italian who was Mary's chief advisor.

Stufa, Agnolo della.Entry Details: Florentine ambassador sent to Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Stupro, caede, adulter, / homocidia, par.Entry Details: (L) in debauchery, slaughter, an adulterer/ a homicide, a parricide, and a perjurer, / killer of old men, bold, licentious.

stuprum, raptum/ I.N.R.I. Sigismund Impe.Entry Details: (L) debauchery, rape/ Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews, Sigismondo Emperor, King of Traitors.

SUNG (1).Entry Details: An important Chinese state that occupied the lower part of the valley of the HOAI river; lasted 1113-285.

SUNG (2).Entry Details: The eighth dynasty (420-23); known as the Liu Sung dynasty.

SUNG (3).Entry Details: The nineteenth dynasty (960-1280); the dynasty is divided into two parts: the Sung (960-1127) and the Southern Sung (1127-1280).

styrax.Entry Details: (L) storax: a balsam used in perfumery.

Sub annulo piscatoris, palatium seu curi.Entry Details: (L) By the ring of the fisherman, the palace or court once of the MALATESTAs.

sub conditione fidelitates.Entry Details: (L) under condition of faith; on trust. (See: John Adams, Works, II, 149, where the phrase is quoted from a work of Strykius).

Subillam/ Cumis ego occulis meis tu thel.Entry Details: (L) Sibyl/at CUMAE I with my own eyes. (Gr) What do you want? (L) She replied (Gr) To die. (See: Petronius, Satiricon, XLVIII, 8; and Appendix A).

Suen-hoa-fou.Entry Details: (Suan-hwa-fu), city near Peiping, in the province of Hopeh.

Suen-ti.Entry Details: (Suan Ti) (reign 569-83), fourth emperor of the Ch'én dynasty.

suffestes.Entry Details: (L) sufes (-fetis) the name of the highest magistrate in Carthage.

suis fils d'un pauvre laboureur.Entry Details: (Fr) I am the son of a poor workingman. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, X, 1).

Sulpicia.Entry Details: Fl. BC 40, the niece of Messalla Corvinus; she was a Roman poet whose six short pieces on her passion for Cerinthus are included in volume III of the works of Tibullus.

Suma.Entry Details: Village on Oska Bay, near Kobe, Japan, here GENJI spent his years of exile from the court. (See: Lady Murasaki, The Sacred Tree, and the Noh play Suma Genji in Translations, 232).

summa.Entry Details: (L) the whole, totality; a treatise covering the whole of a field.

summus justiciarius.Entry Details: (L) chief justice. (See: John Adams, Works, IV, 544).

sumne fugol othbaer.Entry Details: (OE) sumne fugel ob baer: the ship (or bird) carried one of them away. (See: The Wanderer, line 82).

Sumus in fide/ Puellaeque canamus/ sub n.Entry Details: (L) We have the protection / and girls let us sing (the praise of) / beneath the night. (See: Catullus, XXXIV, 1-4 and Virgil, Aeneid, VI, 268).

Sung (1).Entry Details: An important Chinese state that occupied the lower part of the valley of the HOAI river; lasted 1113-285.

Sung (2).Entry Details: The eighth dynasty (420-23); known as the Liu Sung dynasty.

Sung (3).Entry Details: The nineteenth dynasty (960-1280); the dynasty is divided into two parts: the Sung (960-1127) and the Southern Sung (1127-1280).

Sung (4).Entry Details: The Southern SUNG, second part of the nineteenth dynasty (1127-1280).

Sun-hao.Entry Details: d. AD 283, ruler of the kingdom of OU, which controlled the territory south of the Yangtze. Emperor TÇIN-OU-TI spent many years trying to bring the kingdom under his rule, and succeeded in 280; Sun-hao was a cruel king, and his people finally revolted to join the emperor.

Sun Te.Entry Details: fl. AD 901, first general of the Empire during the reign of Emperor Chao Tsung (reign: 889-905). He freed the emperor from the control of the eunuchs and had several of them executed. In gratitude, the emperor made his family an affiliate of the royal house.

Sun-tong.Entry Details: (Sun Tung) fl. 202-195, a member of the court of Emperor KAO-HOANG-TI whose task it was to write on the ceremonies and usages of the rites.

Sun up; work Imperial power is? and to u.Entry Details: An ancient Chinese lyric, the Sun up song. (See: Shen Tê-ch'ien, Origins of Ancient Poetry, 1).

Surrender of Breda..Entry Details: Painting by VELÁSQUEZ, hanging in the Prado, Madrid.

[Su-siang-koué].Entry Details: (Su Hsiang-kuei) fl. AD 1355, a fighting companion of TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG.

Su Ta.Entry Details: d. AD 1385, served as the lieutenant of TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG during his struggles to found the MING dynasty; when Tchu became emperor (under the name HONG-VOU), Su-ta became his advisor.

Swedenborg, Emanuel.Entry Details: 1688-1772, the Swedish scientist, philosopher and religious writer.

Swift-amoursinclair.Entry Details: Swift and Armour are American meat packers. Upton Sinclair, 1878- , American novelist and politician exposed the Chicago meat packing industry in The Jungle (1906).

Sylla.Entry Details: 138-78, the Roman general, noted for his cruelty.

Sylva.Entry Details: A book on practical arboriculture by John EVELYN (1664).

Symons.Entry Details: Arthur, 1865-1945, the British poet and literary critic.

Syntagma.Entry Details: The Syntagma Philosophicum by Pierre Gassendi. (See: GOSINDI)

Syrinx.Entry Details: A nymph pursued by PAN; when she changed into a tuft of reeds, Pan fashioned the reeds into his pipes -- thus, the pipes of Pan.

Syrus.Entry Details: Publilius Syrus, a writer of Latin mimes and maxims in the first century BC.

[Szechwan].Entry Details: A province in S central China.

T..Entry Details: Prob. Thomas Trask, one of John ADAMS' farm hands at BRAINTREE.

Tabarin.Entry Details: The Bal Tabarin, a night club in Montmarte, Paris.

[Tagore, Sir Rabindranath].Entry Details: 1861-1941, the Bengali poet, awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature (1931).

Tagus.Entry Details: The river in Spain and Portugal.

Tai.Entry Details: (T'ai), a feudal state in the province of SHANSI, lasted C. BC 350-100.

Tai chen..Entry Details: (T'ai Shen) fi. AD 1643, a Mongol prince who allied himself with the Manchu leader TAI-TSONG during one of the latter's many raids on SHANSI province.

Tai Haku, Mt..Entry Details: Prob. Taihoku, mountain peak in South Kankyo province of N Korea.

Tai-hia.Entry Details: (Ch) Tai-hoa. mountains. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 259).

Taiping.Entry Details: A city and district in the old province of KIANG-NAN, now a city in the modern province of Anhwei.

Taipou.Entry Details: Tai-pouhoa (T'ai Pu-hoa) d. AD 1352, a scholar and military officer serving Emperor CHUNTI; he successfully encountered the rebels against the throne on several occasions but finally died in battle.

Taishan, Mt..Entry Details: (Tai or T'ai Shan), a sacred mountain of China in W Shantung province, 32 miles S of Tsinan, there are many shrines on the road to the top, on which stand the temples.

Taishan-Chocorura.Entry Details: See TAISHAN. Mount Chocorua, a peak in E New Hampshire, in the Sandwich Range of the White Mountains.

Taitong.Entry Details: (Tai-tung), city in SHANSI province, just inside the northern border between China and Inner Mongolia.

Tai Tsong (1).Entry Details: (T'ai Tsung) (reign: 626-649), one of China's most remarkable emperors. A disciple of Confucius, he noted that when emperors were attached to Taoism or Buddhism they brought about the downfall of their dynasties and said, "Just as wings are necessary for the birds and water for the fishes, so I put my trust in the teachings of the sages of our country." He cut government costs, reduced taxes, built libraries, aided scholars, and saw that his people had more than enough for their daily needs. In 645 he invaded Korea, but could not bring it completely into the Empire. In 649 he composed NOTES ON CONDUCT.

Tai Tsong (2).Entry Details: (T'ai Tsung) (reign: 977-998), a mild but decisive emperor who governed with economy. His first important act was to suppress the state of Northern HAN (979), a task his brother, TAI-TSOU, had not completed. But Tai-tsong was unable to check the KHITAN Tartars or to stop a dangerous alliance between the Khitan and NUTCHÉ Tartars. He was a student of history, honored Confucius and studied the Classics.

[Tai-tsong].Entry Details: (T'ai Tsung), imperial title of OGOTAI Khan.

Tai Tsong (3).Entry Details: (T'ai Tsung or T'ein Ts'ung) 1591-1643 (reign: 1625-43), son of TAI TSOU (1559-1626), who was the founder of the Manchu power. In 1635 Tai-tsong proclaimed himself Emperor of China, although the MING dynasty still held Peiping. In 1636 he established the Manchu rule as the Ch'ing dynasty, conquered Mongolia and gained much of the Empire. He modeled his government after the Chinese, especially in the matter of holding public examinations, but denationalized the Chinese by abolishing some of their customs.

Tai-Tsou.Entry Details: (T'ai Tsu) (reign: 960-76), founder of the SUNG dynasty. He was serving as a general under Emperor CHI-TSONG when his troops invested him with the yellow robe of emperor. His greatest accomplishment was the restoration of the Empire; he reclaimed Southern Han, Heou-chou, Szechwan and other provinces for the throne, and only Northern Han resisted his attacks. He encouraged the study of literature, revised the law courts, changed the criminal code, and stabilized the economy.

[Tai-tsou].Entry Details: (T'ai Tsu or Chu Wên) (reign: 907-13), first emperor of the After Liang dynasty (907-60). When the last emperor of the TANG dynasty made him Prince of Liang, Tai-tsou assumed much of the emperor's power and assassinated him in 907. Tai-tsou's reign was troubled by rebellions and invasions of the KHITAN Tartars.

Tai-Tsou (1).Entry Details: (T'ai Tsu) (reign: 951-54), founder and first emperor of the After CHOU dynasty. Although his reign was disturbed by the rebellious Prince of Han, Tai-tsou proved to be an able administrator and leader. He was a patron of literature and honored the memory of Confucius by saying, "Confucius is the master of a hundred generations of emperors.

Tai-Tsou (2).Entry Details: (T'ai Tsu), the imperial title of GENGHIS KHAN.

Tai Tsou.Entry Details: (T'ai Tsu or Nurhachu) 1559-1625 (reign: 1616-25), the real founder of the Manchu power; he consolidated the tribes of Inner Mongolia and brought most of the territory north of the Great Wall under his control. In 1625 he established the Manchu capital at Mukden.

Takasago.Entry Details: Seaport of S Honshu, Japan; there two pines grow that are inhabited by the spirits of an old man and his wife, symbolic of long life and conjugal loyalty.

Talbot.Entry Details: An extinct breed of dog; perhaps the name comes from the Talbot family of England, on whose crest appears the figure of a dog.

Talleyrand.Entry Details: Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord, 1754-1838, French statesman; created grand chamberlain by Napoleon (1804); helped to restore the Bourbons after Napoleon's fall; instrumental in organizing the Quadruple Alliance (1834). The agents in the XYZ Affair were reputed to be those of Talleyrand (who was minister of foreign affairs, 1797-1807) but he denied any connection with them.

Tamerlan.Entry Details: An opera with music by P. Winter and text by E. Morel de Chéfdeville (based on Voltaire's Orphelin de la Chine) first performed: Paris, C. 1802.

Tami.Entry Details: Possibly Tami Koumé, Japanese painter, of whom see Letters, passim; possibly a reference to Tomi, a Roman outpost on the Black Sea, S of the Danube, where OVID spent his ten years of exile and where he died.

Tammany Hall.Entry Details: The New York City headquarters of the Tammany Society of New York (founded 1786), the major force in New York politics until the elections of 1932.

Tancred.Entry Details: Frederic W., a member of the Hulme-Flint poetry group (c. 1909).

Tancreds, Jerusalem and Sicily.Entry Details: Reference to Tancred (d. 1194), King of Sicily; and Tancred (?1078-1112), Norman hero of the First Crusade who distinguished himself in the capture of Jerusalem.

Taney.Entry Details: Roger Brooke, 1777-1864, American jurist; US Attorney General (1831-33), Secretary of the Treasury (1833-34), Chief Justice of the Supreme Court (1836-64). He is most famous for his decision in the Dred Scott case (1857) when the Supreme Court held that Scott (an American Negro who held that he had obtained his freedom by residing in free territory) was not a citizen and not entitled to any standing in court.

Tang.Entry Details: Various references to the TANG dynasty and related topics.

Tang dance.Entry Details: A dance called the "Tang" in the text because the dancers wore headdresses like those of the TANG dynasty. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IX, 608).

Tangier.Entry Details: The seaport of NW Morocco. (See also: TANGIERS).

T'ang Wan Kung.Entry Details: Title of Book III of the works of Mencius, (See: Mencius, III, I, iii, 6-7).

tanka.Entry Details: Probably the Japanese verse form of five lines; the first and third have five syllables, the others seven.

Tan Ki.Entry Details: (T'a Chi) d. C 1122, an evil woman who was the concubine of Emperor CHEOU-SIN; after WU WANG's victory at MOU YE, she was executed "to the delight of nearly everyone who knew her."

Tan mare fustes.Entry Details: (O Fr) tant mar fustes So unfortunately you were. (See: Chanson de Roland, 2034).

Tant las foter com auzirets / Cen e quat.Entry Details: (Pr) And I had them as often as you shall hear/ 120 and eight times. (See: William of Poitiers, Farai un vers, pos mi sonelh, 79).

Taoist.Entry Details: Believer in Taoism, supposedly founded by LAO-TSE (c. BC 604). Taoism is essentially a religion of inaction, of mystical contemplation of the Tao -- the way the universe functions or the path which natural events take. Later Taoism became a seeking for long life and for the elixir vitale. The Taoist idea of a laissez faire government was in direct contradiction to the Confucian ethic.

Taouen.Entry Details: Ta-ouan (Ta-wan), a principality in SHENSI province; according to legend, the horses of Ta-ouan were celestial (TIEN-MA) and their sweat was the color of blood.

Tarascon.Entry Details: A town of Bouches-du-Rhône department in SE France.

Tartars.Entry Details: The northern barbarians or Huns; the nomadic tribes on the borders of Chih-li, Shansi, and Kansu provinces. By the end of the third century BC the Tartars, or HIONG-NOU, had formed a nation composed of many nomadic tribes. In BC 142 they crossed the Great Wall and gained control of much of Shansi province. By BC 33 the Empire had divided the Tartars into small tribes, most of which offered at least token homage to the emperor.

Tartars, West.Entry Details: A western tribe of barbarians, the K'iang, which lived to the west of Kansu; they defeated the forces of SIUEN-OUANG in the battle of "The Thousand Acres" (BC 788).

Tartar war.Entry Details: The wars between the Chinese Empire and the Tartars, during the first century AD.

Tartary.Entry Details: Or Tatary, an indefinite region in Asia and Europe, from the Sea of Japan to the Dnieper river, controlled at various times by the Tartar tribes. The Tartars which invaded China occupied the area beyond the northern boundaries of Shensi, Shansi and Hopeh provinces.

Tarviso.Entry Details: Treviso, (L) Tarvisium, city of Treviso province, N Italy, seat of the Lombard duchy in the early Middle Ages; home of Ezzelino III of ROMANO.

Tatler, The.Entry Details: A British magazine devoted to gossip about the upper classes.

Taylor.Entry Details: John, 1703-66, English jurist and scholar, author of Elements of Civil Law (1755).

Taylor, John.Entry Details: 1753-1824, a printer and political writer of Caroline County, Virginia, in 1814 he printed a letter of John ADAMS' written to John Penn (1776), author of An Inquiry into Principles and Policy of the Government of the United States (1814).

Té-tchéou.Entry Details: (Tz'u-ch'ou), city near Liuchow in Kwangsi province, SE China; in AD 954 the Northern Han attacked Liuchow and Emperor CHI-TSONG engaged the Han troops near Té-tchéou.

Tchang.Entry Details: River which rises in Shensi province and flows NE parallel to the Hwang Ho, joining it on the Great Plains. Ouang-tchang (Wang Chang) fl. AD 290, a Chinese officer. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IV, 192-193).

Tchang-siun (1).Entry Details: (Chang Hsün) fl. AD 756, a commander of imperial troops serving Emperor SOU-TSONG; he is best known for his defense of YONG-KIEU during a siege.

Tchang Chi.Entry Details: (Chang Shih) fl. AD 1521, Empress dowager, mother of Emperor OU-TSONG. At the death of her son, who left no heir, she called a council to name the next emperor. CHI-TSONG, grandson of Emperor HIEN-TSONG, was chosen.

Tchang-hien-tchong.Entry Details: (Chang Hsien-chung) fl. AD 1643, a rebel chieftain with a reputation for extreme cruelty. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, X, 479).

Tchang-ku-tching.Entry Details: (Chang Chü-chêng) d. AD 1582, a scholar and statesman who was tutor to Emperor Mu Tsung (reign: 1567-73) and regent over Emperor CHIN-TSONG. He centralized the government, promoted peace and order in the Empire, and tried to balance the budget. Often accused of taking bribes, he was deprived of his titles and property in 1584.

Tchang-ngan.Entry Details: (Changan), the modern city of Sian in Shensi province, NE China; it was the capital of the Empire under the HAN dynasty.

Tchang-siun (2).Entry Details: (Chang Hsün) fl. AD 756, a commander of imperial troops serving Emperor SOU-TSONG; he is best known for his defense of YONG-KIEU during a siege.

Tchang-sun Chi.Entry Details: (Chang Sun-shih) d. AD 636, the empress of TAI-TSONG. She was one of the great queens of China; like her husband she was a foe of Taoism and Buddhism; at her death she asked the emperor not to build her a great tomb because it would cost the people too much. She wrote a work on the lives of the princesses who had been on the throne before her time.

Tchang tcheou.Entry Details: (Changchow), the modern city of Lungki in Fukien province, SE China, on the left bank of the Saikoe river.

Tchang-tsong.Entry Details: (Chang Tsung) fl. 202-195; a member of the court of Emperor KAO-HOANG-TI who studied the theory of music.

Tchan-y.Entry Details: Tchang-y (Chang I) fl. BC 313, a Chinese condottiere who served the States of OUEI, TSIN and Chou during the feudal wars near the end of the TCHEOU dynasty.

Tchao-hou.Entry Details: Tchao-hoei (Chao Hui) fl. AD 1759, a general of the imperial troops serving Emperor KIEN-LONG; he was responsible for the success of the campaigns to put down the ELUTES who, under the leadership of Amursana, revolted against the Empire and attempted to take the district of Ili in Sinkiang province.

Tchaomed.Entry Details: Tchao-modo (Chaomoto), a town to the north of the Gobi desert; here FEYANKOU defeated KALDAN, leader of the ELUTES

Tchao-ouang.Entry Details: (Chao Wang) (reign: 1052-01), an emperor who allowed the government to become weak and the prosperity of the country to decline; he was drowned while crossing the River Han, probably the victim of a plot.

Tchao Siang.Entry Details: Tchao-siang-ouang (Chao Siang-wang) fl. BC 288, Prince of TSIN, in his many wars with the other feudal states of China he did much to weaken the TCHEOU dynasty and prepare the way for the TSIN dynasty.

Tchao-tso.Entry Details: (Chao Tso) fl. BC 170, minister of war in the court of Emperor HIAO-OUEN-TI.

Tchen-yu.Entry Details: (Chen-yu), the title which the Tartars gave to their kings.

Tcheou Kong.Entry Details: (Chou Kung) d. BC 1105, Duke of Chou, advisor to his brother WU WANG and regent for his nephew TCHING-OUANG. His activities, devoted wholly to the welfare of the state, aided greatly in establishing the TCHEOU dynasty; he is credited with the invention of the SOUTH CHARIOT. Tcheou-kong is one of the measuring sticks for the greatness of any ruler.

Tcheou Tun-y.Entry Details: (Chou Tun-i) 1017-73, a scholar and philosopher who held small posts in the government; his chief works are elucidations of the mysteries of the Book of Changes, or I Ching, which is ascribed to WÊN WANG.

Tchi.Entry Details: Tseng Hsi, a disciple of Confucius and father of Tsêng Tzu, the most important of the disciples. (See. Analects, XI, 25).

Tchin (1).Entry Details: (Chin), a powerful feudal state in the southern half of Shansi, NW of Honan, on the Yellow river.

Tching (2).Entry Details: (Ching), a principality of feudal China near the present city of Kaifeng in Honan province, E central China.

Tching-gintai.Entry Details: (Cheng Jen-t'al) fl. AD 662, a general of the imperial troops serving Emperor Kao Tsung (reign: 650-84), he was sent to deal with the Tartar tribes which had been attacking the borders of the Empire -- his campaign was a success.

Tching ouang.Entry Details: (Cheng Wang) (reign: 1115-1078), son of WU WANG; second emperor of the TCHEOU dynasty, he fostered cultivation and reclamation, brought good men into the government, and regulated the measure of money and cloth.

Tching Tang.Entry Details: (Ch'êng T'ang) (reign: 1766-53), the founder of the Shang dynasty (1766-1122); he was a model king who subordinated every passion and feeling to the good of his people; in time of drought he coined money so the people could buy grain, but there was no grain to buy until his sacrifices were accepted by Heaven and rain fell. On his wash basin he inscribed the admonition: Make it new.

Tching-tcheou.Entry Details: poss. the city of Ting-tcheou (Ting-ch'ou) in Hopeh province, N China.

[Tching-tsong].Entry Details: (Cheng Tsung), imperial title of TIMOUR Khan.

Tchinkiang.Entry Details: Tching-kiang (Chinkiang), city and port of Kiang-su province, E China.

Tchin-kin.Entry Details: (Chen Chin) d. AD 1285, son of KUBLAI KHAN and prince royal of the Empire. He was a model of all virtues and manners, learned in the humanities and the arts of war and ruling; his early death was a great loss to the Empire.

Tchinkis.Entry Details: Tchinkis-han (Ghingiz Khan) see GENGHIS KHAN. It is said that 'Tchinkis' is an imitation of the cry of a celestial bird, which no one has ever seen but which will herald great happiness when it does appear.

Tchin-li.Entry Details: (Ch'ên Li) fl. AD 1363, second son of TCHIN-YEOU-LEANG, after his father was defeated at the battle of Lake Po-yang, Tchin-li was allowed by TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG to retain the family estates.

[Tchin-mao].Entry Details: (Chen Mao) fl. AD 1717, a second-class mandarin holding a military command in Kwangtung and serving as viceroy of Canton. In 1717 he memorialized Emperor KANG-HI to drive the Christian missionaries from the Empire and to expel the European merchants from MACAO. The emperor, insulted by the actions of CLEMENT XI, proclaimed that no missionary could stay in China without special imperial permission and persecuted those who did not comply.

Tchin Tiaouen.Entry Details: Tchin-tiao-yen (Chen Tiao-yen) fl. AD 1297, a brigand in the south of China who gathered a large band of vagabonds, he attacked the city of Tchang-tchéou (in Fukien province) and killed KANQUEN, the commander of the city.

Tchin-tsong.Entry Details: (Chen Tsung) (reign: 998-1023), a capable emperor but a devout Taoist, whose superstition led him to disgrace. K'ou Chun, a brilliant general and statesman, forced the emperor to fight the Khitan Tartars and to make peace with them by promising an annual tribute of one hundred ounces of silver and two hundred pieces of silk. When court intrigues ousted K'ou Chun, the emperor fell into the hands of ministers who used his superstition to their advantage. Three books, reputed to be from heaven, were presented to the emperor, who was so impressed by this supposed honor that he ordered a great temple built; the temple took seven years to build and cost so much that some date the decline of the SUNG dynasty from this event. By 1020 the emperor was insane and his power in the hands of eunuchs.

[Tchnn-yeou-gin].Entry Details: (Ch'én Yu-Jen) fl. AD 1363, brother of TCHIN-YEOU-LEANG he took part in the battle of Lake Poyang (1363) in which his brother was defeated by TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG, founder of the MING dynasty.

[Tchun-yeou-leang].Entry Details: (Ch'ên Yu-liang) d. AD 1363, commander of an independent revolutionary force during the general revolutions of the reign of Emperor CHUNTI. In 1358 he proclaimed himself Prince of Han and styled himself emperor of a "Han" dynasty; by 1363 his power in China was second only to that of TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG, the great revolutionary leader who founded the MING dynasty. In 1363 the two forces met in a battle on Lake Poyang, and Tchin-yeou-leang was killed by a stray arrow and his army routed; his two brothers, TCHIN-YEOU-GIN and Ch'en yu-kuei were associated with him in his career.

Tchong (1).Entry Details: prob. Fan-tchong (Fan Chung) fl. AD 22, a bandit leader. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, III, 248 ff).

[Tchong-king-fou].Entry Details: (Chung-ching-fu), the modern city of Chungking in SZECHWAN province, China.

[Tchong-tsong].Entry Details: (Chung Tsung) (reign: 684-710), a weak emperor who was controlled by women. His mother, OU-HEOU, ruled the Empire until 705; and from 705-710 the emperor was ruled by his wife, Wei, who wanted to be a second Ou-heou; We was murdered in 710.

Tchuen.Entry Details: Tchuen-hio (Chuan Hsü) (reign: 2514-2436), the fifth of the legendary emperors of China, grandson of HOANG TI.

Tchun-tsiou.Entry Details: the Ch'un Ch'1u, or SPRING AND AUTUMN Annals.

Tchun-tsong.Entry Details: (Chun Tsung or Li Sung) (reign: AD 805), a mild and good man, but ill with an incurable disease when he came to the throne. After eight months he abdicated in favour of his son, who ruled under the name HIEN-TSONG.

Tchu-ouen.Entry Details: (Chu Wên) 1383-1403, grandson of Emperor HONG-VOU and prince royal; he succeeded his grandfather, taking the title of KIEN-OUEN-TI.

Tchu-yé.Entry Details: Tchu-yé-yuen (Chu Yeh-yuan) fl. AD 1622, commander of imperial forces in Shantung serving Emperor Hsi Tsung (reign: 1621-27), he inflicted heavy losses on the rebel forces during the rebellions of 1622.

[Tchu-yuen-tchang].Entry Details: (Chu Yuan-chang) 1328-99, founder of the MING dynasty. He was a Buddhist novice, but when the Buddhists were forced to disband some monasteries, Tchu-yuen-tchang offered his services to Kuo Tzu-hsing (d. 1355), one of the leaders of the revolutionary WHITE LILY SOCIETY; he later parted from Kuo Tzu-hsing and proclaimed himself Prince of Wu (1364). From this time he led the major force seeking the overthrow of Emperor CHUNTI and the Mongol dynasty. In 1367 he proclaimed himself Emperor of China, founded the Ming dynasty, and called himself HONG-VOU.

Tcin (2).Entry Details: (Chin), the seventh dynasty (265-420), it is divided into the Western Chin (265-317) and the Eastern Chin (317-420).

Tein.Entry Details: (Chin), a principality in the province of Shansi.

Tin.Entry Details: (Chin), the Western Chin dynasty (265-317); the first part of the TÇIN.

Tçin Hiao.Entry Details: Tcin-hiao-ou-ti (Hsiao Wu Ti) (reign: 373-97). His reign was plagued with civil wars, for TÇIN was declining in power and the SUNG dynasty was about to appear. This emperor is noted for his poor knowledge of female psychology.

[Tcin-hoai-ti].Entry Details: (Hwai Ti) (reign: 307-13), a very intelligent emperor who was versed in the arts of government, but he had no success in war with the Prince of the Eastern Sea (who was to bring the Eastern TÇIN into prominence). The emperor had such poor results in battle that he was deposed.

[Tcin-hoei-ti].Entry Details: (Hui Ti) (reign: 290-307), son of TÇIN OU TI; he was rather feeble-minded and his reign was one of unrest, mostly caused by his advisors.

[Tcin-min-ti].Entry Details: (Min Ti) (reign: 313-17). His reign was disturbed by Tartar attacks; in 317 the Tartars captured the capital and made the emperor a prisoner.

Tin Ngan.Entry Details: Tcin-ngan-ti (An Ti) (reign: 397-419), an emperor who was little better than an idiot. However, the reference may be to Tcin-ngai-ti (Ai Ti) (reign: 362-66), who is known as the "Sad and Sorrowful Emperor" and wasn't much better than Tcin-ngan-ti.

Tin Ou Ti.Entry Details: (Wu Ti) (reign: 265-90), founder of the Western TÇIN dynasty; his most important act was the overthrow of the kingdom of OU, one of the THREE KINGDOMS.

Tçin Tching.Entry Details: Tcin-tching-ti (Ch'eng Ti) (reign: 326-43), not a bad man himself, but he came to the throne at the age of five and had incompetent and cruel advisors.

Te cavero la budella del corpo! / El con.Entry Details: (It) I will carve the guts right out of you! And the Count rising: / I'll tear the liver out of you!

Te cavere le budelle/ corata a te.Entry Details: (It) I'll cut your guts out/ (and I) yours!

Te Deum.Entry Details: (L) Thee, God (a Christian hymn sung on all Occasions of thanksgiving).

Te fili Dux, tuosque successores/ Aureo.Entry Details: (L) Thee, my son the Duke, and thy successors/ with a golden ring.

Télémaque.Entry Details: a ballet, prob. based on the opera Télémaque by Adrien Boieldieu; first performed in St. Petersburg, 1808.

Tellus.Entry Details: the Roman divinity of the Earth.

Tellus-Helena.Entry Details: a combination of TELLUS and HELEN of Troy; the divinity of fertility, and a semi-goddess of destruction.

telo rigido.Entry Details: (L) with rigid javelin; with hardening of the archery.

Témougin.Entry Details: (Temuchin), the personal name of GENGHIS KHAN.

Tempio.Entry Details: the Tempio Malatestiano in Rimini; the early Renaissance style building was begun 1446 (or 1447), consecrated 1450, and work was suspended in 1455. To build his Tempio, Sigismondo MALATESTA secured some of the best artists and craftsmen of Italy: Leon Battista ALBERTI, Agostino di DUCCIO, Pier della FRANCESCA, and PISANELLO. (For a complete description see: Corrado Ricci, Il Tempio Malatestiano, Rome: 1925).

Temple.Entry Details: Sir John, an English agent in Boston (1776).

Temple, the.Entry Details: the Inner Temple or the Middle Temple, among the Inns of Court.

templum aedificavit.Entry Details: (L) built a temple. (See: the TEMPIO), tempora, tempora mores.

tempora, tempora mores.Entry Details: (L) time (ages), time customs. (See: Cicero, o tempora! O mores!).

Tempus loquendi, / Tempus tacendi.Entry Details: (L) There is a time to speak, / there is a time to be silent, (inscribed on the tomb of Isotta degli ATTI in the TEMPIO).

Ten Bou.Entry Details: prob. Outoubou (Wutubu) (reign: 1214-25), emperor of the KIN dynasty; his reign was one of almost continual war with the Mongols of GENGHIS KHAN.

Teng.Entry Details: (Têng), village in the province of Honan, near the modern city of Nanyang.

Tengtcheou.Entry Details: (Têng-ch'ou), the modern city of Penglai on the N coast of Shantung Peninsula in Shantung province, NE China.

Teng-tchi.Entry Details: (Têng Chê) fl. AD 107, refused to be made a prince, but later returned to the court to aid the government of Emperor HAN-NGAN-TI.

Tennyson.Entry Details: Alfred, 1st Baron Tennyson, 1809-92, the English poet.

Ten Seo Daisin.Entry Details: (Tensio Dai Sin or in Japanese Amaterasu-o-mi-kami), the Japanese Goddess of the Sun, chief goddess of the Shinto religion; her descendants became the emperors of Japan.

TenShi.Entry Details: (Jap) Son of God; poss. a place name.

10th District.Entry Details: the Tenth Congressional district of Massachusetts; a reference to George Holden TINKHAM, who represented the district in the House of Representatives

Téou-Chi.Entry Details: (T'ou Shih) fl. AD 168, queen dowager; appointed regent over the Emperor HAN-LING-TI; she was the daughter of the prime minister, Tau Bu.

Teoui-tchéou.Entry Details: Tsoul-tchéou-tou (Ts'ui Ch'ou-tu) fl. AD 952, an officer of the imperial troops serving Emperor TAI-TSOU.

ter flebiliter.Entry Details: (L) thrice mournfully. (See: Horace, Odes, IV, xii, 5).

Terminus.Entry Details: the "great god Terminus," the sacred boundary stone which stood in the great temple of the Capitoline Jupiter in Rome.

Ter pacis Italiae.Entry Details: (L) Three times of the Italian peace.

ter pacis Italiae auctor.Entry Details: (L) three times author of the Italian peace.

Terracina.Entry Details: seaport of Latium in central Italy, just SE of the Pontine Marshes, was an ancient town on the Appian Way, and the ruins of an ancient temple to Jupiter are found there.

Terreus.Entry Details: Tereus, legendary King of Thrace. (See: ITYS).

Té Tsong.Entry Details: (Te Tsung) (reign: 780-805), a weak but amiable emperor. His ministers urged him to obtain revenue by finding new taxes and to abolish the three existing taxes: land tax, compulsory labor, and payment in kind; the new tax was an annual collection in money. Once the emperor became aware of the condition of the peasants, he gave much attention to making their lot easier, but his ministers prevented him from accomplishing many of his aims. He was a poet and wrote his imperial decrees in verse.

teuke.Entry Details: a piece of money used by the Russians in W Asia; about the value of one TAEL of silver in China.

[Thacher, Oxenbridge].Entry Details: 1720-65, American lawyer and member of the Massachusetts general court; associated with James OTIS and Stephen SEWALL in the controversy over the Boston WRITS OF ASSISTANCE (1763).

[Thebes].Entry Details: the ancient Greek city; TIRESIAS was from Thebes.

their Highnesses.Entry Details: see FERDINAND II of Tuscany and MARIA MAGDALENA.

Theognis.Entry Details: Theognis of Megara, an aristocratic elegiac poet of the 6th century BC whose best known work is the Elegies to Kyrnos, in which he considers the values of the aristocratic man in human affairs.

Theresa.Entry Details: a French ship carrying cargo to South Carolina during the Revolution (1778) and belonging, so he claimed, to BEAUMARCHAIS firm RODERIQUE HORTALEZ & CO; but the ownership of the vessel was disputed by M. MONTHIEU.

The scarlet curtain throws a less scarle.Entry Details: from Golding's translation of Ovid's Metamorphoses, X, 586-96. (See: Literary Essays, 235-37).

These fragments you have shelved (shored.Entry Details: Variation of T. S. Eliot, The Waste Land: These fragments I have shored against my ruins.

Theseus.Entry Details: the Greek hero, son of Aegeus; his most famous exploit was the slaying of the Minotaur.

thethear.Entry Details: (Sp) cecear: lisping; to pronounce Spanish C in the Castilian manner, th.

the yellow bird.Entry Details: from Ta Hsio, III, 2; Shih Ching, ode 230. (See: Appendix B).

\"This wind, sire, is the king's wind\nN.Entry Details: from Sung Yu, The Man-Wind and the Woman-Wind. (See: Waley, 170 Chinese Poems, 41).

Tholomeno, Don Joas.Entry Details: see Don Joas Theolomico de ALMEIDA.

Thomas, Tony.Entry Details: Antoine, fl. 1691, Jesuit missionary in China.

Thompson.Entry Details: James Thomson, 1700-1748, the Scottish poet; author of the Seasons (1726-1730).

[Thrace].Entry Details: ancient country on the E Balkan Peninsula, SE Europe.

Three Kingdoms.Entry Details: the Epoch of the Three Kingdoms, 221-265. During this period there were three minor dynasties: the Minor Han (221-263), the Wei (220-260) and the Wu (222-64). The kingdom of Wei embraced the central and northern provinces; Wu controlled the provinces south of the Yangtze, and Han ruled the province of Szechwan. This was a period of great battles, of heroes, and of chivalry, a period much like that of King Arthur.

Thseng-sie.Entry Details: Têng Hsi, a disciple of Confucius. (See: Analects, XI, xxv).

[Thulemeyer, Baron de].Entry Details: minister from Prussia at the Paris Treaty conference (1783).

Thumiatehyon.Entry Details: Thymiaterium, city founded by HANNO, just south of the Strait of Gibraltar and north of SOLOIS.

Thumon.Entry Details: (Gr) soul, life, strength, courage, mind. (See: Appendix A).

Tian.Entry Details: Tien or Tsêng Hsi, a disciple of Confucius. (See: Analects, XI, xxv).

Tiberius.Entry Details: Tiberius Julius Caesar Augustus, 42 BC-37AD, second Roman Emperor (14-37 AD).

Tiemoutier.Entry Details: (Tiehmutiehr or Temudar) d. AD 1322, minister of state under Emperor GIN-TSONG and prime minister under Emperor Ying Tsung (reign: 1321-23). Tiemoutier was an unscrupulous minister who grew rich by his official robberies. After his death Ying Tsung deprived him of all his honors and started to put his followers to death. Alarmed, some of them plotted to assassinate the emperor; they did in 1323.

Tien-cheou, Mt..Entry Details: (T'ien-shou), a range of hills NW of Peiping where were situated the tombs of the MING emperors.

Tien Hing.Entry Details: (T'ien Hsing) fl. AD 812, a minister of Emperor HIEN-TSONG.

Tienouan.Entry Details: Tien-ouan (T'ien-wan), the name of the dynasty which Siu-cheou-hoei (Hsü Shou-hui) attempted to found (1351-57); his revolt against CHUNTI was successful for a time, but he was captured and killed C. 1357. (See. Mailla, Histoire Générale, IX, 594). The name of the general who "beat the rebels" in the text was Tong-pu-siao (Tung Pu-hsiao) fl. 1352. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IX, 600).

Tien-tan.Entry Details: (T'ien Tan) fl. BC 279, a soldier, and later a commander of the forces of TSI.

Tientsin.Entry Details: city of E Hopeh province in NE China, at the junction of the Pie and the Grand Canal.

Tierci, de.Entry Details: Bernart, nobleman of Provence; his wife was stolen away by Piere de MAENSAC. (See: Make It New, 27).

Ti Ko.Entry Details: (Ti Ku) (reign: 2436-2366), a ruler noted for his justice and interest in his people, he attained fame by being the first emperor to have more than one wife.

Ti Koen.Entry Details: poss. Tien-ki (T'ien-ki) the name given to the reign of Emperor HI-TSONG.

Tilsit.Entry Details: city, formerly of East Prussia, a port on the Niemen; under Russian administration since 1945. The treaties which constitute the Peace of Tilsit were concluded there on 7 and 9 July 1807. After having won the battle of Friedland, Napoleon I met Alexander I of Russia for a conference at Tilsit (25 June 1807); France made peace with Russia and gave Russia a free hand in its design on Finland, but the pact was broken in 1812.

Timour.Entry Details: Timour Khan (reign: 1295-1308), grandson of KUBLAI KHAN, whom he succeeded to the throne. Timour was an honest ruler who tried to promote the welfare of his people, he improved the administration, reformed the system of selecting officials, curbed the power of the nobility, expelled dishonest officials and cut down bribery. In 1303 he was confined to his bed and the government was run by palace ladies and corrupt officials.

Ting-tsong.Entry Details: (Ting Tsung), imperial title of KUJAK Khan.

Tinkey, Mrs..Entry Details: evidently the landlady of Miscio ITO.

Tinkham.Entry Details: George Holden, 1870-1956, member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts (1915-43). a conservative and isolationist.

Tipa.Entry Details: or Deva, the title of the viceroy who governs Tibet for the Grand Lama.

Tippecanoe clubs.Entry Details: political organizations working for the election of William Henry HARRISON and John TYLER in the presidential campaign of 1840; they were running against Martin VAN BUREN. The slogan of the Whig party was "Tippecanoe and Tyler too.' Harrison was called "Tippecanoe" because of the battle with the Indians which he fought on the Tippecanoe river (7 November 1811).

Tiresias.Entry Details: the legendary Greek seer associated with the royal house of Cadmus. In Hades, Tiresias informs ODYSSEUS the way he must go to return to Ithaca. (See: Odyssey, X, XI; Ovid, Metamorphoses, III).

Tirol.Entry Details: or Tyrol, former province of Austria; now Italian; includes the Bavarian Alps on the N border and the Otztaler Alps in the center.

Titania.Entry Details: epithet of CIRCE. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, XIV, 382 and 438)

(Tithonus).Entry Details: son of Laomedon and brother of Priam; he was loved by Eos, who asked that Zeus grant him immortality, Tithonus was granted immortal life but without immortal youth, so he became old and shriveled and is said to have turned into a grasshopper.

Titus.Entry Details: Titus Flavius Sabinus Vespasianus, 40-81, Roman emperor (79-81).

Todero.Entry Details: the column of St. Theodore in the Piazza di San Marco, Venice, where the statue of Theodore stands on a crocodile.

Tola, octroi decime.Entry Details: Tola(?). octroi (Fr) town dues, toll-house, decime (Fr) 1/10 of a franc.

Tolfa.Entry Details: town in central Italy, famous for its alum mining industry.

Tolosa.Entry Details: poss. (L) Toulouse, the city on the Garonne, France; prob. Tolosa, a town of Guipuzcoa, Spain.

Tompkins.Entry Details: Daniel D., 1774-1825, American politician; governor of New York (1807-16); Vice President of the US (1817-25). He was closely allied with the DeWitl CLINTON political faction of New York.

Ton.Entry Details: Tou-ché-kéou (Tu-shih-k'ou), a gorge north of Shansi province, leading from Inner Mongolia into China.

Tong-ping-tchang.Entry Details: (Tung Ping-chang) fl. AD 1355, a fighting companion of TCHU-YUEN-TCHANG.

Tonkin.Entry Details: region in N French Indo China; once a part of China.

Topa-hong.Entry Details: (Toba Hung) d. AD 499, the Tartar emperor of OUEI; rebelled against the Empire in 489 but later made peace. He was known for the reverence he gave to the ancient emperors and to Confucius.

To-pa-tao.Entry Details: (Toba Tao) d. AD 452, prince of the kingdom of OUEI; a very important and powerful ruler of the time, who paid much attention to the state of education in his domain. One day he entered a Buddhist monastery and found the priests all drinking whiskey and the monastery full of weapons -- so he abolished the Buddhists of his kingdom.

tornsel.Entry Details: prob. (It) tornese: of Tours; a minor coin of base silver or copper, struck in many of the Italian states prior to the unification.

Toro.Entry Details: town in ZAMORA province, NW Spain.

Toro, las almenas.Entry Details: (Sp) the battlements of TORO; Las Almenas de Toro is a play by Lope de Vega (1618).

Torrano.Entry Details: a locality in central Italy, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by Pope PIUS II (c. 1460).

Torre! Torre! Civetta!.Entry Details: (It) Tower! Tower! Screech owl! (See: TOWER OF PISA).

Torwaldsen.Entry Details: Bertel Thorwaldsen, 1770-1844, the Danish sculptor; one of his best known works is the statue of a lion at Lucerne, Switzerland.

Tory (Tories)..Entry Details: the loyalist party in America during the Revolution.

Toto.Entry Details: (T'o-t'o) 1313-55 minister of state under Emperor CHUNTI and one of that emperor's few honest ministers. Toto attempted to quell the rebellions of the rising MING, but court intrigue hindered his efforts. His campaign against the rebels was stopped by a decree stripping him of all honors and sending him into exile, in 1355 he was poisoned, but by 1363 his reputation was again honored. He is also known for his historical studies, particularly for his history of the KIN Tartars.

Tou-kou-hoen.Entry Details: (Tu-ku Hun), a Tartar tribe which occupied the territory around Lake Koko Nor in Tsinghai province, W central China.

Touli-Kahn.Entry Details: Touli-kohan (Tuli Kohan) fl. AD 593, leader, or Kohan, of the Tu-chüe, a Tartar tribe in northern China, he was given the daughter of Emperor OUEN-TI.

Tournon, Maillard de.Entry Details: Charles-Thomas Maillard de Tournon, 1668-1710, titular Patriarch of Antioch who, in 1704, was sent to China by Pope CLEMENT XI with the title of Patriarch of the Indies and Legate. He arrived in Canton in 1705 and published the decretal of Clement XI condemning Chinese ancestor worship.

Tou-san.Entry Details: (Tu-san), a Tartar tribe; or Tartars in general.

tout crédit soit d'un peuple soit d'un p.Entry Details: (Fr) all credit whether of a people or an individual/ of two things the opinion as to the good faith/ and as to the chances/ of his meeting. (See: John Adams, Works, VII, 344).

Tout dit que pas ne dure la fortune.Entry Details: (Fr) Everything says that fortune doesn't last.

Tou-yu.Entry Details: (Tu Yu) fl. AD 247, an officer of Emperor TÇIN-OU-TI who proposed to build a bridge over the Hwang Ho, he also led an attack against the kingdom of OU.

tovarisch.Entry Details: (Russ in Fr transliteration) comrade; in a comradely fashion.

Tower of Hananel.Entry Details: in the north corner of Jerusalem, on the wall.

Tower of London.Entry Details: the ancient fortress, prison and royal residence in London.

[ Tower of Pisa].Entry Details: the Campanile of Pisa; the leaning tower.

Tower of Ugolino.Entry Details: the Torre Della Fame (Tower of Famine) in Pisa, in which UGOLINO della Gheradesca, his sons and grandsons were imprisoned and starved to death; it stood at the north side of the Piazza degl'Anziani. (See: Inferno, 33).

Towers of Pisa.Entry Details: there are several, but the two most famous are the Torre Della Fame (the TOWER OF UGOLINO) and the Campanile (The Leaning TOWER OF PISA).

Trachulo.Entry Details: Servulo, court poet of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Tracy.Entry Details: see Comte Antoine Louis Claude DESTUTT DE TRACY.

\"Trade, trade, trade\".Entry Details: prob. from Sidney Lanier, The Symphony.

Train, Francis.Entry Details: George Francis Train, 1829-1904, American merchant and writer.

Trapier.Entry Details: an acquaintance of John ADAMS. (See: Adams, Works, II, 249).

Trastevere.Entry Details: district in Rome, across the Tiber from the main city.

Trebizond.Entry Details: an offshoot of the Byzantine Empire which included Georgia, the Crimea, and the S shore of the Black Sea.

Tree of Visages.Entry Details: prob. an invention; poss. a reference to the tsuboki or Camellia Japonica, the flowers of which are often likened to human heads in Japanese poetry.

[Tribunal of Rites].Entry Details: a commission set up in 1601 by Emperor CHIN-TSONG to consider the merits of Christianity when the Jesuit missionary Mathieu RICCI came to the court. The Tribunal rejected Christianity and recommended that the missionary be sent back to his own country. However, the emperor allowed him to remain at court.

Tribune.Entry Details: prob. the New York Herald Tribune, Paris edition.

Trieste.Entry Details: the seaport at the head of the Adriatic Sea.

Trimouill.Entry Details: Georges de la Tremouille, d. 1433, favourite and prime minister of CHARLES VII of France (1425-33); he was an enemy of Joan of Arc and aided in handing her over to the English.

Trinacrian.Entry Details: (L) Trinacria: three-pointed; a poetical name for Sicily.

trine as praeludio.Entry Details: poss. (It) trino as preludio: threefold (in trinity) as prelude.

Trinity, the.Entry Details: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost.

Trist.Entry Details: Eliza House, fl. 1785, a friend of Thomas JEFFERSON; she cared for Jefferson's daughter while he was in Europe.

Tristano.Entry Details: (It) Tristram, poss. the version of the story of Tristram and Isolde by Thomas of Britain (c. 1185) in Norman French verse; the earliest extant version. (See: Spirit of Romance, 79).

Trivio.Entry Details: in Rimini; site of the TEMPIO.

Troas.Entry Details: the Troad, territory surrounding the ancient city of TROY.

Troezene.Entry Details: Troizen, a plain on the NE extremity of Argolis, home of Aethra, mother of THESEUS.

[Trotsky, Leon].Entry Details: 1877-1940, the Russian Bolshevik leader, negotiated the treaty of Brest-Litovsk.

[Trowbridge, Edmund].Entry Details: 1709-93, Massachusetts jurist; presided at the Boston Massacre trial (1770), remained neutral in the Revolution. (He changed his name from Goffe).

Tsai.Entry Details: (Ts'ai), a small feudal state situated on the river HOAI in Honan province, E central China. - see TSAI-KING. - see OUANG-TSAI-GIN.

Tsai King.Entry Details: (Ts'ai Ching) 1046-1126, a partisan of OUANG- NGAN-CHÉ; in 1107 he became lord high chamberlain under Emperor HOEI-TSONG and gained control of the administration. He filled all posts with his own men, made oppressive changes in the salt tax and coinage, and led the Empire into expensive wars, he was several times degraded but always managed to work his way back to power. Tsai-king is known in Chinese history as "the Chief of the Six Traitors.

Tsao.Entry Details: a principality of feudal China in Shantung province (1122-501).

Tsé-ho.Entry Details: (Tzu-ho), city on the northern border of Shansi province.

Tseng.Entry Details: Tzu Kung, disciple of Confucius; important in Chinese interstate diplomacy (495-68). (See: Mencius, III, I, 1V, 13).

Tseou-kou.Entry Details: prob. Tcheou-kien (Ch'ou Chien) fl. AD 27, a Chinese bandit leader. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, III, 290-291).

Tsé Tchin.Entry Details: prob. name of a Chinese emperor. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 211).

sé-tchi tong-kien.Entry Details: (Tzu-chih t'ung-chien commonly called T'ung-chien or Mirror of History), a history of China from the fifth century BC down to the beginning of the Sung dynasty, AD 960, SSE-MA-KOUANG was editor and chief author; the work, begun before 1064, was completed in 1084 and presented to Emperor CHIN-TSONG. The history was later abridged and cast in a new form and given the title Tsé-tchi-tong-kien kang-mou (Tzu-chiht'ung-chier kang-mu or Kang-mu).

Tseu-lou.Entry Details: Tzu-lu, a disciple of Confucius. (See: Analects, XI, xxv).

Tse-Yng.Entry Details: (Tzu Ying) (reign: BC 206), son of EULH-chi-hoang-ti and last emperor of the TSIN dynasty, he held the throne for- ty-six days and then surrendered it to LIEOU-PANG, Prince of Han, who allowed Tse-yng safe conduct from the palace.

Tsi.Entry Details: (Chi), a feudal state comprising a large part of northern Shantung and southern Chihli (1122-265); the Duke of Tsi mentioned is prob. Ching Kung (fl. 547-489).

Tsié-mé.Entry Details: (Chieh-me), town in the province of Shantung.

Tsin (1).Entry Details: (Ch'in), a city, once the capital, of Kansu province, N China.

Tsin Chi.Entry Details: Tsin-chi-hoang-ti (Ch'in Shih Huang Ti) (reign: 246-209), fourth emperor of the TSIN dynasty to rule all of China and the real founder of its power.

Tsing.Entry Details: (Ch'ing), the twenty-second dynasty (1616-1912); the reference is prob. to KANG HI, fourth emperor of the Ch'ing dynasty.

Tsing-chin.Entry Details: (Ch'ing-shên), city in Szechwan province; known later as Koan-hsien.

Tsing-mo.Entry Details: Tsing-mao, a Chinese herb. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, I, 74).

Tsiun-Y-.Entry Details: (Chun-i), prob. a village in Honan province.

Tso-kieou-min.Entry Details: (Tso Chiu-min or Tso) fl. 5th century BC, a disciple of Confucius; he wrote a commentary on the SPRING AND AUTUMN Annals (or CH'UN CH'IU) of Confucius. Tso has been canonized as the "Father of Prose," for he expanded the brief entries of Confucius into dramatic episodes. His commentary is known as the Tso Chuan.

Tsunhoa.Entry Details: (Tsun-hwa) a fortified city in the province of Hopeh; in AD 1629 the city fell to the Manchu forces during their march on Peiping.

Tsu Tsze.Entry Details: Tzu Hsi, 1835-1908, Empress dowager of China and actual ruler (1898-1908). (See: Guide to Kulchur, 81n).

Tucker, Sam.Entry Details: Samuel, 1747-1833, American naval officer; as captain of the Franklin and the Hancock he preyed on British shipping during the Revolution, he was commander of the frigate Boston which carried John ADAMS to his post as commissioner to France (1778).

Tudor.Entry Details: royal family that ruled England from 1485-1603.

Tudor, William.Entry Details: 1779-1830, author of Biographical Memoir of the Life of James OTIS (Boston: 1823).

Tudor indeed is gone and every rose.Entry Details: variation of the Rubai-yat V. Iram indeed is gone with all his Rose.

Tuft.Entry Details: Cotton Tufts, 1732-1815, American physician; a friend of John ADAMS, whose affairs he administered while Adams was in London.

Tuilleries.Entry Details: Tuileries, former palace in Paris; while seldom used as a royal residence before the Revolution, Napoleon made it his chief residence, as did Louis XVIII.

Tung Kieou.Entry Details: (Tun-chiu), a place near the department of Ta-ming-fu in the province of Chihli, NE China.

Tura, Cosimo.Entry Details: or Cosmé, C. 1430-95, Italian painter of murals; a leader of the Ferrarese school and court painter to Borso and Ercole d'ESTE; one of the SCHIFANOJA mural- ists.

Turgot.Entry Details: Anne Robert Jacques, 1727-81, the French economist.

Turk.Entry Details: prob. a reference to LIEOU-TCHI-YUEN, - who was originally a Chato Tartar before he became emperor.

turris eburnea.Entry Details: (L) tower of ivory. (See: Litany of the Blessed Virgin).

Tuscany.Entry Details: region of central Italy. During the 12th and 13th centuries the region was divided into small republics and then united under the MEDICI dukes of Florence, later it passed to the HOUSE OF LORRAINE, and subsequently to Sardinia and the kingdom of Italy.

tu theleis respondebat.Entry Details: see SUBILLAM CUMIS EGO OC- CULIS MEIS

24 E 47th.Entry Details: poss. the residence of Pound's AUNT F(rank).

29th Styschire.Entry Details: (poss. Styx + shire) the 29th Regiment of His Majesty's Foot was quartered in Boston in 1770. (See: John Adams, Works, I, 97).

Tyler (1).Entry Details: John, 1790-1862, tenth President of the United States (1841-45), Vice-President (1841), succeeding to the presidency on the death of President William Henry HARRISON (4 April 1841).

Tyler, Wat.Entry Details: or Walter, d. 1381, English leader of the Peasants' Revolt (1381) in protest against the Statute of Laborers and the poll tax.

Tyndarida.Entry Details: a reference to HELEN of Troy, whose mother was Leda, wife of Tyndareus; also a reference to the wife of Bernart de TIERCI.

Tyro.Entry Details: daughter of Salmoneus; loved by Poseidon, who visited her disguised as the Thessalian river, Enipeus.

[Uberti, Farinata degli].Entry Details: d. 1264, Florentine Ghibelline leader who was banished to Siena (1258) and recaptured Florence from the Guelphs in 1260, he is called the 'Savior of Florence;' his daughter married Guido CAVALCANTI (1266 or 67). (See: Inferno, 10).

[Uberti, Ubaldo degli].Entry Details: friend of Ezra Pound; a descendant of Farinata degli UBERTI; a resident of Genoa.

Uberton (Gubberton).Entry Details: prob. reference to Surbiton, a town on the Thames, Surrey, England.

Uccello, Paolo.Entry Details: Paolo di Dono, C. 1396-1475, Florentine painter; one of the 'realists' of the 15th century.

Udine.Entry Details: city of Friuli province in NE Italy; in World War I it was an Italian military base of operation against Austria (1915-18); occupied by Austrian troops in October 1917.

Ugolino.Entry Details: Ugolino della Gheradesca, ?1220-89, Ugolino da Pisa; conspired to seize power in Pisa but was imprisoned and his wealth confiscated (1274); escaped and allied himself with the Guelphs of Florence and Lucca, then at war with Pisa, and regained his property (1276). After committing other treasons against Pisa, he, his two sons and two grandsons were imprisoned in the tower of Gualandi (since called Torre Della Fame) and starved to death (See. Inferno, 33)

Ulster.Entry Details: the northernmost of the four historic provinces of Ireland.

Un' abbondanza che affamava.Entry Details: (It) a plenty that kept you hungry. (See Zobi, Storia Civile, I, 403: l'affamatrice abbon danza).

una compagna d'Adamo. Come si fesse?.Entry Details: (It) a mate for ADAM. How to make her?

una nuova messa/ (dodicesimo anno E.F.).Entry Details: (It) a new mass/ (12th year of the Fascist Era) / beautiful ceremony.

\"Uncurédéguisé / Me parait un curé dégu.Entry Details: (Fr) 'A disguised priest.. / Seems to me like a disguised priest.' At the door/(I) don't know, Sir, he seems like a disguised priest to me.'

U. S. Constitution.Entry Details: see CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES

U. S. N. A..Entry Details: the United States of North America.

[United States Senate].Entry Details: the upper house of the CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES.

Un peu moisi, plancher plus bas que le j.Entry Details: (Fr) A bit mildewed, floor(ing) lower than the garden. (See Flaubert, Un Coeur Simple).

Unruh, von.Entry Details: Fritz von Unruh, 1885- , German playwright, poet and novelist; officer in World War I.

[Unruh, Karl von].Entry Details: German military officer; father of Fritz von UNRUH.

un terzo cielo.Entry Details: (It) a third atmosphere. (See: Paradiso, 8, 37: il terzo cielo).

Urbino, Federico d'.Entry Details: Federigo da Montefeltro, 1422-82, First Duke of Urbino; a great Italian condottiere and politician, but more famous as a patron of arts and letters.

Ussel.Entry Details: town in Corrèze department, S central France; near VENTADOUR.

Ut animum nostrum purget.Entry Details: see DE LIBRO CHI-KING SIC CENSO

utilité publique, motif trop élevé.Entry Details: (Fr) public usefulness, too elevated a motive.

Utrecht.Entry Details: province in central Netherlands, the capital city thereof.

Uzano, Nic..Entry Details: Niccolò da Uzzano, d. 1432, Florentine statesman; as the leader of the aristocratic party of Florence, he was opposed to the growing power of the MEDICI; he was one of the few truly honest and disinterested men in Florentine politics of the day.

vacabile.Entry Details: (It) that which is to be vacant.

Vada.Entry Details: village of Livorno province, Tuscany, central Italy.

Val Cabrere.Entry Details: Valcabrère, village in the department of Haute-Garonne, S France.

Valcaire.Entry Details: Valcarce, river in León province, Spain.

Val di Chiana.Entry Details: Valle di Chiana, the valley of the Chiana river in central Italy.

Valencia.Entry Details: region and ancient kingdom in eastern Spain; became an independent Moorish kingdom (11th century); held by Ruy DIAZ (1094-99); finally reconquered from the Moors in 1238 by James I of Aragon.

Valenciennes.Entry Details: city of Nord department, N France.

Valent.Entry Details: Valenzia, city of Alessandria province, Piedmont, NW Italy.

Valturio.Entry Details: Roberto, d. 1489, Italian engineer and author; engineer on the Great ROCCA of Sigismondo MALATESTA; as Sigismondo's first secretary he urged Malatesta to support Florence rather than ALFONSO V of Aragon, author of De Re Militari (1472).

Van Berckel.Entry Details: Engelbert François, 1726-96, pensionary of Amsterdam and a friend of the American cause against England; a party to the first negotiations for a trade treaty between America and the Netherlands (1779).

Van Buren, Martin.Entry Details: 1782-1862, eighth President of the United States. Member of the US Senate from New York (1821-28), governor of New York (1829); US Secretary of State (1829-31); Vice-President of the US (1833-37); President (1837-41). In 1840 Van Buren was the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for the presidency, and in 1848 he was defeated on the Free-Soil ticket.

Van Capellen.Entry Details: see Joan Derk van der CAPELLEN TOT DEN POL.

Vandenberg.Entry Details: Arthur Hendrick, 1884-1952, member of the US Senate from Michigan (1928-52), he was leader of the Senate "isolationist bloc" before World War II, but later served as a US delegate to the United Nations conference in San Francisco (1945).

[Van den Santheuvel, Baron].Entry Details: deputy from Holland at the Paris Peace Conference (1782).

Van der Capellen.Entry Details: see Joan Derk van der CAPELLEN TOT DEN POL.

Vanderpyl.Entry Details: Fritz-Rene, 1876- , Dutch writer living in Paris at 13, rue Gay-Lussac, author of books on art

Van Myden.Entry Details: Van Muyden's Short Treatise on the Institutions of Justinian.

Van Renselaer.Entry Details: Stephen Van Rensselaer, 1764-1839, American army officer and politician, Lieutenant Governor of New York (1795-1901), member of the House of Representatives (1822-29), associated with DeWitt CLINTON's Republican party machine in New York State.

Van Staphorst.Entry Details: Nicholas and Jacob, fl. 1780, directors of the Dutch banking house having their name.

Van Tzin Vei.Entry Details: (Wang Ching-wei) 1885-1944, a Chinese statesman, a disciple of Sun Yat Sen, he broke with the Kuomingtang and became puppet ruler of Manchuria (1939-44).

Van Vloten.Entry Details: Van Vlooten, fl. 1780, a Dutch broker.

Varchi.Entry Details: Benedetto, 1503-65, Italian historian; author of Storia Fiorentino (published 17 21), a history of Florence, 1527-38, commissioned by Cosimo de' MEDICI.

Vauban.Entry Details: Sebastien le Prestre, Marquis de Vauban, 1633-1707, French military engineer; commissary general of fortifications (1678), marshal of France (1703).

Vaughn.Entry Details: Benjamin Vaughan, 1751-1835, British diplomat; a friend of Benjamin FRANKLIN, he sided with the Colonists during the Revolution and unofficially promoted conciliation in the Anglo-American negotiations of 1782; settled in America in 1796.

Vauguyon.Entry Details: Paul François, duc de la, 1746-1828, French diplomat, ambassador to Holland (1770) and to Spain (1784-90).

Vechu, Orazio.Entry Details: Orazio Vecchi, ?1550 -1605, Italian composer, known especially for his L'Amfiparnasso. Commedia Armonica.

Velásquez.Entry Details: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y Velásquez, 1599-1660, the Spanish painter.

Ven der Kemp.Entry Details: François Adriaan Van der Kemp, 1752-1829, Dutch scholar and soldier who migrated to New York; friend of John ADAMS.

Vendoise.Entry Details: a councillor of CHARLES VII of France.

Vendome.Entry Details: Vendôme, town in Loir-et-Cher department, N central France.

Vendramin.Entry Details: Cardinal Francesco (elected 1605), Venetian cleric. The Palazzo Vendramin is on the Campiello della Chiesa in Venice; it once contained a magnificent art collection.

Venerandam.Entry Details: (L) compelling adoration. (See: Georgius Dartona Cretensis' Latin translation of Homeric Hymn VI, To Aphrodite).

Venere, Cytherea \"aut Rhodon\"/ vento l.Entry Details: (It) VENUS, (L) CYTHERA "or Rhodes" (It) Ligurian wind, come.

Ventadour.Entry Details: former duchy in the department of Corrèze, S central France; near Limousin.

Ventadour, Lady of.Entry Details: Alice of Montpellier, wife of EBLIS III vicomte of Ventadour, the Provençal troubadour Bernart de Ventadour (1148-95) belonged to the court of Ventadour, but when Eblis discovered Bernart making songs to his wife he banished the troubadour and locked Alice in a tower; Bernart later joined the court of ELEANOR of Aquitaine.

Venter venustus, cunni cultrix.Entry Details: (L) belly beautiful, cunning in country matters.

Verbiest.Entry Details: Ferdinand, 1623-88, Jesuit missionary in China. He arrived in Peiping in 1660 and introduced the Chinese, whose astronomy was largely Ptolemaic, to the systems of Copernicus and Galileo; he was also employed by Emperor KANG-HI as a mathematician and a cannon founder. Verbiest's plea that Chinese priests be ordained, that they be allowed to say a vernacular Mass, and that ancestor worship be tolerated, was not granted by Rome.

Verdun.Entry Details: fortified town in NE France, in Lorraine on the Meuse, site of the longest and bloodiest battle of World War I in which Marshal PÉTAIN repulsed the Germans (1916).

Vergennes.Entry Details: Comte Charles Gravier de, 1717-87, French statesman; minister of foreign affairs under Louis XVI (1774-87).

Verjaring/ van den veldslag by Lexington.Entry Details: (Dut) Concerning/ the battle of LEXINGTON/ First memoir by Mr. ADAMS/ Impression of the Dutch Navy. (See: John Adams, Works, III, 279).

Vernon, W..Entry Details: William, 1719-1806, American merchant; in 1777 appointed chairman of the Navy Board of the Eastern Department.

Verona.Entry Details: city of Verona province, NE Italy; among its buildings is an ancient Roman amphitheater.

Verres.Entry Details: Gaius, C. 120-43, Roman administrator whose corruption astonished even the Romans.

Versailles.Entry Details: city S of Paris where Louis XIV built the palace known as Versailles.

Versailles (Court of).Entry Details: the Court of Versailles, at VERSAILLES.

Verucchio.Entry Details: Verrucchio, town and castle 10 miles S of Rimini, Italy.

Vervennes.Entry Details: see Comte Charles Gravier de VERGENNES.

Vesuvius.Entry Details: the volcano on the east side of the Bay of Naples.

Vexis.Entry Details: Vexin, ancient district of France, N of the Seine and the Oise.

via Balbo.Entry Details: via Caesar Balbo, a street in Rome.

Vicenza.Entry Details: capital of Venezia Euganea, NE Italy.

[Vickers].Entry Details: the international armament makers; Vickers has controlling interests with firms in many countries besides England and has (or had) connections with MITSUI, SCHNEIDER, etc.

Victor Emanuel.Entry Details: Victor Emmanuel II, 1820-78, King of Italy (1861-78).

Vidal.Entry Details: Peire, fl. 1175-1215, Provençal troubadour; followed Richard Coeur de Lion on the Third Crusade (1189-92); it is said that when he loved Loba de Perrautier he dressed in wolf-skins and was almost killed by hounds during a hunt.

Vidas.Entry Details: a Jewish merchant whom Ruy DIAZ, noted for his cunning, cheated.

videt et urbs.Entry Details: (L) he saw and cities. (See: Raphael of Volterra, trans. Odyssey, I, 2: qui mores hominum multorum vidit et urbes, quoted in Literary Essays, 265).

Vidkun.Entry Details: Vidkun Quisling, 1887-1945, Norwegian politician who collaborated in the German conquest of Norway (1940) and became head of the government under the German occupation.

viels.Entry Details: viell, an early form of the medieval viol.

Vildrac.Entry Details: Charles, 1882- , the French poet and playwright.

Villa Catullo.Entry Details: the villa on Lake Garda, Italy, where Catullus lived for a time; it was here that he wrote his salutation to the promontory of SIRMIO.

Villa Falangola.Entry Details: the villa in Sorrento where Martin VAN BUREN lived (c. 1854) after his retirement from public life.

vingt à vingtcinq navires dans le bassin.Entry Details: (Fr) twenty to twenty-five ships in the basin/ / warehouses (or armories) of the city are filled/ a man's day (is worth) 15 sous, / including food. (For this extract from the Journal of Count SARSFIELD for 5 June 1782, see John Adams, Works, III, 283).

Virgil.Entry Details: Publius Vergilius Maro, 70-19, the Roman poet.

Virgin, the.Entry Details: Coronation of the Virgin, a painting by VELÁS- QUEZ in the Prado, Madrid.

Virgo.Entry Details: a constellation due south of the handle of the Dipper, the Virgin, represented as a woman holding in her left hand a spike of grain.

Vischer.Entry Details: Visscher, fl. 1780, a pensionary of The Hague.

Visconti, Bianca.Entry Details: Bianca Maria Visconti, 1423-68, daughter of Filippo Maria VISCONTI, married Francesco SFORZA (1441).

[Visconti, Filippo Maria].Entry Details: 1392-1447, Duke of Milan; warred with Venice and Florence; his daughter, Bianca Maria VISCON- TI, married Francesco SFORZA, who took over the dukedom of Milan.

Visigoths.Entry Details: one of the tribes of West Goths; founded the Visigothic kingdom in Spain, southern France and Africa.

Viterbo, Paulo.Entry Details: Paulo da Viterbo, an officer in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Vitruvius.Entry Details: Marcus Vitruvius Pollio, fl. 1st century BC, Roman architect whose work served as one of the models for Renaissance architecture.

Vivante.Entry Details: Leone, 1887- , Italian author and critic; author of English Poetry (1950). Vivante lives in a villa on a hill outside Siena.

Vlaminck.Entry Details: Maurice, 1876-1905, the French painter, writer and printmaker.

V01 che passate per questa via.Entry Details: (It) you who pass through this street (you who go in this way).

Volpe.Entry Details: Giuseppe Volpi, Count di Misurata, 1877-1947, Italian statesman and financier; member of the Italian delegation to the Paris Conference (1919); minister of finance (1925-29).

Voltaire.Entry Details: François Marie Arouet de, 1694-1778, the French philosopher.

Von Moltke.Entry Details: Helmuth Karl Bernard, Graf von Moltke, 1800-91, Prussian field marshal; was responsible for the successes of the Prussian army in the Danish War (1864), the Austro-Prussian War (1866) and the Franco-Prussian War (1870-71).

Von Tirpitz.Entry Details: poss. Alfred von Tirpitz, 1849-1930, German admiral.

vous étes tres mal élevé / \nTiens, elle.Entry Details:
(Fr) you are very badly brought up (ill-mannered) 
Look, she's telling you
